If things get too heated, one of us will wander off—she might fling herself onto the sofa, I’ll poke around in “my corner” of the studio—until we both cool down. Then one of us will come back and say, “Tell me again why you felt hurt,” or “Help me see your side.” Once we’ve really listened, we usually make up by doing something we both love—sometimes it’s whipping up breakfast together (she handles the marmalade, I fry the eggs), other times we’ll crank up a favorite song and dance in the kitchen until we’re both laughing. By the end, we’re hugging it out, promising to respect each other’s feelings next time.
questions.answer_ch: 当吕诗恩和我发生冲突时，通常是她大声抗议开始的——她觉得某些事情不公平，而且毫不掩饰，而我则静静地指出我的看法，常常给出太多的事实。起初，我们会抢着说话：她受感情驱动，我受逻辑驱动。如果事情变得过于激烈，我们其中一个会走开——她可能会跳到沙发上，我则在工作室的“我的角落”里转悠——直到我们都冷静下来。然后，我们其中一个会回来，说：“告诉我你为什么觉得受伤，”或者“帮我看看你的观点。”一旦我们真正倾听对方，通常会通过一起做我们都喜欢的事情来和解——有时是一起做早餐（她负责橘子酱，我煎鸡蛋），有时是放一首喜欢的歌，在厨房里跳舞直到我们都笑起来。最后，我们会相拥而泣，承诺下次尊重彼此的感受。

questions.question_en: What is something new you have taught Luthien this year, and how did she react?
questions.question_ch: 你今年教给了露西恩什么新东西，她的反应如何？
questions.answer_en: This year I taught Luthien how to identify garden birds using my binoculars and nature guide: I showed her how to spot a blue tit by its yellow belly and blue cap, how to listen for the great tit’s “chick-a-dee” call, and we practised sitting very still under the oak in our yard. She watched with wide, sparkling eyes, and when at last she pointed out her first blue tit flitting through the leaves she threw her arms around me and let out the happiest squeal, then clutched my binoculars all afternoon, declaring, “I’m a real bird detective now!”
questions.answer_ch: 今年我教了路瑟恩如何用我的望远镜和自然指南识别花园里的鸟：我告诉她如何通过黄色的肚皮和蓝色的帽子来辨认蓝山雀，如何聆听大山雀的“咕咕”叫声，我们还在院子里的橡树下练习保持静止。她睁大眼睛，眼里闪烁着光芒，当她终于指出她看到的第一只蓝山雀穿过树叶时，便兴奋地拥抱了我，发出最快乐的尖叫，接着整个下午都紧紧握着我的望远镜，宣称：“我现在是真正的鸟类侦探了！”

questions.question_en: What is Luthien’s favorite game to play with you, and how do you teach her new rules or introduce her to new activities?
questions.question_ch: 露西恩最喜欢和你玩的游戏是什么？你如何教她新规则或介绍新活动？
questions.answer_en: Luthien’s favorite game had always been Snakes & Ladders because she delighted in the tiny dramas of sliding down a snake or climbing a ladder. I would sit beside her on the carpet, lay out the board, show her how to roll the dice and count each square aloud, and patiently guide her hand on her first few moves. When I introduced a new twist—say, earning a second turn for landing on a six—I demonstrated it on my own token, talking her through every step, then encouraged her to try it herself until she understood. Whenever she hesitated I broke the rule down into even simpler parts and let her practice those alone, praising her bravery each time she mastered a new rule. To introduce fresh activities I once built a pillow-fort obstacle course: I sketched a simple map on paper, walked her through each challenge, then quietly watched as she navigated the cushions and low tables on her own. Each small success made her beam, and before long she was suggesting her own rule-changes and teaching them back to me—an adventure that always felt as much mine as hers.
questions.answer_ch: 露西恩最喜欢的游戏一直是蛇和梯子，因为她喜欢滑下蛇或爬上梯子的微小戏剧。我会坐在她旁边的地毯上，铺开棋盘，教她如何掷骰子，并大声数出每一个方格，然后耐心指导她进行头几步。当我引入新的变化时——比如，掷出六可以再掷一次——我会在自己的棋子上示范，逐步讲解每一步，然后鼓励她自己尝试，直到她理解。每当她犹豫时，我会将规则拆分得更简单，让她单独练习，每当她掌握一个新规则时，我都会赞扬她的勇气。为了引入新的活动，我曾搭建了一个枕头城堡障碍赛：我在纸上画了一张简单的地图，带着她逐一挑战，然后悄悄地观察她独自穿越那些靠垫和低桌子。每一个小成功都让她开心不已，不久之后，她开始提出自己的规则改动，并教回给我——这段冒险总让我觉得既是她的，也是我的。

questions.question_en: How do you comfort Luthien when she’s upset or frightened, and can you recall a specific time you helped calm her?
questions.question_ch: 当露西恩感到不安或害怕时，你是如何安慰她的？你能回忆起一个你帮助她平静下来的具体时刻吗？
questions.answer_en: Whenever Lucien was frightened or upset I always tried to meet her at her level—literally, by kneeling so my eyes were at hers—and speak in a gentle, steady voice while offering my hand or a quiet hug. I knew she needed to feel heard first, so I’d ask, “What’s the scariest part?” and really listen to her answer before saying anything. Once she’d told me why she was upset, I’d remind her how brave she was, tell her a tiny part of a princess story we both loved, and suggest we take three deep breaths together—slow in through the nose and out through the mouth—to help her body relax. I remember clearly one afternoon in Richmond Park when she was trembling after a startled deer had bounded too close. I crouched beside her, wrapped my arm around her shoulders, and pointed out a blue tit flitting nearby, asking her to count how many times it hopped between branches. As she whispered “one… two… three,” her breathing evened out, her tears stopped, and by the time the bird flew off I saw her shoulders relax and her lips quirk into a shy smile—then we walked home hand in hand, and she told me she felt safe again.
questions.answer_ch: 每当露西恩感到害怕或沮丧时，我总是试图在她的水平线上与她沟通——字面上来说，就是跪下来让我的眼睛与她平视——以温柔而稳定的声音，伸出手或轻轻地拥抱她。我知道她首先需要感到被倾听，所以我会问：“最可怕的地方是什么？”然后认真倾听她的回答，在说任何话之前。一旦她告诉我为什么她感到沮丧，我就会提醒她有多勇敢，给她讲一个我们都喜欢的公主演绎的小故事，并建议我们一起深呼吸三次——慢慢通过鼻子吸气，再通过嘴巴呼气——来帮助她的身体放松。我清楚地记得在一个下午的瑞士公园，当她因为一只惊慌的鹿突然靠得太近而颤抖时。我蹲在她身旁，用手臂搂住她的肩膀，指着一只在附近飞来飞去的蓝雀，问她能数出它在树枝间跳了多少次。当她低声说出“一……二……三”时，她的呼吸平稳下来，眼泪止住了，当那只鸟飞走时，我看到她的肩膀放松了，嘴角露出了害羞的微笑——然后我们手牵手走回家，她告诉我她又感到安全了。

questions.question_en: What is something Luthien does that never fails to make you laugh, and how do you both share those moments with your parents?
questions.question_ch: 露西恩做的什么事情总是能让你笑，你们是如何与父母分享这些时刻的？
questions.answer_en: Whenever we’re at home Luthien will suddenly decide she’s a princess and insist on formal announcements—she storms into the living room in her tutu, lifts her chin and declares in a tiny but imperious voice, “Attention, subjects! Luthien Newton, Princess of Hampstead, commands you to greet her!”—then when I forget to curtsey properly she pouts so fiercely it’s impossible not to laugh. After the performance we race into the kitchen at dinner time to retell every hilarious detail to Mum and Dad, with Luthien demonstrating her grand entrance and me doing my best bow, and they collapse laughing, sometimes asking us to do it all again before they can even take a bite.
questions.answer_ch: 每当我们在家时，露西恩总是突然决定自己是公主，并坚持进行正式的宣告——她穿着芭蕾舞裙冲进客厅，抬起下巴，用微小但威严的声音宣布：“注意，臣民们！汉普斯特德的公主露西恩命令你们来迎接她！”——然后当我忘记正确鞠躬时，她会气鼓鼓地撅起嘴巴，让人忍不住想笑。表演结束后，我们在晚餐时间冲进厨房，把每一个搞笑的细节都讲给爸爸妈妈，露西恩展示她的盛大登场，而我则尽力鞠躬，他们笑得前仰后合，有时甚至要求我们再来一遍，才愿意吃第一口。

questions.question_en: How do you and Luthien celebrate her birthday together, and what special role do you like to play in planning her party?
questions.question_ch: 你和露西恩是怎么一起庆祝她的生日的，你喜欢在策划她的派对中扮演什么特别的角色？
questions.answer_en: I always woke Luthien at dawn with a ribbon in her hair and her favorite whole-wheat toast ready—her birthday breakfast became my proudest chore ever. We’d set the kitchen table with her tiny pink plates and a pile of storybooks about princesses, and I’d show her my latest marmalade-jam experiment, letting her pick her favorite flavour. Then I’d whisk her off to Hampstead Heath or Kew Gardens for our “sister’s tea party in the wild,” where I’d secretly hide little felt flowers I’d made among the blooms so she could discover them on our walk. Back home, I’d take charge of the invitations—hand-drawing each one with tiaras and unicorns—and draw up our party schedule, from “dress-up parade” to “royal dance-off.” As the guests arrived, I’d guide our homemade photo booth (a blanket strung between two trees) and hand out props—flower crowns for the girls, cardboard swords for the boys—while Luthien beamed in her favourite white dress. My special role was always “chief happiness engineer,” making sure every game, every ribbon and jam-topped scone, felt perfectly tailored to her princess-of-the-day dreams.
questions.answer_ch: 我总是在黎明时分用一条丝带把露西恩叫醒，准备好她最喜欢的全麦烤面包——她的生日早餐成了我最自豪的工作。我们会用她的小粉色盘子和一堆关于公主的故事书设置厨房桌子，我会给她展示我最新的橘子酱实验，让她挑选自己喜欢的口味。然后我会带她去汉普斯特德荒野或基尤花园，参加我们的“姐妹野外茶会”，我会在花丛中偷偷藏一些我做的小毛毡花，让她在散步时发现它们。回到家后，我会负责邀请函——每一张都是手绘的，画上头冠和独角兽——并制定我们的派对日程，从“化妆游行”到“皇家舞会”。客人到达时，我会引导我们的DIY照片亭（在两棵树间挂的毯子），发放道具——给女孩们花冠，给男孩们纸板剑——而露西恩则穿着她最喜欢的白色裙子笑容满面。我的特殊角色总是“首席幸福工程师”，确保每一个游戏、每条丝带和每个果酱松饼，都是为她的“当日公主”梦想量身定制的。

questions.question_en: What is one important lesson you’ve taught Luthien, and how did you figure out the best way to explain it to a younger child?
questions.question_ch: 你教给露西恩的一个重要课程是什么，你是怎么找到向小孩解释的最佳方式的？
questions.answer_en: I once taught Luthien that when someone’s feelings are hurt—like when a classmate is embarrassed—you don’t laugh, you offer comfort. I remembered how Maeve refused to join in when the boy in kindergarten soiled himself and how everyone respected her for it, so I told Luthien that story. Because she adores princess tales, I asked, “What would a kind princess do if she saw someone ashamed?” and she immediately said she’d help them feel better. I spoke in a gentle voice, used words she already knew, and linked the lesson to something she loves, so she grasped the idea of compassion right away.
questions.answer_ch: 我曾经教过Luthien，当有人受伤害时，比如同学感到尴尬时，你不要笑，而是要提供安慰。我想起了Maeve在幼儿园时拒绝参与那个男孩弄脏了自己的事情，大家都因此尊重她，所以我把这个故事告诉了Luthien。因为她喜欢公主的故事，我问：“如果一个善良的公主看到有人感到羞愧，她会怎么做？”她立刻回答说，她会帮助他们感觉好些。我用温和的语气，使用她已经知道的词汇，并将课程与她喜欢的事物联系起来，因此她立刻理解了同情的概念。

questions.question_en: What is something Luthien does that always makes you proud, and how do you encourage her to keep improving?
questions.question_ch: 露西恩做的哪件事总是让你感到骄傲，你是如何鼓励她继续进步的？
questions.answer_en: I’m always proud of the fierce sense of justice Luthien shows whenever she sees someone being treated unfairly—like the time she ran to protect Jeffery when Chris pushed him in the playground, insisting “Don’t laugh at him!” even though everyone else thought it was just a silly accident. Her instinct to speak up for someone smaller than herself, without worrying what other kids think, reminds me that real courage isn’t about muscles or speed but about standing by your convictions. To help her keep growing, I make sure to celebrate every small act of kindness she does—thanking her warmly, giving her the first choice of bedtime stories that night, or drawing her a little “justice star” next to her name on our family chart. I also share stories of people I admire—like Maeve from arts club who defended her classmates, or Rosa Ridley’s fearless tennis spirit—to show Luthien that speaking up is a strength heroes share. And whenever she hesitates, I remind her, “Your voice matters,” so she knows I trust her judgment and she learns to trust it too.
questions.answer_ch: 我总是为露西亚看到人们受到不公正对待时表现出的强烈正义感感到骄傲——就像她曾经在操场上冲去保护杰弗瑞，当克里斯推他时，她坚决地说：“不要笑他！”尽管其他人都认为那只是个愚蠢的意外。她为比自己小的人挺身而出的本能，不在乎其他孩子的想法，让我想起真正的勇气并不是力量或速度，而是坚持自己的信念。为了帮助她不断成长，我确保庆祝她每一个小小的善举——热情地感谢她，给她选择那晚睡前故事的优先权，或在我们的家庭图表上给她的名字旁边画一个小小的“正义星”。我还分享我欣赏的人的故事——例如艺术俱乐部的梅芙，她为同班同学辩护，或者罗莎·里德利那无畏的网球精神——以此让露西亚明白，发声是一种英雄所共有的力量。每当她犹豫时，我会提醒她：“你的声音很重要，”让她知道我信任她的判断，并学会信任自己。

questions.question_en: How do you handle moments when you and Luthien want the same toy or privilege—what compromises have you learned?
questions.question_ch: 当你和露西恩想要同一个玩具或权利时，你是如何处理这些时刻的——你学会了哪些妥协？
questions.answer_en: I remembered one afternoon when Luthien and I both reached for the same space-shuttle model at the same moment; I felt a rush of frustration, but then I suggested we divide our time in two-minute turns while the other watched and cheered us on, and she agreed. On another occasion we both wanted to sit in the front seat of Dad’s car, so we drew names from a hat and promised the loser the next time—and because Luthien trusted me to keep my promise, she accepted. From those experiences I learned that small timers, simple games of chance and keeping track of promises help us trade toys or privileges without tears; most important, I discovered that saying “I’m sorry” when I felt unfair and “thank you” when she yielded made our compromises feel like teamwork rather than defeat.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得有一个下午，露西恩和我在同一时刻都伸手去拿同一个航天飞机模型；我感到一阵挫败，但是我提议我们轮流每两分钟交换一次，另一个则在旁边观看和加油，她同意了。在另一个场合，我们都想坐在爸爸车的前座，所以我们抽签决定，向输的人承诺下次给他——因为露西恩相信我会履行我的承诺，所以她接受了。从这些经历中，我学会了小时间、简单的机会游戏和遵守承诺可以帮助我们在不流泪的情况下交换玩具或特权；最重要的是，我发现当我感到不公平时说“对不起”，而她让步时说“谢谢”，让我们的妥协更像是团队合作，而不是失败。

questions.question_en: What is a creative idea you and Luthien came up with together to solve a problem at home?
questions.question_ch: 你和露西恩一起想出的解决家庭问题的创意是什么？
questions.answer_en: Luthien and I were always tripping over her dress-up clothes strewn across the hallway so we turned an old set of cardboard boxes into a “Princess Tower Closet.” we taped them together into a tower shape, painted the whole thing white and blue (her favourite colours), cut out arched doorways as cubbyholes and attached little hooks for tiaras, wands and slippers, then drew a simple chart naming each shelf the “Royal Tiara Nook,” the “Wand Wing” and the “Slipper Moat.” once the tower was in place she loved returning every treasure to its proper turret and our hallway stayed neat—building it together felt like a real royal project.
questions.answer_ch: 卢西恩和我总是被她散落在过道上的服装绊倒，所以我们把一组旧纸箱变成了“公主塔衣柜”。我们把它们贴在一起，做成塔的形状，然后把整个东西涂成白色和蓝色（她最喜欢的颜色），切割出拱形门口作为储藏室，并附上小钩子用来挂冠冕、魔杖和拖鞋，然后画出一个简易的图表，将每个架子命名为“皇家王冠角”、“魔杖区”和“拖鞋护城河”。一旦塔搭建好，她就喜欢把每个宝物放回它们各自的塔楼，我们的过道也保持整洁——一起建造这个感觉就像一个真正的皇家项目。

questions.question_en: When Luthien is learning something new, how do you support her practice, and what do you learn in the process?
questions.question_ch: 当露西恩学习新知识时，你如何支持她的练习，同时你在这个过程中学到了什么？
questions.answer_en: When Luthien tackles something new, I first sit beside her and break the task into small, clear steps—whether it’s tying shoelaces, a new dance move or learning a Chinese character—then demonstrate each step slowly and let her try. I encourage her by naming every small success: “Great loop!” or “Well done on that stretch!” and only offer help when she truly needs it, so she builds confidence. I cheer her on, clap when she masters a bit more and sometimes we time her sprints together, recording each run in my notebook so she can see her own progress. Most importantly, I listen to how she feels—if she’s frustrated I remind her of how many times I scrambled eggs before I could do it without a burn. In the process I learn patience—I discover how different teaching is from learning, how explaining slows me down and deepens my own grasp of simple skills, and how empathy grows when I see the world through her wide-eyed curiosity. Supporting Luthien reminds me that every learner’s pace is unique and that real understanding comes when you guide someone gently but let them find the strength to do it themselves.
questions.answer_ch: 当露西恩尝试新事物时，我首先坐在她身边，将任务分解成小而清晰的步骤——无论是系鞋带、新舞步还是学习汉字——然后慢慢示范每一步，让她尝试。我通过称赞每一个小成功来鼓励她：“做得好！”或“这个伸展做得很棒！”只有在她真的需要帮助时才提供支持，这样她才能建立自信。我为她加油，掌声鼓励她掌握更多，有时我们一起计时她的冲刺，并在我的笔记本中记录每次跑步，以便她能看到自己的进步。最重要的是，我倾听她的感受——如果她感到沮丧，我会提醒她在我能做到不烫手之前煮了多少次鸡蛋。在这个过程中，我学会了耐心——我发现教学与学习的不同，解释使我放慢速度，深化我对简单技能的理解，而当我通过她好奇而宽广的视野看世界时，同情心也在增长。支持露西恩让我意识到，每个学习者的节奏都是独特的，真正的理解来自于温柔地引导他人，但也让他们找到自己行事的力量。

questions.question_en: How do you feel when you see Luthien achieve something for the first time, and how do you celebrate with her?
questions.question_ch: 当你看到露西恩第一次取得成就时，你的感觉如何？你是如何与她一起庆祝的？
questions.answer_en: I always felt a sudden rush of warmth in my chest—pride mixed with a touch of astonishment—whenever Luthien did something for the first time: her first perfect jump in gymnastics, the first time she read a whole sentence by herself, the moment she outpaced everyone in a sprint. In those moments my heart seemed to swell bigger than my ribcage, as if I’d discovered an entirely new continent inside me. I’d scoop her up in a tight hug, whispering “You did it!” into her hair, and she’d laugh that bright, tinkling laugh that made our whole living room feel like it was lit from within. Then we’d turn the achievement into a small celebration—her choice of treat (maybe a scone with Devonshire cream or a scoop of ice cream), a homemade certificate I’d draw with my 24-colour pencils, and often a quick dance-around-the-room to her favourite tune. If it was something truly big, we’d tell Mum and Dad over afternoon tea, and sometimes I’d add her name and the date to our stair-well “art wall” so everyone who visits can see just how far my little sister has leapt—quite literally, sometimes—because every first is a treasure worth remembering together.
questions.answer_ch: 每当露西恩第一次做某件事时，我总会感到胸口涌起一阵温暖的激动——自豪夹杂着一丝惊讶：她第一次在体操中跳出了完美的动作，第一次独自读完整个句子，或是她在短跑中领先所有人。在那些瞬间，我的心似乎比胸腔还要膨胀，就仿佛我在内心深处发现了一个全新的大陆。我会紧紧抱住她，低声在她的头发里说：“你做到了！”然后她会发出那种明亮而清脆的笑声，让整个客厅都仿佛被点亮。接着，我们会将这个成就变成一次小庆祝——她选择的零食（也许是德文郡奶油配的司康饼或是一球冰淇淋），我用我的24色铅笔画的自制证书，通常还会伴随着她最喜欢的音乐快速在房间里跳舞。如果是特别重要的成就，我们会在下午茶时告诉爸爸妈妈，有时我还会把她的名字和日期记在楼梯间的“艺术墙”上，让每位来访的客人都能看到我妹妹取得的进步——有时甚至是字面意义上的飞跃，因为每一个第一次都是值得我们一起铭记的珍贵记忆。

questions.question_en: How does your father’s work as a secondary school language teacher influence the way he helps you with homework?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲作为一名中学语言教师的工作如何影响他帮助你做作业的方式？
questions.answer_en: My dad’s experience as a secondary‐school language teacher shows up in the way he helps me with homework every day: he never simply gives me the answer but guides me through a series of questions so that I learn to spot mistakes and discover patterns in grammar and vocabulary on my own; he insists I explain what I think a sentence means before he offers a correction, because he knows that true understanding comes from articulating ideas, not memorizing rules; he draws diagrams and mind‐maps on a scrap of paper to help me visualise sentence structure just as he would in front of a class; he encourages me to use a learner’s dictionary and to underline new words in context so I build habits of independent study; he treats my weekly timetable like a lesson plan, breaking larger assignments into smaller steps and setting short checkpoints to keep me on track; and when he praises my effort he does so with the same sincere, measured feedback he’d give to his older students, which makes me proud but never complacent.
questions.answer_ch: 我爸爸作为中学语言教师的经验体现在他每天帮助我做作业的方式上：他从不简单地告诉我答案，而是通过一系列问题引导我，让我自己发现错误并找出语法和词汇的规律；他坚持让我解释我认为一个句子的意思，然后才给我纠正，因为他知道真正的理解来自于表达思想，而不是死记规则；他在一张废纸上画图和思维导图，帮助我可视化句子结构，就像他在课堂上做的一样；他鼓励我使用学习者字典，并在上下文中划出新单词，以便我养成独立学习的习惯；他把我的每周时间表当作课程计划，将较大的作业分解成较小的步骤，并设置短期检查点以确保我保持进度；当他赞扬我的努力时，他给出的反馈和他对年长学生所给予的同样真诚、恰到好处，这让我感到自豪但从不自满。

questions.question_en: What did your father share about growing up in 1984 that you find interesting or surprising?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲关于1984年成长的经历中，有什么让你觉得有趣或惊讶的分享？
questions.answer_en: He told me that when he was my age, growing up in 1984, there was no internet or smartphones—if he wanted to look something up he had to climb the stairs to our local library, pull the big Encyclopædia Britannica off the shelf, and turn dozens of heavy pages by hand.  He even remembers having to learn geography from paper maps taped to his bedroom wall and labelling them himself with coloured pencils.  I find it amazing that a decade ago anyone could get through school without typing a single word on a screen or tapping a search bar—everything had to be written longhand or looked up in those enormous tomes.  The idea that a whole afternoon’s homework might involve physically hunting through a card catalogue still seems almost like a game to me, but for him it was just how you learned.
questions.answer_ch: 他告诉我，当他和我这个年纪，成长于1984年时，那个时候没有互联网或智能手机——如果他想查找某样东西，就必须爬上楼去当地的图书馆，把厚厚的《大英百科全书》从书架上拿下来，用手翻动几十页沉重的书。他甚至记得必须从贴在他卧室墙上的纸质地图上学习地理，并用彩色铅笔自己标注。我觉得很惊讶，十年前有人能够在没有在屏幕上打出一个字或点击搜索框的情况下完成学业——一切都必须手写或在那些巨大的书籍中查找。想象整个下午的作业可能涉及亲自查找卡片目录，对我来说几乎像是一场游戏，但对他而言，这就是学习的方式。

questions.question_en: How does your father’s background in languages inspire you to learn Chinese, French, Spanish, and Japanese?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲的语言背景如何激励你学习中文、法语、西班牙语和日语？
questions.answer_en: My dad taught languages at the secondary school down the road, so ever since I was little I heard him explain tones and verb conjugations over breakfast. I remember him practicing Chinese characters with me at the kitchen table as a toddler, patiently guiding my hand across each stroke and insisting I say “谢谢” instead of “thanks.” When I was five he brought home French picture books and we spent Sundays hunting for “le chat” in every illustration, and at six he surprised me with a Spanish song he’d learned so we could sing together. Last year he started taking evening classes in Japanese, and I joined him in tracing kana in my notebook, copying his disciplined habit of looking up every new word. Watching him slip seamlessly from one language to another made me believe it was natural to speak four tongues, not a strange feat. His enthusiasm for the sounds, the stories and even the mistakes he made along the way taught me that learning a language was like making friends with another corner of the world. Because he never treated any language as “too hard” for me, I never thought I was too young to learn Chinese, French, Spanish or Japanese, and that confidence has carried me through every new phrase I’ve picked up.
questions.answer_ch: 我爸爸在附近的中学教语言，所以从小我就听他在早餐时讲解声调和动词变位。我记得他在厨房桌子上和我一起练习汉字，耐心地引导我的手写每一笔，坚决要求我说“谢谢”而不是“thanks”。当我五岁时，他带回了法语图画书，我们周日一起在每一幅插图中寻找“le chat”，六岁时他还给我惊喜，教我学唱他学过的西班牙歌。去年他开始上晚上的日语课程，我也跟着他在笔记本上描摹假名，模仿他查每一个新单词的严谨习惯。看着他自如地在几种语言之间切换，让我相信说四种语言是自然的，而不是一种奇怪的壮举。他对声音、故事甚至沿途犯下的错误的热情让我明白，学习一门语言就像是与世界的另一个角落交朋友。因为他从来没有把任何语言视为“太难”让我学习，我从来没有觉得我太小而不能学汉语、法语、西班牙语或日语，这种自信让我在学习新短语的过程中一直向前。

questions.question_en: What language or cultural story has your father shared from his classroom that inspired you to explore other cultures?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲在课堂上分享了哪种语言或文化故事，激励你去探索其他文化？
questions.answer_en: My father once told me the Mid-Autumn Festival legend in his Chinese class—the story of Chang’e fleeing to the Moon and her Jade Rabbit pounding the elixir of immortality—and he showed us Li Bai’s poem “Quiet Night Thought,” explaining how the Chinese words for “moon” and “home” carry the ache of distance. That tale stayed with me and sent me hunting for other moon myths: I read about Selene and Endymion in Greek stories, Tsukuyomi in Japan, the Man in the Moon in Europe, and even lunar legends from the Maya. It taught me that every culture spins its own language and poetry around the same stars, and exploring those different voices became my first step toward understanding the wider world.
questions.answer_ch: 我父亲曾在他的中文课上告诉我中秋节的传说——嫦娥奔月和她的玉兔捣药的故事——并给我们展示了李白的诗《静夜思》，解释了中文中“月亮”和“家”这两个词所蕴含的思乡之情。这个故事让我铭记在心，也让我开始寻找其他的月亮神话：我阅读了希腊故事中的塞勒涅和恩底弥翁、日本的月读、欧洲的月亮人，以及玛雅的月亮传说。这教会我每种文化都围绕着同样的星星编织自己的语言和诗歌，探索这些不同的声音成为我理解更广阔世界的第一步。

questions.question_en: How does your father balance being a teacher and a parent—what advice does he give you about studying or managing your time?
questions.question_ch: 你爸爸如何平衡当老师和当父亲——他给你关于学习或时间管理的建议是什么？
questions.answer_en: My father always said that a teacher’s lesson plan and a family’s daily plan share the same backbone: careful timing and clear priorities. He would rise before dawn to mark essays and prepare his Chinese language class, then set aside the hour between school’s end and my afternoon tea not for more work but for our walk home together, where I could tell him about my day. At dinner he taught me to sketch a simple timetable: block out fixed commitments—school, piano practice or nature walks—then slot in homework and reading in bite‐size sessions, with short breaks for fresh air or sketching. He warned me that spreading myself too thin made every task feel half-done, so he urged “single-tasking,” finishing one assignment before starting the next. Whenever I fretted about exams, he reminded me that passion was the best motivation—if I chose the right order for my tasks, based on what interested me most, I’d find the energy to keep going. By watching him plan lessons, grade papers quickly without fuss, and still read bedtime stories to me, I learned that managing time wasn’t about doing more things, but about doing the right things, in the right order, at the right time.
questions.answer_ch: 我父亲总是说，教师的课程计划和家庭的日常计划有着相同的核心：精确的时间安排和清晰的优先事项。他会在黎明前起床批改论文，为中文课做准备，然后在放学和我下午茶之间留出一小时，不是为了干更多的工作，而是为了和我一起走回家，让我告诉他我的一天。在晚餐时，他教我草拟一个简单的时间表：划出固定的承诺——学校、钢琴练习或自然散步——然后把作业和阅读安排为小块时间，期间有短暂的休息时间用于透气或素描。他告诫我，分散精力会让每项任务都感觉做得不够好，因此他鼓励我“专注于单一任务”，在开始下一个任务之前完成一个作业。每当我对考试感到焦虑时，他总是提醒我，热情是最好的动力——如果我根据最感兴趣的事情选择任务的合适顺序，就能够找到继续下去的能量。通过观察他制定课程计划、迅速且不费劲地批改论文，同时仍然给我讲睡前故事，我明白了管理时间并不是做更多的事情，而是要在正确的时间，以正确的顺序做正确的事情。

questions.question_en: What’s a memorable trip you took with your father, and what did you learn about the world from his perspective?
questions.question_ch: 你和父亲一起去过的一个难忘的旅行是什么？你从他的角度学到了关于世界的什么？
questions.answer_en: I remember one summer evening when Dad, Uncle Owen and I went camping in New Forest National Park to watch the Perseid meteor shower under a truly dark sky. After Mum dropped us off, Dad spread our blankets on a hilltop and we lay back staring up while Dad quietly pointed out constellations—Orion, the Plough, the Milky Way—and explained how ancient sailors had used those same stars to guide their ships. When the meteors began streaking overhead he told me about Voyager 1, the tiny probe that had travelled for decades beyond the planets, carrying a golden record with greetings from Earth, and how scientists use the Drake Equation to estimate the number of other worlds that might have life. In those hours, as I watched shooting stars arch across the sky, I learned from Dad’s perspective that our planet is only a small part of a vast, beautiful universe full of mysteries waiting to be explored—and that the greatest adventures often begin by simply looking up and asking questions.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得一个夏天的晚上，爸爸、欧文叔叔和我去新森林国家公园露营，想在真正黑暗的天空下观赏英仙座流星雨。在妈妈把我们放下后，爸爸在山顶铺开我们的毯子，我们躺下来仰望天空，爸爸静静地指着星座——猎户座、北斗七星和银河，并解释古代水手是如何利用这些星星来引导他们的船只的。当流星开始在头顶划过时，他告诉我关于旅行者1号的故事，这个微小的探测器已经在行星之外旅行了几十年，携带着一张金唱片，上面是来自地球的问候，科学家们是如何使用德雷克方程来估计可能存在生命的其他世界数量的。在那几个小时里，当我看着流星划过天空时，我从爸爸的角度了解到，我们的星球只是一个浩大美丽宇宙中一个小小的部分，那里充满了等待被探索的奥秘——而且，最大的冒险往往只是从仰望星空和提问开始。

questions.question_en: How do you and your father discuss your future goals—does he offer suggestions for subjects you might excel in?
questions.question_ch: 你和你的父亲如何讨论你们的未来目标——他会给你提供可能擅长的科目的建议吗？
questions.answer_en: I often sat with Dad at our kitchen table after dinner, excitedly telling him about some new fossil or the latest experiment I’d tried, and he’d listen carefully before gently steering me toward subjects he thought played to my strengths—biology and geology because of my love of the Natural History Museum, mathematics since I could see patterns in everything, even in cooking ratios, and language when I surprised him by composing stories in Chinese; he never forced me down any particular path but suggested courses and clubs at school that might sharpen those talents, always reminding me that it was my curiosity and joy in learning, not any single grade, that would shape my future.
questions.answer_ch: 我常常和爸爸坐在厨房的餐桌旁，饭后兴奋地告诉他一些新发现的化石或我尝试的最新实验，他会仔细倾听，然后温和地引导我去关注他认为能发挥我优势的话题——生物和地质，因为我热爱自然历史博物馆，数学因为我能在任何事物中看到模式，甚至是在烹饪的比例中，还有语言，特别是当我用中文写故事时让他感到惊讶；他从未强迫我走上任何特定的道路，而是建议我在学校选择一些可以培养这些才能的课程和社团，始终提醒我，塑造我未来的不是单一的成绩，而是我对学习的好奇心和快乐。

questions.question_en: What is your father’s proudest moment related to you or your sister, and how did he celebrate it with the family?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲和你或你妹妹有关的最自豪时刻是什么，他是如何与家人一起庆祝的？
questions.answer_en: My father’s proudest moment wasn’t when I aced a test or when Lucy sprinted to first place in her kindergarten race, but on a sunny afternoon in Qiu Garden when I lay on the grass watching my hand move against the sky and blurted out, “Dad, why am I alive?” He froze, eyes wide, then tears filled them as he admitted he’d never heard a question so profound, so full of wonder, at my age—or any age. He swept me into a fierce hug while Mum wiped her own tears and said she’d never been prouder. That very evening he surprised us both by presenting me with a set of “Big Questions from Little People” books and we spent the rest of the week curled up after dinner, reading them aloud together, making that simple moment into a family celebration of curiosity and love.
questions.answer_ch: 我父亲最自豪的时刻不是我考试得了满分，也不是露西在幼儿园比赛中冲到第一名，而是在秋园的一个阳光明媚的下午，当我躺在草地上看着手在天空中移动，突然问道：“爸爸，我为什么活着？”他愣住了，双眼睁得大大的，然后泪水盈满了眼眶，他承认在我这个年龄——或者任何年龄——都从未听到过如此深刻、充满 wonder 的问题。他紧紧抱住我，而妈妈擦干了自己的眼泪，说她从未如此感到自豪。就在那天晚上，他给我们俩带来了惊喜，送我一套《小朋友的大问题》书籍，接下来的一周我们在晚饭后蜷缩在一起，一起大声阅读，让那个简单的时刻变成了家庭对好奇心和爱的庆祝。

questions.question_en: What is one piece of advice your father gave you that you still think about every day, and why does it resonate?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲给过你的一个建议是什么，至今仍让你每天思考，为什么它会与你产生共鸣？
questions.answer_en: My father once told me that instead of wasting time doubting myself, I should use every minute to work toward what I love, because the world is full of problems waiting to be solved and discoveries waiting to be made. I think of those words every morning when I’m faced with a tricky math problem, a stubborn science experiment, or a new recipe in the kitchen, because whenever I feel the knot of uncertainty in my stomach I remember his advice and choose to act rather than hesitate. It resonates so deeply because it turned my fear of making mistakes into excitement about learning, and it reminds me that every step—no matter how small—is part of my own great adventure.
questions.answer_ch: 我父亲曾告诉我，与其浪费时间怀疑自己，不如把每一分钟用来朝着我所热爱的方向努力，因为这个世界充满了等待解决的问题和等待被发现的奇迹。每当早上我面对一个棘手的数学问题，一个顽固的科学实验，或者厨房中的新食谱时，我都会想到这段话，因为每当我感到肚子里的不确定感时，我就会想起他的建议，选择行动而不是犹豫。这句话让我深有共鸣，因为它把我对犯错的恐惧转变成了对学习的兴奋，并且提醒我，每一步——无论多么微小——都是我伟大冒险的一部分。

questions.question_en: How does your father involve you in his teaching or lesson planning, and what have you learned from that experience?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲是如何让你参与他的教学或课程规划的，你从中学到了什么？
questions.answer_en: My father often asked me to be his “young consultant” when he planned his Chinese language lessons: he’d sketch out a new vocabulary topic or cultural story on his desk at home and invite me to point out which words or examples I found boring or confusing, and which surprised or delighted me. Sometimes he’d test me on idioms he was about to teach, then ask, “How would you explain this to a friend who’s never heard it before?” Other times he’d let me help him choose illustrations for his slides—my job was to spot pictures that made me curious enough to ask questions, because he knew that if I was intrigued, his students would be too. From these sessions I learned that good teaching isn’t just about knowing the material but about thinking carefully how each word, each image, each activity feels to someone encountering it for the first time. I saw how much patience and creativity it takes to turn a dry list of characters into a memorable story, and I learned the power of asking “Why?”—not only to understand a lesson but to shape one that makes others eager to learn.
questions.answer_ch: 我父亲经常让我成为他的“年轻顾问”，当他规划中文课程时：他会在家里的桌子上勾勒出一个新的词汇主题或文化故事，并邀请我指出哪些词汇或例子让我觉得无聊或困惑，哪些让我感到惊讶或愉悦。有时他会让我测试他即将教授的成语，然后问：“你会如何向一个从未听过这个的人解释？”有时他会让我帮助选择他幻灯片的插图——我的工作是找到让我好奇到想提问的图片，因为他知道如果我感到好奇，他的学生也会如此。通过这些课堂我学到了，好的教学不仅仅是对材料的了解，更是仔细思考每个词汇、每个图像、每个活动对第一次接触它的人来说是什么感觉。我看到了将一串干巴巴的汉字变成一个令人难忘的故事需要多少耐心和创造力，我也学到了问“为什么？”的力量——不仅是为了理解一节课，更是为了塑造一堂使他人渴望学习的课。

questions.question_en: When your father is preparing for a school event or parent–teacher meeting, how do you help him get ready?
questions.question_ch: 当你的父亲在为学校活动或家长会准备时，你如何帮助他准备？
questions.answer_en: I sort Dad’s printed schedules and lesson outlines into neat piles on the dining table, staple his handouts, charge his laptop and remind him to pack the HDMI cable and his favorite pen. I polish his shoes and smooth his tie, then make him a cup of tea so he can review his notes calmly. I even quiz him on the questions he plans to ask parents by pretending to be a parent myself. Finally I tuck a fresh notebook into his bag, give him a cheerful thumbs-up, and watch him head off feeling perfectly ready.
questions.answer_ch: 我把爸爸的打印日程和课程大纲整理成整齐的堆放在餐桌上，给他的手稿钉好，给他的笔记本电脑充电，提醒他打包HDMI线和他最喜欢的笔。我擦亮他的鞋子，把他的领带整理好，然后给他泡一杯茶，让他能平静地复习笔记。我甚至假装成家长，给他出题，考问他计划向家长提问的问题。最后，我在他的包里放一本新笔记本，给他一个愉快的竖起大拇指，看到他信心满满地出门。

questions.question_en: What is a story your father has shared about his own childhood that made you see him differently?
questions.question_ch: 你父亲分享过的关于他自己童年的故事是什么，让你对他有了不同的看法？
questions.answer_en: I remember him telling me how, when he was eight, he had a terrible stutter and would freeze every time the teacher asked him a question. Every morning he’d lie awake in bed, dreading the moment he’d have to answer roll call, until one day his drama teacher encouraged him to join the school play. He spent weeks rehearsing a simple monologue—“In the beginning was the Word…”—and the first time he stepped on stage he trembled so badly he thought he’d faint, but he forced himself to finish. When he did, the whole auditorium cheered. He told me in that moment he realized that finding your voice often meant facing your greatest fear, and it made me see him not just as the calm, confident dad I knew, but as a boy who’d fought hard to speak up.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得他告诉我，当他八岁时，他有严重的口吃，每次老师问他问题时，他都会呆住。每天早上，他躺在床上，心里害怕着自己必须回答点名的时刻，直到有一天他的戏剧老师鼓励他参加学校的表演。他花了好几个星期排练一个简单的独白——“起初有道……”——第一次上台时他紧张得手足无措，甚至觉得自己会晕倒，但他逼着自己完成了。当他完成时，整个礼堂都为他欢呼。他告诉我，在那一刻他意识到，找到自己的声音往往意味着面对自己最大的恐惧，这让我不仅仅把他看作我熟悉的冷静自信的爸爸，而是一个为表达自己而努力奋斗的男孩。

questions.question_en: How do you and your father decide on family rules—do you ever suggest changes, and how does he respond?
questions.question_ch: 你和你父亲是如何决定家庭规则的？你会建议改变吗？他是如何回应的？
questions.answer_en: I’ve noticed that most of our family rules—bedtime, chores, screen-time limits and pet care—get set during our weekly Sunday evening sit-down. Dad and I spread out my homework planner, his laptop and a cup of tea; he asks me what works and what doesn’t, I point out when too little time is left for projects I care about, or when a rule feels unfair (for example insisting on lights-out at 8 p.m. even on Friday). Often I suggest tweaks—like shifting bedtime to 8:30 p.m. on weekends or rotating dish-washing duties—and Dad pauses to really think it over, explains why he worries about too much late reading, or agrees and says we’ll try my idea for a month. Once, when I explained that forcing me to practise tennis every Saturday was making me resent sport, Dad admitted he’d been listening to his own wishes instead of mine and stopped that rule altogether. He never dismisses my voice—he might ask for evidence (how late I read, how often chores really slip) but he always gives reasons and welcomes compromises, which makes me feel respected and more responsible for keeping the rules.
questions.answer_ch: 我注意到我们家庭的大部分规则——睡觉时间、家务活、屏幕时间限制和宠物照顾——都是在我们每周日的晚上会议上制定的。爸爸和我会把我的作业 planner、他的笔记本电脑和一杯茶摆开；他询问哪些安排有效，哪些无效，我会指出留给我在意的项目的时间太少，或者当某个规则感觉不公平时（比如坚持在晚上 8 点关灯，即使是星期五）。我经常建议调整——比如周末把睡觉时间改为晚上 8:30 或者轮流洗碗——而爸爸会停下来仔细考虑，解释他为什么担心过多的夜间阅读，或者同意并说我们会试试我的主意一个月。有一次，当我解释强迫我每周六练习网球让我对运动产生反感时，爸爸承认他一直在听从自己的愿望，而不是我的，并完全取消了那个规则。他从不忽视我的声音——他可能会要求证据（我晚上阅读多晚，家务活到底有多频繁），但他总会给出理由并欢迎妥协，这让我感到被尊重，也更负责任地遵守规则。

questions.question_en: What medical or health tip has your mother taught you that you now use in your daily habits—like hand-washing or checking for fever?
questions.question_ch: 你妈妈教过你的哪条医疗或健康建议，你现在在日常习惯中使用，比如洗手或测量体温？
questions.answer_en: My mother taught me that keeping germs away is as simple as washing my hands properly and knowing when to check for fever. Every time I come in from outside or before I eat, I wet my hands, lather soap for at least twenty seconds—scrubbing the backs, palms, between each finger and even under my nails—then rinse and dry with my own clean towel. To make sure I’ve timed it right, I hum “Happy Birthday” twice in my head. She also showed me that to sense a fever before I even grab the thermometer, I can press the palm of my hand or the back of my wrist against my forehead or neck—areas where the skin is thin and warm—and if it feels hotter than usual, I know I must take my temperature properly with the digital thermometer under my tongue. These simple steps now fit into my day so naturally that I hardly notice them, yet they give me the confidence that I’m doing my part to stay healthy.
questions.answer_ch: 我妈妈教我保持细菌远离的方法其实很简单，就是要正确洗手和知道何时测量体温。每次我从外面回来或在吃饭前，我都会先把手弄湿，然后涂上肥皂，至少搓洗二十秒——清洗手背、掌心、每个手指之间，甚至指甲下——然后用自己的干净毛巾冲洗和擦干。为了确保我计时正确，我会在脑海里哼两遍“生日快乐”。她还告诉我，在我拿体温计之前，可以用手掌或手腕的背面贴在额头或脖子上——这些地方的皮肤比较薄且温暖——如果感觉比平常热，我就知道需要用电子体温计在舌下正确测量体温。这些简单的步骤现在已经融入我的日常生活，我几乎没有注意到，但它们让我有信心在保持健康方面尽了自己的努力。

questions.question_en: How do you and your mother bond over storytelling—does she share any favorite patient anecdotes or family stories at bedtime?
questions.question_ch: 你和你母亲如何通过讲故事建立联系——她在睡前分享任何喜欢的病人趣事或家庭故事吗？
questions.answer_en: I often lay beneath my quilt while Mum sat on the edge of my bed, her stethoscope slung over her shoulder like a friendly alligator waiting to tell me tales. She never named real patients, of course, but she loved to invent characters from her day at the clinic: there was Mr. Patel, who insisted his sneeze sounded like a foghorn and taught everyone in the waiting room to cover their mouths, and little Rosie who swallowed a jellybean and declared it “the greatest adventure of her life” once it came out again. Sometimes she wove those moments into our family tapestry, recalling how her own grandmother Orla once said you could “hear the roses bloom” if you listened closely enough—and I’d imagine petals unfurling in the dark. Other nights she’d slip into a story about my father as a boy, hiking through Ireland’s fields in search of fairies, proudly bearing tales of his first fossil discovery. As she spoke, I felt our minds walking side by side through each strange and wonderful world—hers of caring for others, mine of chasing butterflies and beetles—until at last she whispered “Good night, my scientist,” and I drifted to sleep, already curious about what tomorrow’s story might be.
questions.answer_ch: 我常常躺在被子底下，而妈妈坐在我床边，听诊器挂在她的肩上，就像一只友好的鳄鱼，等着告诉我故事。她当然不会提及真实的病人，但她喜欢从诊所的日常中编造角色：有帕特尔先生，他坚称自己的喷嚏听起来像雾号，教会候诊室里的每个人要遮住嘴；还有小罗西，她吞下了一颗果冻豆，并在它再出来时宣称这是“她一生中最大的冒险”。有时她会把这些瞬间编织进我们的家庭故事中，回忆起她自己的祖母奥尔拉曾说过，如果你认真倾听，就能“听见玫瑰开放”的声音——我会想象在黑暗中花瓣绽放的样子。其他晚上，她会讲起我父亲小时候的故事，讲述他在爱尔兰的田野间寻觅仙子，自豪地分享他的首次化石发现。随着她的讲述，我感觉我们的思维并肩走过每一个奇异而美妙的世界——她的世界是关心他人，我的世界是追逐蝴蝶和甲虫，直到最后她轻声说：“晚安，我的科学家。”我便沉沉入睡，已经对明天的故事充满好奇。

questions.question_en: What’s a time you accompanied your mother during her rounds at the community hospital, and what did you observe about her work?
questions.question_ch: 你陪伴你母亲在社区医院巡岗的时候，有什么印象？你观察到了她工作的哪些方面？
questions.answer_en: One afternoon last spring I asked Mum if I could join her on hospital rounds and she agreed, so we parked by the community hospital and I followed her through the automatic doors into a buzzing corridor. She greeted every patient by name, gently shook their hands and quietly reviewed their charts on a wheeled tablet computer. The first patient was an elderly man with a deep cough; I watched Mum place her stethoscope on his back, listen attentively, then look up and explain in calm, simple language how his antibiotics were helping. When a young mother fretted over her toddler’s fever, Mum crouched to the child’s level, offered a toy lion for comfort and showed the mother how to use a digital thermometer properly. Between patients I noticed Mum exchanging quick jokes with the nurse at the station, comparing notes on blood test results, then pausing to wash her hands with that special hospital soap we keep at home. I saw her kindness in the way she remembered small details—‘You love strawberry jam, don’t you?’ she teased a patient recovering from surgery—and the way she consulted medical reference charts on her tablet when she wasn’t sure of a dosage. By the end of that afternoon I understood that being a doctor meant not only knowing anatomy and illness but also listening with your head and your heart, and I decided I wanted to learn that balance too.
questions.answer_ch: 去年春天的一个下午，我问妈妈是否可以跟她一起去医院查房，她答应了，于是我们把车停在社区医院旁，我跟着她走过自动门进入繁忙的走廊。她逐一用名字问候每位病人，轻轻握手，安静地在移动平板电脑上查看病历。第一位病人是一位有着深沉咳嗽的老年男士；我看着妈妈把听诊器放在他的背上，专心倾听，然后抬头用平静简单的语言解释抗生素如何在帮助他。当一位年轻母亲对孩子的发烧感到烦恼时，妈妈蹲下来与孩子同一高度，递给他一只玩具狮子以示安慰，并教母亲如何正确使用数字温度计。在病人间隙，我注意到妈妈与站台的护士迅速开玩笑，比较血液检测结果，然后暂停用我们在家里备的特殊医院肥皂洗手。我看到她的善良体现在她记住的小细节上——“你喜欢草莓酱，对吧？”她用调侃的语气问一位正在康复的病人——以及当她不确定药物剂量时查阅平板电脑上的医学参考图表。到那个下午结束时，我明白作为医生不仅意味着了解解剖学和疾病，还包括用头脑和心灵倾听，我决定也想学会这种平衡。

questions.question_en: How does your mother encourage you when you feel sensitive to criticism, and what comforting words does she use when you’re upset?
questions.question_ch: 你妈妈在你对批评敏感时是如何鼓励你的，她在你感到沮丧时使用了哪些安慰的话？
questions.answer_en: I remember once after I stumbled over a line in the school play and felt my cheeks burn with shame, my mother sat beside me on the sofa, took my hand in hers and said she’d seen how hard I’d practised and that one mistake didn’t undo all the steps I’d learned; whenever I felt crushed by a teacher’s stern words or by my own fear of being wrong she would whisper, “It’s only one moment, it doesn’t change what you are capable of,” or “I love you exactly as you are,” and then she would gently stroke my hair and remind me that even the greatest scientists made mistakes before their brightest discoveries, which always helped me believe, bit by bit, that everything would be all right.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得有一次在学校的演出中，我结结巴巴地念了一句台词，感到脸颊因羞愧而发烫，妈妈坐在沙发旁，握着我的手说她看到了我练习的努力，一次错误并不能抵消我所学的所有步骤；每当我被老师严厉的话语或自己对出错的恐惧压垮时，她就会轻声说：“这只是一个瞬间，这并不改变你所能做到的。”或者“我爱你，正如你现在的样子。”然后她会轻轻抚摸我的头发，提醒我即使是最伟大的科学家在实现他们最辉煌的发现之前也会犯错误，这总是让我一点一点地相信，一切都会好起来的。

questions.question_en: What is one recipe or comfort food you learned to make with your mother, and why is it special to you both?
questions.question_ch: 你和你母亲学会做的哪一道食谱或安慰食品对你们来说特别？为什么它对你们俩都特别？
questions.answer_en: I learned to make cream tea scones with my mother one damp Saturday afternoon: we measured the flour, rubbed in cold butter until it looked like fine breadcrumbs and stirred in just enough milk to bring the dough together, then she showed me how to pat it into a round on the floured board and cut perfect circles. As the scones tumbled golden from the oven we slipped them open, piled one half with Devonshire cream and her homemade strawberry jam, and sat by the kitchen window sipping tea while we ate. It became our secret ritual—watching steam curl from the warm scones and listening to her gentle laughter as I dribbled jam down my chin—so every time I taste that creamy sweetness, I feel both proud of what I’ve learned and comforted by the memory of her patient hands guiding mine.
questions.answer_ch: 我在一个潮湿的星期六下午跟我妈妈学做奶油茶司康：我们量了面粉，揉进冷黄油，直到它看起来像细面包屑，然后搅拌进刚好足够的牛奶把面团揉合在一起。接着，她教我如何在撒了面粉的案板上将面团拍成圆饼并切出完美的圆形。当司康从烤箱中金黄滚落时，我们轻轻打开它的一半，放上德文郡奶油和她自制的草莓酱，坐在厨房的窗边喝茶边享用。这个成了我们的秘密仪式——看着蒸汽从温暖的司康上缭绕升起，听着她温柔的笑声，我的草莓酱不小心滴下到下巴上——每次我品尝那丝滑的甜美，心中都感到自豪，因为我学到了东西，也被她耐心的手引导着我的记忆所安慰。

questions.question_en: How does Dr. Kate Newton’s work as a general practitioner shape your understanding of health and medicine at home?
questions.question_ch: 凯特·牛顿医生作为全科医生的工作如何影响您对家庭健康和医学的理解？
questions.answer_en: When I saw Mum arriving home after long days at the clinic, I realized that being healthy wasn’t just about not having a fever but about everyday choices: washing hands before meals, eating balanced foods, stretching after sitting too long, even talking through worries rather than hiding them. Watching Dr. Newton gently question a patient about sleep or stress taught me that medicine is as much listening and understanding someone’s life as it is prescribing pills. At home she never used big medical words without explaining them—when I asked what blood pressure meant she drew little pipes on a napkin and showed me how narrowing passages can slow or speed up flow—so I learned early that anatomy and physics go hand in hand. She encouraged me to keep first‐aid basics in my desk, taught me how to clean and bandage scratches after bike rides, and reminded me that prevention—vaccines, check‐ups, wearing a helmet—was more powerful than any cure. In her office she took time to reassure children who were nervous about injections; at our kitchen table she reassured me that science and compassion were both part of being a doctor. Because of her, I came to understand that good medicine is rooted in observation, careful questioning, evidence‐based treatment and, above all, kindness.
questions.answer_ch: 当我看到妈妈在诊所工作了很长时间后回到家时，我意识到健康不仅仅是不发烧，而是与日常选择有关：饭前洗手，吃均衡饮食，坐太久后拉伸，甚至与他人沟通烦恼而不是隐藏它们。观看牛顿医生温和地询问患者关于睡眠或压力的问题教会我，医学不仅仅是开药，更是倾听和理解一个人的生活。在家里，她从不使用复杂的医学术语而不加解释——当我问血压是什么意思时，她在餐巾纸上画了小管子，并向我展示了通道变窄如何影响血液流动——因此我很早就了解到解剖学和物理学是息息相关的。她鼓励我在书桌里备好基础的急救用品，教我如何在骑自行车后清洗和包扎伤口，并提醒我预防——疫苗、检查、佩戴头盔——比任何治疗都更具力量。在她的办公室，她花时间安慰那些对注射感到紧张的孩子；在我们的餐桌上，她让我明白科学和同情心都是作为医生的重要组成部分。正因为她，我开始理解良好的医学根植于观察、细致的提问、基于证据的治疗，更重要的是， kindness。

questions.question_en: What advice has your mother given you about being sensitive to others’ feelings, based on her experience caring for patients?
questions.question_ch: 你妈妈根据照顾病人的经验，给你关于对他人感受敏感的建议是什么？
questions.answer_en: My mum says that being sensitive to someone’s feelings means more than just knowing what hurts them physically; it’s about noticing the little signs—a quiver in their voice, a downcast glance, the way they clutch their coat or fidget with their hands—and remembering that behind every patient chart is a person who wants kindness as much as medicine. She taught me to pause before I speak, to ask “How are you?” and really listen, then mirror their words gently so they know I understand, and always to explain what I’m going to do before I do it so they feel safe. She reminds me that a simple question like “Is there anything you’d like?” or offering a quiet smile can make people feel seen, and that sometimes the most powerful medicine is a caring presence, not a prescription.
questions.answer_ch: 我妈妈说，敏感于他人的感受不仅仅是了解他们身体上的疼痛；它还涉及到注意那些细微的迹象——声音中的颤抖、低垂的目光、他们紧握外套的方式或是手指的不安——并记住每一个病历背后都是一个渴望善意与药物同样重要的人。她教我在说话前要暂停一下，问“你还好吗？”并真正倾听，然后温柔地反映他们的话，让他们知道我理解，始终在做任何事情之前解释我要做什么，让他们感到安全。她提醒我，一个简单的问题，比如“有什么想要的吗？”或者一个温暖的微笑，都可以让人感到被关注，有时最强大的“药物”是关心的陪伴，而不是处方。

questions.question_en: How do you and your mother celebrate her birthdays and milestones, given her busy schedule at the community hospital?
questions.question_ch: 你和你母亲如何在她忙于社区医院的工作之余庆祝她的生日和里程碑？
questions.answer_en: Though Mum often works late at the hospital I never let her birthday pass in silence: early in the morning I made her whole-wheat toast with Bonne Maman marmalade and surprise-wrapped our small kitchen table with paper flowers I’d crafted from my art stash alongside a handwritten card from Luthien and me; at her tea break Dad and I stood outside the staff room with cupcakes I’d baked (her favourite—little lemon ones) and called her to come out, watching Mum’s tired eyes light up as she blew out candles, then we stole a quick family picnic in the hospital garden before she returned to work, and on bigger milestones we plan weekend excursions—picnic at Kew, tea with Audrey, or sunrise walk at Richmond Park—so she feels the pause she deserves even on her busiest days.
questions.answer_ch: 尽管妈妈经常在医院加班，但我从不让她的生日静静过去：一大早我给她做了全麦吐司，配上Bonne Maman果酱，并用我用艺术材料制作的纸花给我们的小餐桌包了个惊喜，再加上我和露西恩手写的贺卡；在她的茶歇期间，爸爸和我带着我烤的小柠檬杯子蛋糕（她最喜欢的）站在员工休息室外呼唤她出来，看到妈妈疲惫的眼睛在吹灭蜡烛时闪烁着光芒，然后我们在医院花园里迅速享用了一次家庭野餐，在她返回工作前，我们还会在更大的里程碑时计划周末外出——在基尤野餐，和奥黛丽喝茶，或是在里士满公园看日出——让她在最忙碌的日子里也能感受到应有的暂停。

questions.question_en: What has your mother taught you about kindness through her work as a doctor, and how do you show kindness to others?
questions.question_ch: 你母亲通过作为医生的工作教会了你关于善良的什么，以及你如何向他人表现善良？
questions.answer_en: Mother taught me that kindness means treating each patient not just as a body with a sickness but as a person with feelings. Once I watched her gently hold an elderly man’s hand, explain his diagnosis step by step, and listen to his worries even when she had a hundred more patients waiting. She told me that a warm smile and thoughtful words can soothe fears better than medicine alone. From her example I learned that kindness comes from noticing a small face shut in fear or a friend sitting silently in a corner. I show kindness by helping classmates who struggle with a puzzle, offering my sandwich to someone who forgot theirs, standing up for anyone being teased, drawing cheerful pictures to leave in the school corridor for others to find, taking extra care of my injured gecko so it feels safe, and always asking how my neighbors and friends are before rushing off to play. In all these ways I try to follow my mother’s lessons and treat others as she treats her patients—with patience, respect, and a ready ear.
questions.answer_ch: 母亲教我善良意味着把每个病人视为一个有感情的人，而不仅仅是一个生病的身体。有一次，我看到她温柔地握着一位老人的手，逐步解释他的诊断，并倾听他的担忧，即使她还有一百多个病人在等候。她告诉我，一个温暖的微笑和体贴的话语能比单靠药物更好地安抚恐惧。通过她的榜样，我明白善良来自于注意到一个因恐惧而缩小的脸，或者在角落里默默坐着的朋友。我通过帮助在难题上挣扎的同学、把我的三明治分享给忘记带午餐的人、为被嘲笑的任何人辩护、画一些欢快的图片留在学校走廊供他人发现、特别照顾我受伤的壁虎让它感到安全，以及总是在匆忙去玩之前询问邻居和朋友的情况，来表现我的善良。在所有这些方式中，我努力遵循母亲的教导，以耐心、尊重和倾听之心对待他人，就像她对待她的病人一样。

questions.question_en: How do you comfort your mother when she’s had a challenging day at the hospital, and what does she say to make you feel better?
questions.question_ch: 你怎么安慰你的妈妈，当她在医院经历了艰难的一天时，她说了什么让你感觉好一些？
questions.answer_en: I waited by the door every evening with a steaming mug of chamomile tea in my hand. The moment she stepped inside, I slipped off her shoes, guided her to the sofa and gently rubbed her shoulders while she sank into the cushions. I brought her whole-wheat toast with marmalade and sat beside her, asking softly about the hardest parts of her day. As she talked about frightened patients and long hours, I kept my voice calm, telling her how proud I was of her courage. When she finished, she reached out, stroked my hair and said, “Isaac, your warm tea and your listening ears are the best medicine I could ever need,” and she pressed a tired kiss on my forehead. In that moment her smile told me she felt lighter, and I felt braver too.
questions.answer_ch: 我每晚都在门口等着，手里捧着一杯热腾腾的洋甘菊茶。她一走进来，我就帮她脱掉鞋子，引导她坐到沙发上，轻轻按摩她的肩膀，让她沉浸在柔软的靠垫中。我给她端来全麦吐司和果酱，坐在她身边，柔声询问她一天中最艰难的部分。当她谈起害怕的患者和漫长的工作时间时，我保持着平静的语气，告诉她我有多为她的勇气感到骄傲。等她说完，她伸出手来轻抚我的头发，说：“艾萨克，你的温暖茶水和倾听的耳朵是我所需要的最好药方。”随后，她在我额头上轻轻吻了一下。在那一刻，她的微笑告诉我她感到轻松，我也感到更勇敢。

questions.question_en: When your mother shares medical knowledge—like why it’s important to wash hands—what experiments or demonstrations do you do together?
questions.question_ch: 当你的母亲分享医学知识时，比如为什么洗手很重要，你们一起做了哪些实验或演示？
questions.answer_en: Whenever Mum wants to show me why handwashing matters, we turn our kitchen into a mini‐lab: first she rubs some glitter or pepper into my palms and I try to wash it off with just water—of course the “germs” stick stubbornly—then I add soap and suddenly everything washes away. Next we use a special glow‐in‐the‐dark lotion and a UV torch so I can see how “invisible” germs hide between my fingers and under my nails; even after a quick rinse the UV light shows patches still glowing until I learn to scrub properly. Sometimes we press our fingertips onto agar plates, then repeat after soap and let the dishes sit on the windowsill for a few days—on the unwashed plate tiny colonies grow like a bad science fiction movie, while the washed one stays almost spotless. Once Mum even let me look down her microscope at samples from our taps before and after cleaning with antiseptic—countless little dots vanished after we treated the metal handle. All these hands-on demos help me really understand what those tiny microbes are up to and why soap is our best defense.
questions.answer_ch: 每当妈妈想向我展示洗手的重要性时，我们就把厨房变成一个迷你实验室：她先在我的手掌上涂上一些闪粉或胡椒粉，然后我用水尝试洗掉——当然，“细菌”顽固地粘着——接着我加上肥皂，突然一切都洗掉了。接下来，我们使用一种特殊的夜光乳液和紫外线手电筒，这样我就能看到那些“看不见”的细菌藏在我的手指之间和指甲下；甚至在快速冲洗后，紫外光仍然显示出一些发光的斑块，直到我学会正确擦洗。有时我们会将指尖按在琼脂培养基上，然后在使用肥皂后重复这个过程，让盘子在窗台上静置几天——未洗的盘子上会像糟糕的科幻电影一样长出微小的菌落，而洗过的几乎一尘不染。一次，妈妈甚至让我通过显微镜观察我们水龙头上清洁前后样本的区别——在我们用消毒剂处理金属把手后，无数的小点消失了。所有这些亲身体验的演示都帮助我真正理解那些微小微生物的动向，以及为什么肥皂是我们最好的防线。

questions.question_en: What is a time you helped your mother with a work-related project or household task, and how did it change your perception of her job?
questions.question_ch: 你帮妈妈完成过什么工作相关的项目或家务任务吗？这如何改变了你对她工作的看法？
questions.answer_en: One Saturday afternoon I went with my mother to her community clinic after school to help her prepare for the next day’s patient schedule. She showed me how to sort the appointment cards, check that each file had the correct blood‐pressure readings and blood tests attached, and sterilize the small ear examination instruments before she wound their cords neatly and placed them in the tray. At first I thought a doctor’s work was only about prescribing medicine or giving injections, but standing beside her as she methodically ticked off names and gently folded each file made me realise how much careful planning and quiet care goes into every consultation. Watching her balance so many tasks—reassuring a worried grandmother, explaining inhaler techniques to a young asthmatic, and still smiling while she washed her hands for the next patient—taught me that being a doctor is as much about attention to detail and steady kindness as it is about knowing science. From then on I felt proud not only of her knowledge but of her patience and of the trust her patients place in her every day.
questions.answer_ch: 一个星期六的下午，我放学后跟着妈妈去她的社区诊所，帮助她为第二天的病人安排做好准备。她教我如何整理约诊卡，检查每个病历是否有正确的血压读数和血液检测报告，并在将小耳朵检查器具的线缠好并放入托盘之前对它们进行消毒。起初我以为医生的工作只是开药或打针，但当我站在她身旁，看到她有条不紊地勾选名字，温柔地折叠每个病历时，我才意识到每次咨询都需要如此细致的计划和细心的关怀。看着她在很多任务中游刃有余——安慰一位担心的祖母，向一位年轻的哮喘患者解释吸入器的使用技巧，洗手时还对下一个病人微笑——让我明白，成为一名医生不仅关乎科学知识，更关乎对细节的关注和稳定的善良。从那时起，我不仅为她的知识感到自豪，也为她的耐心以及患者每天对她的信任感到自豪。

questions.question_en: How do you and your mother plan special mother–child activities, and what do you look forward to doing with her most?
questions.question_ch: 你和你母亲是如何计划特别的母子活动的，你最期待和她一起做什么？
questions.answer_en: My mother and I usually set aside her next day off in my little wall-calendar, then sit at the kitchen table after dinner to brainstorm what we’d like to do — I’ll suggest things like baking scones with Devonshire cream, cooking a new recipe from our “World in My Kitchen” book or packing art supplies for a picnic sketching session in Kew Gardens, and she’ll check her rota, we’ll swap ideas and then write down what we need: ingredients, sketch pads, binoculars or museum tickets. We make a shopping list together and I love helping her gather everything the next morning before school — there’s something magical in seeing a row of jam jars and flour lined up on the counter, knowing we’re about to make something new. What I look forward to most is cooking side by side with her in our tiny kitchen: measuring, tasting, laughing over my lopsided scones or runny marmalade tarts, and then sitting down together to enjoy the result — it feels like our very own alchemy, and I treasure her proud smile more than anything.
questions.answer_ch: 我和妈妈通常会在我的小挂历上标记好她下一个休息日，然后在晚餐后坐在厨房的桌子旁一起头脑风暴，想想我们想做些什么——我会建议像用德文郡奶油烘焙松饼、从我们的《世界在我厨房》中尝试新食谱，或者准备艺术用品去凯尤花园进行野餐素描等等，她会查看她的工作安排，我们交换想法，然后写下我们需要的东西：食材、素描本、望远镜或博物馆门票。我们会一起列购物清单，我非常喜欢在上学前的早晨帮助她收集一切——看到一排果酱瓶和面粉整齐地排列在柜台上，知道我们即将创造些什么，感觉很神奇。我最期待的就是和她一起在我们的小厨房里并肩做菜：测量、品尝、为我那歪歪扭扭的松饼或流淌的橘子酱挞大笑，然后一起坐下来享受结果——这就像是我们自己的炼金术，而我比任何事情都珍惜她自豪的微笑。

questions.question_en: What stories has George Patrick Newton shared about his role as a government official, and what did you learn from them?
questions.question_ch: 乔治·帕特里克·牛顿分享了哪些关于他作为政府官员的故事，您从中学到了什么？
questions.answer_en: My grandpa once told me about a time early in his career when he was sent to mediate a dispute between two neighbouring counties over water rights––farmers in one wanted to build a new irrigation channel and downstream villages feared it would leave their wells dry. He spent a week living in a tiny guesthouse, rising at dawn to speak with elderly villagers, then in the afternoon drafting compromise proposals, and by evening negotiating with county officials in candlelit rooms. He described how he learned to listen more than he spoke, to weigh everyone’s needs equally and never pretend to know an answer when he didn’t. In another story he recounted helping to organise a citywide health outreach program: instead of issuing orders from his office, he would ride the bus to clinics, hand out flyers himself and ask nurses how best to reach families who’d never visited a doctor. From him I learned that true public service means humility, patience and a willingness to walk in people’s shoes rather than simply draft policies on paper. His tales taught me that doing my part for others, however small, is both a responsibility and an honor.
questions.answer_ch: 我爷爷曾经告诉我，他职业生涯早期有一次被派去调解两个邻近县之间关于水权的争端——一个县的农民想要修建新的灌溉渠道，而下游的村庄担心这会导致他们的井水枯竭。他在一个小客栈里住了一个星期，黎明时分起床与老年村民交谈，下午起草妥协提案，晚上则在烛光下与县官员谈判。他描述了他是如何学会倾听多于发言，平等地考虑每个人的需求，绝不在不确定的情况下假装知道答案。在另一个故事中，他讲述了帮助组织一个全市的健康宣传项目：他不是在办公室下达命令，而是乘公交车去诊所，亲自发放传单，并询问护士如何更好地接触从未看过医生的家庭。从他身上我明白，真正的公共服务意味着谦逊、耐心，以及愿意站在他人的角度思考，而不仅仅是在纸上拟定政策。他的故事教会了我，尽管我的付出很小，但为他人尽一份力既是一种责任，也是一种荣誉。

questions.question_en: How did your grandfather’s upbringing in 1955 differ from your childhood, and what lessons did he pass on to you?
questions.question_ch: 你祖父在1955年的成长与您的童年有什么不同，他传授给你什么教训？
questions.answer_en: My grandfather George Patrick Newton grew up in 1955 in a working-class Irish home where the only book on the shelf was the Bible, summers meant helping in fields rather than visiting museums, and opportunities to travel or study beyond the village were almost unheard of—by contrast, I’ve grown up surrounded by shelves of encyclopedias and storybooks, weekend trips to Kew Gardens and Natural History museums, language lessons in Chinese, French and more, and family holidays in Japan and the USA. From him I learned that knowledge isn’t confined to pages or screens but is also forged through hands-on work and curiosity about the world around you, that real responsibility means caring for your tools, your home and each person you meet, and that a steady routine—showers after a hard day, keeping your space tidy, honouring commitments—builds the self-discipline you need to explore life’s greatest mysteries.
questions.answer_ch: 我的祖父乔治·帕特里克·纽顿于1955年在一个工薪阶层的爱尔兰家庭长大，家里唯一的书是《圣经》，夏天的时间是在田间帮助劳动，而不是去参观博物馆，出村旅行或学习的机会几乎不曾听说过——相对而言，我是在满是百科全书和故事书的书架中长大的，周末去基尤花园和自然历史博物馆，学习中文、法语等语言，以及全家去日本和美国的假期。从他身上我学到，知识不仅限于书页或屏幕，而是通过动手工作的实践和对周围世界的好奇心来形成的，真正的责任意味着关心你的工具、你的家和你所遇见的每一个人，以及稳定的日常规矩——在辛苦的一天后洗澡，保持空间整洁，遵守承诺——建立你探索生活最大奥秘所需的自律。

questions.question_en: What qualities of leadership or responsibility do you admire most in your paternal grandfather?
questions.question_ch: 你最欣赏你祖父身上的哪些领导或责任品质？
questions.answer_en: What I admire most in Grandpa George is his unwavering sense of duty—both in his work as a government official and at home. He rose early each morning, impeccably dressed and ready to serve the public, yet he never let that commitment crowd out family time: he’d host our monthly Sunday Roasts, listen patiently to our questions about the world, and quietly teach us by example what public service truly means. He leads by calm example—meticulous in planning, generous with his time and knowledge, humble about his own achievements—and he always finds a way to make each of us feel seen, whether by sharing stories from his career or helping us tend the garden he loves. His steadiness under pressure, his readiness to put others first, and his genuine encouragement of our passions are the qualities of leadership and responsibility I most aspire to emulate.
questions.answer_ch: 我最钦佩乔治爷爷的是他坚定不移的责任感——无论是在他作为政府官员的工作中，还是在家里。他每天清晨早起，衣着得体，准备好为公众服务，但他从不让这种承诺挤占家庭时间：他会主持我们的每月周日烤肉，耐心倾听我们对世界的提问，并通过自身的榜样悄然教会我们什么是真正的公共服务。他以冷静的榜样引领他人——在计划上 meticulous，慷慨地分享自己的时间和知识，对自己的成就谦虚——并且总能找到方法让我们每一个人都感到被关注，无论是分享他职业生涯的故事，还是帮助我们照料他所热爱的花园。他在压力下的稳重、愿意把他人放在首位以及对我们热情的真诚鼓励，都是我最渴望效仿的领导和责任品质。

questions.question_en: What traditions does Grace Newton maintain from her family, and how do you help her with household tasks?
questions.question_ch: 格蕾丝·牛顿保留了哪些家庭传统？你如何帮助她完成家务？
questions.answer_en: Grace Newton still keeps her family’s old Sunday-Roast tradition alive, laying out her mother Orla’s hand-woven lace and inviting everyone for roast beef, Yorkshire puds and boiled carrots on the last Sunday of every month just as her parents did in Ireland; she also takes the whole family back to her childhood village each summer, wandering the same hedgerows while telling us Celtic myths Orla taught her. I help Grandma Grace by setting the table—carefully placing the lace doily, polishing the silver cutlery and arranging the roast potatoes just right—then clearing the plates afterwards, scrubbing pans and peeling carrots, and in the garden I water her flower beds each evening, carrying on the ritual she learned as a little girl.
questions.answer_ch: 格蕾丝·牛顿依然保留着家族的传统，每月最后一个星期天像她父母在爱尔兰时那样摆上她母亲奥拉亲手编织的蕾丝桌布，招待大家享用烤牛肉、约克郡布丁和水煮胡萝卜。她还每年夏天带全家回到她的童年小村庄，漫步在同样的树篱边，给我们讲奥拉教她的凯尔特神话。我帮奶奶格蕾丝摆餐具——小心地铺好蕾丝垫、擦亮银质餐具、把烤土豆摆得恰到好处——饭后收拾碗盘、刷锅、削胡萝卜；每天晚上在花园里给她的花床浇水，延续她小时候学会的仪式感。

questions.question_en: How does your grandmother’s experience as a housewife influence the way she supports your family’s daily routine?
questions.question_ch: 你祖母作为家庭主妇的经历如何影响她支持你们家庭日常生活的方式？
questions.answer_en: My grandmother Mary spent decades at home raising her daughters, tending the garden and cooking meals for her family, so she never saw those tasks as “chores” but as ways to show love. Because of her example my mum grew up learning to juggle school runs, Sunday roasts and gardening projects, and now our household follows a similar rhythm: every weekend we help set the table or pick herbs in the back yard, we bake bread or prepare marmalade together in the mornings, and there’s always a pot of tea at hand. Grandad still teases me that granny’s “secret ingredient” is care, but it’s true – the little routines she taught my mum (hand-washing before meals, tidying toys before bedtime, checking who needs clean socks or a hot drink) have woven themselves into our lives. Her calm, practical affection reminds us every day that caring for one another is the heart of our family’s routine.
questions.answer_ch: 我的祖母玛丽在家度过了几十年，抚养她的女儿们，打理花园，为家人做饭，因此她从不把这些事情当作“家务”，而是视为表达爱的方式。正因为她的榜样，我妈妈在成长过程中学会了兼顾接送孩子、周日烤肉和园艺项目，现在我们的家也遵循类似的节奏：每个周末我们帮忙摆放餐具或在后院采摘香草，早上一起烤面包或做果酱，并且总有一壶茶随时待命。祖父仍然笑称奶奶的“秘密配料”是关心，但这是真的——她教给我妈妈的小习惯（吃饭前洗手、睡前收拾玩具、查看谁需要干净的袜子或一杯热饮）已融入我们的生活。她那种平和而务实的关爱每天都在提醒我们，彼此照顾才是我们家庭日常的核心。

questions.question_en: What have you learned from your grandmother’s stories about life growing up in 1960?
questions.question_ch: 你从祖母讲述的1960年成长生活的故事中学到了什么？
questions.answer_en: From Grandma’s stories I’ve learned that growing up in the 1960s was a far quieter, simpler life driven by community and family: children had only a few treasured toys, spent endless hours exploring outdoors or helping with chores, and ate home-cooked meals every night; there were no screens, so the radio, books and storytelling around the fire were everyone’s entertainment; holidays meant long walks in the countryside, relatives gathering for roast dinners and baking together, while schooldays were full of learning by doing, from writing letters on paper to drawing maps by hand; people measured time by seasons, church bells or the coming of spring rather than by digital clocks; and despite modest means, Grandma’s perseverance to read by lamplight and learn new things taught me that resilience, kindness and curiosity are the treasures that endure across generations.
questions.answer_ch: 从奶奶的故事里我了解到，在1960年代长大的生活要安静得多、简单得多，以社区和家庭为驱动：孩子们只有几件珍贵的玩具，花无数小时在户外探险或帮忙做家务，每晚都吃家常饭；没有屏幕，所以收音机、书籍和火堆旁的讲故事成了大家的娱乐；假期则意味着在乡间漫长的散步，亲戚们聚在一起吃烤肉晚餐并一起烘焙，而上学的日子里则通过实践学习——写手写信、手绘地图；人们用季节、教堂钟声或春天的到来而不是数字时钟来计时；尽管生活清贫，奶奶在灯下坚持阅读、不断学习的新事物教会我：坚韧、善良和好奇心才是跨越世代的宝藏。

questions.question_en: What lessons has William Lucas Smith taught you about problem-solving from his work as an automotive technical consultant?
questions.question_ch: 威廉·卢卡斯·史密斯在担任汽车技术顾问期间，在解决问题方面教会了你哪些经验？
questions.answer_en: I learned from Grandpa William that solving a tricky problem is a lot like fixing a car engine: first you study every part carefully, then you test each piece one at a time until you find what’s wrong. He showed me how he’d break down a complex fault into smaller questions (“Is the wiring loose? Is the coolant flowing?”) and never give up until he had an answer. He taught me to keep a notepad by my side so I could write down each test result and my next idea—that way nothing got lost in my head. He also told me mistakes were just clues, not failures: if a solution didn’t work, that meant I was one step closer to the right fix. Best of all he always reminded me to stay calm when things got confusing, because a calm mind sees patterns faster than a panicking one. Those lessons have helped me tackle school puzzles and build my own little experiments with the same steady, step-by-step approach.
questions.answer_ch: 我从威廉爷爷那里学到，解决棘手问题就像修理汽车发动机：首先仔细研究每个部件，然后逐一测试，直到找出故障所在。他教我如何将复杂的故障拆解成更小的问题（“线路是否松动？冷却液是否流通？”），并且永不放弃，直到找到答案。他让我随身带着笔记本，以便记录每次测试结果和下一个想法——这样脑子里就不会漏掉任何细节。他还告诉我，错误只是线索，而不是失败：如果一个解决方案没奏效，那就意味着我离正确修复又近了一步。最重要的是，他总会提醒我在困惑时保持冷静，因为冷静的头脑比惊慌的头脑更快看到规律。这些经验帮助我用同样稳步、循序渐进的方法解决学校难题，并自己动手做小实验。

questions.question_en: How does your maternal grandfather’s experience working with cars inspire you to tinker or experiment with science projects?
questions.question_ch: 你外祖父在汽车方面的工作经历如何激励你自己动手摆弄或尝试科学项目？
questions.answer_en: My grandpa Lucas spent his whole career solving car‐factory puzzles–figuring out why engines ran rough or assembly lines stalled–and I’ve inherited his love for hands-on problem-solving. Watching him calmly crack open a gearbox or trace electrical faults with his wrench and multimeter taught me that science isn’t just in textbooks but in real machines. When I mix soap with coffee grounds or build model aircraft carriers in Uncle Owen’s studio, I channel my grandpa’s persistence and precision. He showed me how to measure twice, bend metal parts to fit, and keep tweaking until everything runs smoothly. His stories of redesigning production tools and prototyping new parts remind me that every experiment is an opportunity to invent better solutions. So whether I’m balancing chemistry equations or aligning birdwatching binoculars, I always think, “What would Grandpa Lucas do?” and then I dive in, confident that with enough curiosity and elbow grease, I can engineer my own breakthroughs.
questions.answer_ch: 我的外公卢卡斯一生都在解决汽车厂的难题——弄明白发动机为什么运转不顺或装配线为什么停滞——我也继承了他对动手解决问题的热爱。看着他平静地撬开变速箱或用扳手和万用表查找电路故障，让我明白科学不仅存在于课本里，更存在于真实的机械中。每当我把肥皂和咖啡渣混在一起，或在欧文叔叔的工作室里打造模型航母，我都在延续外公的坚持和精确。他教会我要“量两次”，将金属部件弯成合适的形状，并不断调整，直到一切顺畅运转。他那些重新设计生产工具、试制新零件的故事提醒我，每一次实验都是发明更好解决方案的机会。所以无论我是平衡化学方程式，还是校准观鸟望远镜，我总会想：“如果外公卢卡斯在，他会怎么做？”然后我就会全力以赴，相信只要有足够的好奇心和双手，就能实现自己的工程突破。

questions.question_en: What family stories did your grandfather share about his childhood in 1960 that made you curious about the past?
questions.question_ch: 你的祖父分享了哪些关于他1960年童年的家庭故事，让你对过去产生了好奇？
questions.answer_en: My grandpa once told me how, back in 1960, his own mother Isabella fell so ill after his birth that she never had a chance to have another child—he grew up as an only boy, always longing for a sister. He described her beauty—“she was so elegant everyone stopped to stare”—and how his father, a government official, doted on him, even inventing a little “G-name game” so that all their names began with the same letter. Grandpa said he spent childhood summers listening to his grandmother Grace’s stories of Irish legends, but he never got to play with a sister the way he’d imagine. Hearing about his lonely, sister-less childhood and the way his parents tried to fill that gap sparked my curiosity: I’ve since wanted to learn more about life in those windswept Irish villages and the traditions that shaped my grandfather’s world.
questions.answer_ch: 我祖父曾告诉我，1960年，他的母亲伊莎贝拉在生下他之后病得很重，从此再也没有机会生第二个孩子——他作为家中唯一的男孩长大，一直渴望有一个姐姐。他形容母亲的美丽：“她优雅得让所有人驻足观望”——而他的父亲是一名政府官员，非常宠爱他，甚至发明了一个小小的“G字游戏”，让他们全家名字都以同一个字母开头。祖父说，他的童年夏天总是在听奶奶格蕾丝讲述爱尔兰的传说中度过，但他从未能像想象中那样与姐姐一起玩耍。听到他那孤独、无姐的童年，以及父母如何努力弥补这一空缺，引发了我的好奇心：从那时起，我就想更多地了解那些被风吹拂的爱尔兰村庄里的生活，以及塑造祖父世界的传统。

questions.question_en: How does Mary Smith’s role as an office clerk influence the way you organize your own tasks and routines?
questions.question_ch: 玛丽·史密斯作为办公室职员的角色如何影响你组织自己的任务和日常安排？
questions.answer_en: I’ve noticed Grandma Mary always arrives at her office on time, checks off every task on her to-do list and uses her lunch break to walk in Kew Gardens before returning to her desk. Watching her juggle patient files, phone calls and garden club meetings taught me to break my day into clear chunks: homework first, then bug surveys, then art projects. I now keep a small planner where I write down three “must-do” items each morning, just as she does, and I review it during meal breaks so nothing slips through the cracks. When she switched from full-time to part-time work, she still managed to care for Aunt Audrey’s five cats, tend her roses and bake scones for Sunday Roast—so I’ve learned to batch-cook my breakfast sandwiches on Sundays, pack my binoculars and bird-spotting snacks together and lay out my art supplies and sketchbook before bedtime. Her steady routine, her habit of tidying her desk at five o’clock sharp and her devotion to both work and family inspire me to organize my own tasks in a way that keeps weekday chaos to a minimum and frees my mind for the discoveries I love most.
questions.answer_ch:
我注意到玛丽奶奶总是准时到办公室，完成待办事项清单上的每一项，并利用午休时间在邱园散步，然后才回到办公桌前。看着她一边处理病人档案、一边接电话、参加园艺俱乐部的会议，教会了我把一天分成清晰的阶段：先做作业，然后做虫类调查，再做艺术项目。现在我每天早上像她一样在小日程本上写下三件“必须做”的事情，并在用餐时查看，确保没有遗漏。

当她从全职转为兼职工作后，仍能照顾奥黛丽阿姨的五只猫、打理她的玫瑰，还为周日烤肉准备司康饼——所以我学会了周日一起批量制作早餐三明治，打包望远镜和观鸟小食，并在睡前把美术用品和速写本都摆放好。她稳定的日常作息、每天五点准时整理办公桌的习惯，以及对工作和家庭的投入，激励我用同样的方法安排自己的事务，把平日的混乱降到最低，让我的大脑有更多空间去探索和发现。

questions.question_en: What advice has your grandmother given about balancing work and family life, and how do you apply it to your chores?
questions.question_ch: 你祖母关于平衡工作与家庭生活给了你什么建议？你如何将这些建议应用到你的家务中？
questions.answer_en: Grandma Mary always told me that work and family are like two hands—you need both to hold life steady. When Mom was a doctor she’d rush home, change out of her coat, kiss us and then head back to her paperwork. Grandma said she not only needed to care for her patients but also to care for herself and her family. She’d slip away after dinner to tend her little garden for just ten minutes—enough time to clear her mind before bedtime—and she urged Mom and Dad to share the household jobs so neither felt buried. I remember her saying, “A life without time to breathe is like a garden without water.” To apply that to my chores, I always start by setting a small timer: first I make my own breakfast—toast and marmalade—then I tidy my room, fold my laundry, and pack my school bag. When the timer dings, I stop what I’m doing, take a five-minute break to draw in my notebook or step outside to look at the oak tree in our yard. That little break keeps me from feeling overwhelmed—just as Grandma’s garden breaks kept her going—so chores get done and there’s still time for family stories and adventure.
questions.answer_ch: 玛丽奶奶常说，工作和家庭就像双手——两只手都要有，生活才能稳稳当当。妈妈做医生的时候，总是急匆匆赶回家，脱下白大褂，吻我们一下，然后又回去做文件。奶奶说，她不仅要照顾病人，也要照顾自己和家人。晚饭后她会溜出去照料小花园，哪怕只有十分钟——足够在睡前让她清空思绪——她还劝爸爸妈妈分担家务，这样谁都不会被压得喘不过气。我记得她常说：“没有喘息时间的生活，就像没有水的花园。”为了把这句话运用到我的家务上，我总是先设一个小闹钟：先自己做早餐——烤面包抹橘子酱——然后收拾房间，叠好衣服，收拾书包。闹钟一响，我就停下手里的事，休息五分钟，或者在笔记本上涂涂画画，或者走到院子里看看那棵橡树。正是这短暂的休息让我不至于觉得压力过大——就像奶奶的花园小憩支撑着她一样——既能把家务做完，也还有时间听家人讲故事、去探险。

questions.question_en: What cultural or family traditions does Mary Smith preserve from her childhood in 1960, and how do you participate?
questions.question_ch: Mary Smith 从1960年童年时期保留了哪些文化或家庭传统？你是如何参与其中的？
questions.answer_en: When I asked Grandma Mary about her childhood she told me how, back in her small Irish village, every summer her mother Orla led her out into the fields to gather wildflowers and whisper old Celtic myths at dusk, and how on Sunday afternoons the whole family would convene for a hearty roast of lamb or beef, vegetables and potatoes roasted in the embers, followed by stories around the hearth. Now, in her own home, Mary still hosts those Sunday roasts for us—with the same recipes she learned as a girl—and she never lets the garden lie fallow, planting bulbs each spring just as Orla taught her. I help by setting the table with our best china and fetching Grandad’s special gravy boat, then during dinner I listen as she tells those same legends of fairies and heroes, and afterwards I carry armfuls of daisies to arrange in vases on the mantel. In this way I felt I was part of a chain stretching back to her childhood in 1960, tending our garden, sharing our meals and passing on our stories.
questions.answer_ch: 当我问玛丽奶奶她的童年时，她告诉我，在她那个爱尔兰小村庄里，每年夏天，她的母亲奥拉都会带她到田野里去采野花，黄昏时分轻声讲述古老的凯尔特神话；周日下午，全家会聚在一起，享用丰盛的烤羊肉或烤牛肉，还有在余烬中烤制的蔬菜和土豆，饭后围坐在炉边听故事。如今，在她自己的家里，玛丽仍然为我们主持那些周日烤肉聚会——用的还是她小时候学到的食谱——她也从不让花园休耕，每年春天都像奥拉教她的那样种植花球。我会帮忙摆上最好的瓷器，端来爷爷那只特制的肉汁船，晚餐时我倾听她讲那些关于仙子和英雄的传说，饭后我则抱着一把一把的雏菊，摆在壁炉架上的花瓶里。就这样，我觉得自己成了那条从她1960年童年延续至今的链条的一部分，一起打理花园，共享美食，传承我们的故事。

questions.question_en: How did Uncle Ian’s Finance/AI career spark your interest in technology or money management?
questions.question_ch: 伊恩叔叔的金融/人工智能事业是如何激发你对科技或理财的兴趣的？
questions.answer_en: Ever since Uncle Ian began talking about his work in finance and artificial intelligence—using computer programs to spot patterns in numbers and help people invest—I found myself curious about how technology could make sense of money. I remember sitting on his lap while he showed me charts on his laptop, explaining how an AI might learn when to buy or sell shares by spotting tiny trends. That inspired me to set up my own “lab” at home, where I used colored beads to represent different investments and experimented with simple rules—saving more of one color when it went up in value, taking some off the board when it went down. Watching Uncle Ian budget his own family’s expenses by running his code made me appreciate that managing money isn’t just about numbers in a piggy bank but about understanding patterns, planning ahead, and even using a bit of smart technology to make better choices.
questions.answer_ch: 自从伊恩叔叔开始谈他在金融和人工智能方面的工作——用计算机程序发现数字中的模式，帮助人们投资——我就对技术如何理解金钱产生了好奇。我还记得坐在他腿上，他在笔记本电脑上给我看图表，解释人工智能如何通过发现微小趋势来判断买入或卖出股票。这激励我在家里建立自己的“小实验室”，用彩色小珠子代表不同的投资，并尝试一些简单的规则——当某种颜色升值时就多存一点，贬值时就从“投资组合”中拿出一些。看着伊恩叔叔用他的代码为家人的开支做预算，让我明白管理金钱不仅仅是储蓄罐里的数字，更是要理解规律、未雨绸缪，甚至运用一些智能科技来做出更好的决策。

questions.question_en: What lessons did you learn from Uncle Ian about balancing work in finance with raising Alex and caring for Duke the Labrador?
questions.question_ch: 你从伊恩叔叔那里学到了哪些关于在金融工作与抚养亚历克斯并照顾拉布拉多犬杜克之间保持平衡的经验？
questions.answer_en: Uncle Ian showed me that even the busiest person can make family time a priority. He works long hours in finance yet never misses Alex’s football matches or his birthday celebrations with Duke, their Labrador. He carves out weekends for outings—sometimes a simple walk with Alex and Duke in the park—and treats those hours as sacred, not as an afterthought. He involves Alex in caring for Duke—teaching him to feed, walk and even groom the dog—so Alex feels responsible and they bond. He sets clear boundaries: work stays at the office, and home is for family. He also shares his own passions—like introducing Alex to financial concepts gently—so Alex learns alongside him rather than feeling ignored. From him I’ve learned that true balance isn’t about clocking equal hours for work and play but about giving your full attention to each when it counts, planning ahead to protect family moments, and sharing genuine interests so that work, play and care all become part of a shared life.
questions.answer_ch: 伊恩叔叔让我明白，即便是最忙碌的人也能将家庭时光放在首位。他在金融行业工作时间很长，却从不缺席亚历克斯的足球比赛，也从不缺席他和他们拉布拉多犬杜克的生日庆祝。他会在周末抽出时间外出——有时只是在公园里与亚历克斯和杜克散步——并把那些时光视若神圣，而不是事后才勉强挤出。他还让亚历克斯参与照顾杜克——教他喂狗、遛狗，甚至梳理狗毛——让亚历克斯感到自己有责任，并借此增进亲子感情。他设立了明确的界限：工作留在办公室，家里只属于家人。他还分享自己的兴趣爱好——比如以轻松方式向亚历克斯介绍金融概念——让亚历克斯能和他一起学习，而不会感觉被忽视。从他身上我学到，真正的平衡并不是在工作和娱乐上平均分配时间，而是在关键时刻全心投入，对家庭时光进行事先规划，并分享真实的兴趣，让工作、娱乐和关爱都成为共享生活的一部分。

questions.question_en: How has spending time with Uncle Ian and Angela influenced your understanding of team sports through her coaching?
questions.question_ch: 通过与Ian叔叔和Angela共度时光，通过Angela的指导，这如何影响了你对团队运动的理解？
questions.answer_en: Spending afternoons watching Aunt Angela coach her high-school soccer team taught me that team sports are about far more than individual talent. I saw how she built drills that emphasized communication and trust, celebrating every player’s small successes and gently correcting mistakes to help the whole group improve. Uncle Ian’s own passion for football—his quiet pride in a well-executed play and his good-natured teasing about my lack of athleticism—showed me that winning isn’t just skill but also shared strategy, mutual support and the courage to keep trying when you miss. Together they helped me understand that a team is like a living puzzle: each person has a unique piece, and only by fitting them all together through respect, honest feedback and teamwork can you unlock real success. This lesson now guides not only how I play sports but also how I collaborate with classmates and friends.
questions.answer_ch: 在下午陪着安吉拉阿姨观看她指导高中足球队的过程中，我明白了团队运动远不止个人天赋。我看到她设计的训练既强调沟通和信任，又庆祝每位队员的小成就，并在温和纠正错误的同时帮助整个团队进步。伊恩叔叔对足球的热爱——他对一次漂亮配合的默默自豪，以及他对我运动细胞欠缺的善意戏谑——让我明白，赢得比赛不仅靠技术，还需共同的策略、相互支持，以及在失误后继续尝试的勇气。他们一起教会我：团队就像一个活生生的拼图，每个人都是独特的一块，只有通过尊重、真诚反馈和协作把它们拼在一起，才能取得真正的成功。这一课不仅指引我如何参与体育运动，也指导我如何与同学和朋友合作。

questions.question_en: What discoveries or missions from Irene’s marine biology career have fascinated you most, and why?
questions.question_ch: 在艾琳的海洋生物学职业生涯中，哪些发现或任务最令你着迷，为什么？
questions.answer_en: I think the most amazing mission Aunt Irene ever told me about was her deep-sea expedition off the coast of Ireland where she and her team piloted a tiny submersible down nearly 1,000 meters into pitch-black water and discovered a brand-new species of bioluminescent jellyfish that glowed like a constellation of tiny stars. She showed me the grainy video of them pulsing with light and explained how their cells flicker in different colors to communicate and hunt. Hearing how she dove into those crushing depths—and then helped name the new species and launch conservation efforts—made me feel like she was exploring an alien world right here on Earth. It was so exciting I couldn’t stop imagining myself in that submersible, mapping undiscovered life in the deep ocean, just like astronauts mapping new planets.
questions.answer_ch: 我觉得艾琳姨妈曾经讲给我听的最惊人的任务，是她在爱尔兰海岸附近进行的深海探险。她和团队驾驶一艘小型潜艇，潜入近1000米的漆黑海水中，发现了一种全新的发光水母，宛如由无数微小星辰组成的星座。她给我看了那些闪烁着光芒的颗粒状视频，向我解释它们的细胞如何通过不同颜色的闪光来交流和捕猎。听她讲到自己潜入那种极度压迫的深渊，又如何帮助给新物种命名并发起了保护行动，让我感觉她就像在地球上探索另一个异星世界。这个故事太激动人心了，我忍不住想象自己也坐在那艘潜艇里，在深海中绘制未知生命的图谱，就像宇航员在新星球上探险一样。

questions.question_en: How do you and Aunt Irene bond over science—do you join her on beach cleanups or lab visits?
questions.question_ch: 你和艾琳阿姨是如何通过科学建立联系的——你会和她一起参加海滩清理活动，还是一起参观实验室？
questions.answer_en: I loved going with Aunt Irene on her beach surveys where we wore gumboots and carried buckets of mussels and wrack, picking up plastic bottles and fishing line before sorting the shells by size on the sand; she showed me how to test the water’s salinity with a refractometer she always carried in her backpack. Sometimes we slipped into her lab at the university, where I peered through her microscope at tiny plankton glowing under blue light, and helped her label Petri dishes for algae cultures she’d collected at low tide. At home she’d patiently answer my questions about sea turtles and coral bleaching as we watched BBC nature films together, and on rainy afternoons we’d experiment in the kitchen with seaweed agar and salt-water brine shrimp—every little task made me feel like a real marine scientist and deepened our bond.
questions.answer_ch: 我最喜欢跟艾琳姨一起去海滩做调查，穿着雨靴，提着装满贻贝和海藻的水桶，一边捡塑料瓶和渔线，一边在沙滩上按大小分类贝壳；她教我用背包里常带的折射仪测试海水的盐度。 有时候我们会溜进她在大学的实验室，我透过显微镜在蓝光下观察发光的微小浮游生物，还帮她给在退潮时采集的海藻培养皿贴标签。 在家里，我们一边看BBC的自然纪录片，她耐心回答我关于海龟和珊瑚白化的问题；下雨的下午，我们就在厨房里用海藻琼脂和盐水丰年虫做实验——每一件小事都让我觉得自己像个真正的海洋科学家，也让我们的关系更加深厚。

questions.question_en: What has Alek (Irene’s spouse Vivek Singh) taught you about the brain and neuroscience when you visit their lab?
questions.question_ch: 当你去他们的实验室参观时，Alek（Irene 的配偶 Vivek Singh）教会了你哪些有关大脑和神经科学的知识？
questions.answer_en: I visited Uncle Vivek’s lab at the hospital one Saturday morning and he showed me a big machine called an electroencephalogram, which looks like a computer with wires and sensors.
