He explained that the brain is made of billions of tiny cells called neurons that send electrical signals to each other like telephone wires. He pulled out a plastic model of the brain, pointed to the folded cortex and said those wrinkles let us pack more neurons inside. Then he described two parts he studies: the hippocampus, where memories are stored, and the prefrontal cortex, which helps with decision-making and planning. He set up a simple reaction-time test, pressing a button every time I heard a beep and timing how quickly I pressed mine back, telling me that the speed shows how fast our nerves carry messages. He talked about how learning makes the connections between neurons stronger and helps build myelin, the insulation around nerves, so practicing really does make your brain work faster. Before I left he drew a picture showing how parts of our brain light up when we feel happy or scared and said understanding this helps doctors treat people with anxiety or depression. It felt like visiting a magical place where you can peek inside your own head and see how thoughts and feelings travel.
questions.answer_ch: 我在一个星期六早晨参观了Vivek叔叔在医院的实验室，他给我看了一台叫做脑电图仪的大机器，看上去像一台带有电线和传感器的电脑。他解释说，大脑由数十亿个名为神经元的微小细胞组成，它们像电话线一样彼此发送电信号。接着他拿出一个塑料脑模型，指出那些折叠的皮层，告诉我那些皱褶让我们能在更小的空间容纳更多神经元。然后他介绍了他研究的两个部分：海马体，这是存储记忆的地方；以及前额叶皮层，它帮助我们做决策和规划。他给我做了一个简单的反应时测试——每次我听到哔声就按下按钮，并测量我按下按钮的速度，告诉我这个速度反映了神经传递信息的快慢。他还讲到，学习会让神经元之间的连接更强，并帮助形成髓鞘——神经的绝缘层，所以练习确实能让大脑工作得更快。离开前，他画了一幅图，展示我们在感到快乐或恐惧时，大脑的哪些部位会被激活，并说了解这些有助于医生治疗焦虑或抑郁患者。那感觉就像参观了一个神奇的地方，可以窥见自己脑海，看看思维和情感是如何流动的。

questions.question_en: How did Irvin’s work as an artist influence your own drawing or painting style, and what lessons did you pick up?
questions.question_ch: 欧文作为一名艺术家的创作如何影响了你自己的素描或油画风格？你从中学到了哪些经验？
questions.answer_en: Irvin’s art taught me that drawing and painting aren’t just about copying what you see but about using whatever materials or ideas spark your imagination — whether that’s paint, scrap wood, or even dried leaves. Watching him in his studio, I learned to treat every “mistake” as part of the picture, to splash colors without worrying about perfection, and to mix unexpected objects into my work. He showed me that art is a way to explore how I feel inside, so I’ve started using bits of thread and torn paper alongside my pencils to capture emotions rather than just outlines. From Irvin I picked up the lesson that creativity thrives when you give yourself total freedom, trust your instincts, and celebrate the uniqueness of each brushstroke or pencil mark.
questions.answer_ch: 欧文的艺术让我明白，绘画不仅仅是复制你所见，而是要利用任何能激发你想象力的材料或想法——无论是颜料、碎木头，甚至是干枯的树叶。在他的工作室里观察他，我学会了把每一个“错误”都视为画面的一部分，毫不在意完美地随意泼洒色彩，并将意想不到的物件融入我的作品。他向我展示了艺术是探索内心感受的一种方式，所以我开始在铅笔画的基础上加入一些线头和撕碎的纸片，以表现情感，而不仅仅是描绘轮廓。从欧文那里，我领悟到，当你给予自己完全的自由、信任直觉并赞美每一笔每一划的独特性时，创造力才能蓬勃发展。

questions.question_en: What stories has Irvin shared about collaborating with his partner Samira on illustration projects?
questions.question_ch: Irvin 分享了哪些关于与他的搭档 Samira 合作插画项目的故事？
questions.answer_en: Irvin loves to tell me how he and Samira turn her delicate illustrations into three-dimensional art. He once described a weekend they spent in the Cotswolds hunting for fallen leaves, feathers and bits of bark so she could draw field-guide plates from life while he carved wooden frames from the branches they found. He laughs about their arguments over colour—she prefers jewel-bright oils, he wants muted earth-tones—then how they always settle on a richer palette by combining both their ideas. When Samira mounted her first solo show at a local gallery, Irvin spent days in his studio making bespoke display panels, drilling in tiny LED lights she’d chosen to bring out the fine detail in her pattern work. He says their best collaborations come from that balance: her patient, precise linework with his rough-hewn, spontaneous sculpting, each pushing the other into new creative territory.
questions.answer_ch: 欧文喜欢告诉我，他和萨米拉如何将她精致的插画变成三维艺术。他曾描述过一个周末，他们在科茨沃尔德地区寻找落叶、羽毛和树皮碎片，让她能够写生并绘制野外观察图，而他则用找到的树枝雕刻木质画框。他常常笑谈他们在色彩上的争论——她偏爱宝石般鲜亮的油彩，他则青睐柔和的大地色——最后两人总能结合各自的想法，调出更丰富的配色。当萨米拉在当地画廊举办她的首次个人展览时，欧文在他的工作室忙碌了好几天，制作专门的展示板，并在她挑选的细小位置上安装了 LED 灯，以突出她图案作品的精细细节。他说，他们最好的合作正是源于这种平衡：她耐心、精确的线条与他粗犷、即兴的雕刻，彼此激发对方，探索新的创作领域。

questions.question_en: How do you and Uncle Irvin explore creativity together—have you ever joined him in a studio session?
questions.question_ch: 你和欧文叔叔是如何共同探索创造力的——你曾经和他一起在录音室参与过创作吗？
questions.answer_en: Uncle Irvin and I always dove into creativity side by side in his cluttered studio at the end of our street. He’d clear a corner for me—“your sandbox,” he called it—and I’d bring my own wild ideas: twisted wires, broken camera lenses or scraps of fabric. Once we spent an afternoon experimenting with coloured plaster and coffee grounds, flinging wet mixtures at a canvas until it leapt to life under our hands. Other days we’d sit quietly, watching him carve tiny wooden totems or weave lengths of rope into miniature jungles, and I’d join by adding specks of paint or threading beads between leaves. He never corrected my mistakes but encouraged me to push each piece past its comfort zone: more blur, heavier texture, sharper angles. Sometimes he’d pause, hand me a tool—an ancient drill or a battered saw—and let me shape the next stage of his sculpture. In those hours I learned that creativity isn’t about perfect technique but about daring to try, to fail, to discover something new. And yes, I’ve joined him many times—so often that the studio smells of our combined sweat and paint, and whenever I step inside I feel that same rush of possibility.
questions.answer_ch: 叔叔欧文和我总是并肩在我们街尽头他那杂乱的工作室里潜入创作。他会为我腾出一个角落——“你的沙盒”，他说——我就带来自己的狂野想法：扭曲的铁丝、破碎的相机镜头或布料碎片。有一次我们花了一个下午用彩色石膏和咖啡渣做实验，把湿漉漉的混合物抛向画布，直到它在我们手下迸发出生命。还有时候我们会静静坐着，看他雕刻微小的木质图腾或把绳子编成迷你丛林，我则在叶片之间点缀颜料或穿上珠子。他从不纠正我的错误，却鼓励我把每件作品推到舒适区之外：模糊更浓重、质感更厚重、角度更锐利。有时他会停下来，递给我一个工具——一把古老的钻机或一把破旧的锯子——让我为他的雕塑塑造下一阶段。那些时光里我学到，创造力并不在于完美的技艺，而在于勇于尝试、勇于失败、勇于发现新事物。是的，我已经和他一起创作过许多次——次数之多，工作室里都弥漫着我们共同挥洒的汗水和油漆味，每次踏入其中，我都会感到同样涌动的无限可能。

questions.question_en: What games or projects do you enjoy doing with Alex, and what have you taught him about storytelling or science?
questions.question_ch: 你喜欢和 Alex 一起玩哪些游戏或做哪些项目？你在故事讲述或科学方面教过他什么？
questions.answer_en: I like two main things with Alex: hunting for fossils on Hampstead Heath and building soap in Uncle Irvin’s studio. When we bird-camped and rock-scratched in Devon you and I dug up little ammonites, and I showed Alex how those spiral shells tell the story of creatures that lived millions of years ago—how sediment hardens, how Mary Anning searched the cliffs, and how to read rock layers like pages in a book. In Irvin’s studio we mixed lye and fat to make soap, and I explained the chemistry—the saponification reaction that turns oils into cleaning bars—and we wrote our “lab report” together in my notebook. For storytelling, we wrote a short puppet play about the journey of a raindrop from cloud to river, crafting a beginning where the drop is born, a middle with a thunderstorm, and an end that waters flowers, teaching Alex how stories need characters, conflict and resolution.
questions.answer_ch: 我喜欢和亚历克斯一起做两件主要的事：在汉普斯特德荒原寻找化石，以及在欧文叔叔的工作室里制作肥皂。我们在德文郡露营观鸟、刻石头时，你和我一起挖出了小菊石，我向亚历克斯展示那些螺旋形的贝壳如何讲述数百万年前生物的故事——沉积物如何硬化，玛丽·安宁如何在悬崖上寻找化石，以及如何像读书一样解读岩层。在欧文的工作室里，我们混合碱液和脂肪来制作肥皂，我解释了化学原理——皂化反应如何将油脂变成清洁皂——然后我们一起在我的笔记本里写下我们的“实验报告”。在讲故事方面，我们写了一个简短的木偶剧，讲述水滴从云层到河流的旅程，设计了一个开端：小水滴诞生；中间：遭遇雷暴；结尾：滋润花朵，同时教亚历克斯故事需要有人物、冲突和解决。

questions.question_en: How did Alex react when he first met Duke the Labrador, and how do you help him care for their pet together?
questions.question_ch: 亚历克斯第一次见到拉布拉多犬杜克时有什么反应？你如何帮助他一起照顾这只宠物？
questions.answer_en: Alex’s eyes went as wide as saucers the first time he met Duke—he practically bounced across the room declaring, “I’ve dreamed of a Labrador just like this!” and hugged Duke so tightly I thought he’d never let go. From that moment Alex poured all his boundless energy into doting on Duke, teaching him “sit” and “stay” (and, for a fool’s hope, trying to train him to talk) and nursing his every bark like it was the sweetest song. I pitch in by helping prepare Duke’s meals—measuring kibble, tossing in carrot bits—walking him around Hampstead Heath on sunny afternoons, brushing his soft ears until they gleam, and setting up little obstacle courses in the garden for Alex to guide Duke through. Working together to care for Duke—feeding, training, pampering—has become our favorite team project, and I love how proud Alex is each time Duke learns a new trick.
questions.answer_ch: 亚历克斯第一次见到杜克时，眼睛顿时瞪得跟茶碟一样大——他几乎在房间里蹦来蹦去，大声宣称：“我一直梦见要一只像这样的拉布拉多！”然后紧紧地抱住杜克，仿佛永远不肯放手。从那一刻起，亚历克斯就把他所有的无穷精力都投入到宠爱杜克上，教他“坐下”和“待着”（甚至抱着不切实际的希望，试着教他“说话”），把杜克每一次的吠叫都当作最动听的乐章来用心呵护。我也加入了这项工作，帮忙准备杜克的餐食——称量狗粮，拌入胡萝卜丁；在阳光明媚的下午带他在汉普斯特德荒原散步；一直刷到他那双柔软的耳朵发亮；还在花园里搭建小型障碍赛道，让亚历克斯带着杜克一起闯关。一起照顾杜克——喂食、训练、宠溺——已经成了我们最喜欢的团队项目，而每次杜克学会新把戏时，我都为亚历克斯的骄傲感到由衷高兴。

questions.question_en: What have you learned from Aunt Angela’s experience coaching high school football that applies to teamwork in your life?
questions.question_ch: 你从安吉拉阿姨执教高中橄榄球队的经历中学到了什么，这些经验如何适用于你生活中的团队合作？
questions.answer_en: I once watched Aunt Angela on the high school football field, how she never left a player standing alone when the ball came their way, always called out exactly where to run or who to pass to, and cheered the smallest success as loudly as a goal. From her I learned that good teamwork depends on clear directions, gentle encouragement and the belief that every person matters. Later, when Gerald and I made soap at Owen’s studio, I remembered how Aunt Angela patiently explained a new drill until everyone understood, so I started doing the same—pointing out which step to mix next, praising Gerald when he measured just right, and helping Chen Jia when the mold kept breaking. Just as Aunt Angela shows her players that victories are shared, I found that in art and science, we succeed together only when we listen, guide and cheer each other on.
questions.answer_ch: 我曾在高中足球场上看过Angela姑妈，她从不让任何球员在球滚过来的瞬间孤立无援，总是准确地喊出该往哪跑或传给谁，并以同进球般的热烈欢呼庆祝哪怕最微小的成功。我从她身上学到：良好的团队合作依赖明确的指示、温和的鼓励，以及相信每个人都很重要。后来，当我和Gerald在Owen的工作室里做肥皂时，我想起Angela姑妈如何耐心地讲解一个新动作，直到每个人都明白为止，于是我也开始这么做——指出下一步要混合的材料，Gerald称量得恰到好处时给予赞赏，当模具总是破裂时帮助陈佳。正如Angela姑妈向她的队员们展示胜利是共同的，我也发现：在艺术和科学中，只有当我们倾听、引导并彼此加油时，才能一起取得成功。

questions.question_en: How does Angela’s American background influence the way she and Uncle Ian celebrate holidays with the family?
questions.question_ch: Angela的美国背景如何影响她和伊恩叔叔与家人一起庆祝节日的方式？
questions.answer_en: Angela’s American roots mean our family festivities often have a transatlantic twist. Every autumn she insists on a proper Thanksgiving spread – roast turkey with all the trimmings, cranberry relish and pumpkin pie – which now sits happily alongside our traditional Sunday Roast. In October she drags us into carving jack-o’-lanterns and trick-or-treating in the neighborhood, a new thrill for everyone used to Bonfire Night fireworks. At Christmas she hangs stockings by the fireplace and teaches us to string popcorn garlands for the tree, and at Easter she fills wicker baskets with chocolate eggs and little toys rather than just hiding painted eggs. Uncle Ian, ever the enthusiast, embraces every bit of it: he now whips up sweet potato mash for Thanksgiving, helps me and Lucy in our Halloween costumes and even braves the late-night candy run. Thanks to Angela, our holidays are a blend of British and American traditions, full of turkey and toffee apples, trick-or-treat ghosts and carol singers, and the whole family loves the mix.
questions.answer_ch: 安吉拉的美国家庭背景让我们的家庭庆祝活动常带有跨大西洋的风味。每到秋天，她都坚持要一桌正宗的感恩节大餐——烤火鸡配各种配菜、蔓越莓酱和南瓜派——现在这顿饭已经愉快地和我们传统的周日烤肉并列成了家常。十月，她把我们拉去刻南瓜灯并在社区要糖，这对习惯了篝火之夜烟花的人来说是全新的刺激。圣诞节，她在壁炉旁挂上长筒袜，还教我们用爆米花串成花环装饰圣诞树；复活节时，她往柳条篮里装巧克力蛋和小玩具，而不仅仅是藏彩蛋。伊恩叔叔一向热情，完全投入：他现在会为感恩节做红薯泥，帮我和露西准备万圣节服装，甚至大胆地在深夜去买糖果。多亏了安吉拉，我们的节日融合了英美传统，充满了火鸡和焦糖苹果、要糖鬼怪和唱诗班，全家人都爱这种混搭。

questions.question_en: What interesting facts about the brain has Dr. Vivek Singh shared that made you curious to learn more?
questions.question_ch: 维维克·辛格博士分享了哪些关于大脑的有趣事实，让你产生了想进一步了解的好奇心？
questions.answer_en: Dr. Vivek once told me that our brain, though it’s only about 2% of our body weight, uses nearly 20% of all the oxygen and energy we breathe in each day—that blew my mind! He also explained that we have about 86 billion neurons sending signals along “wires” at speeds up to 400 kilometers per hour, and that these neurons can actually grow new connections throughout our lives (he called it “plasticity”), which means our brains can learn, heal, and change more than I ever imagined. He mentioned the “brain–gut axis,” too, that our stomach and brain talk all the time, affecting how we feel and even our mood. Hearing that memories are stored by tiny physical changes in synapses made me curious to read about how those changes happen, and I can’t stop wondering what other secrets our brains hold—like how sleep makes new ideas stick, or why a smell can instantly remind us of something from years ago.
questions.answer_ch: Dr. Vivek曾经告诉我，虽然大脑仅占身体重量的约2%，但每天呼入的氧气和能量中近20%都被大脑消耗——这让我大开眼界！他还解释说，我们大约有860亿个神经元，这些神经元通过“电线”以每小时高达400公里的速度发送信号，而且这些神经元实际上可以在我们一生中不断生长新的连接（他称之为“可塑性”），这意味着我们的大脑能够学习、修复和变化，比我想象的还要多。他还提到了“大脑-肠道轴”，即我们的胃和大脑一直在对话，影响我们的感受甚至情绪。听说记忆是通过突触中微小的物理变化来储存的，这让我很好奇这些变化是如何发生的，我忍不住想知道大脑还隐藏着哪些秘密——比如为什么睡眠能让新想法更牢固，或为什么某种气味能瞬间让我想起多年前的某件事。

questions.question_en: How do you and Vivek work together on science experiments—has he ever helped you design one at home?
questions.question_ch: 你和Vivek是如何一起合作做科学实验的——他有没有在家帮你设计过实验？
questions.answer_en: Yes — Uncle Vivek and I have sketched out a few simple experiments at home. Last month he helped me design a reaction-time test using a ruler drop and a stopwatch: he showed me how to write a clear hypothesis (“taller people catch the ruler faster”), choose independent (drop height) and dependent (catch distance) variables, control light and noise, and repeat each trial ten times to get an accurate average. He taught me how to record data in a neat table and plot it on graph paper to see trends. He even suggested adding a second condition—dropping the ruler over different coloured backgrounds—to test whether colour affects reaction speed. He explained why we need “controls” (keeping the room temperature and time of day the same) to avoid hidden factors, and encouraged me to report my conclusions clearly, just like he does in his neurobiology lab. Having his calm, patient guidance turned what could have been a messy junior-high science fair idea into a proper little home investigation—and it was fun sharing the results with Dad and Luthien afterward.
questions.answer_ch: 是的——维维克叔叔和我在家里设计了几个简单的实验。上个月，他帮我设计了一个用尺子下落和秒表测反应时间的测试：他教我如何写清晰的假设（“个子更高的人抓到尺子的速度更快”），如何选择自变量（落下高度）和因变量（抓到的距离），如何控制光线和噪音，并且每次测试重复十次以获得准确的平均值。他教我如何在整齐的表格中记录数据，并在方格纸上绘制图表以观察趋势。他甚至建议增加第二个条件——在不同颜色的背景上落下尺子——来测试颜色是否会影响反应速度。他解释了为什么我们需要“对照组”（保持室温和时间一致）以避免隐藏因素的干扰，并鼓励我像他在神经生物学实验室那样清晰地报告结论。有了他平和、耐心的指导，本来可能会变成杂乱无章的初中科学展项目，变成了一个真正的小型家庭研究——事后和爸爸及露西恩一起分享结果也非常有趣。

questions.question_en: What techniques has Samira taught you about illustration or digital art that you’ve used in your own artwork?
questions.question_ch: 萨米拉教过你的哪些插画或数字艺术技巧，你在自己的作品中使用过？
questions.answer_en: Samira showed me how to blend traditional sketching with digital finishing so my drawings feel both hand-made and crisp. First she taught me to start every piece with a loose pencil or pen sketch—capturing the shapes and posture of my subject without worrying about details—then scan or photograph it and import it into Procreate. There, she showed me how to use layers: one for clean line work, another for flat colors, and extra ones for shadows (using Multiply mode) and highlights (using Overlay). She taught me to experiment with custom brushes—some that mimic watercolor washes, some that look like pencil textures—so I can build rich surfaces without getting bogged down. She also introduced me to simple color-theory tricks: picking a warm accent color against a cool background, or using complementary pairs to make my characters “pop.” Finally, Samira encouraged me to borrow patterns from Persian art—stylized floral or geometric motifs—and tuck them into borders or clothing, which gives my work a unique twist. Ever since, I’ve used her layering method and brush techniques in every project, from my “Contact” installation to my digital nature sketches.
questions.answer_ch: 萨米拉向我展示了如何将传统素描与数字润饰结合，让我的画作既有手工感又清晰利落。她首先教我用松散的铅笔或钢笔速写开始每一幅作品——捕捉主体的形状和姿态而不必纠结细节——然后将其扫描或拍照导入 Procreate。在那里，她教我使用图层：一层用于干净的线稿，另一层用于平涂，再加几层用于阴影（使用“正片叠底”模式）和高光（使用“叠加”模式）。她还教我尝试自定义画笔——有些模拟水彩晕染，有些看起来像铅笔纹理——让我在不陷入繁琐的同时营造丰富的质感。她还引入了一些简单的色彩理论技巧：在冷色背景下选用暖色点缀，或使用互补色对比让角色“跳”出来。最后，萨米拉鼓励我借鉴波斯艺术中的图案——风格化的花卉或几何纹样——将它们藏在边框或服饰中，为我的作品增添独特韵味。从那以后，无论是“接触”装置还是我的数字自然素描，我都在每个项目中使用她的分层方法和画笔技巧。

questions.question_en: How do you and Samira collaborate when creating a piece—does she let you pick colors or sketch ideas?
questions.question_ch: 在创作一件作品时，你和萨米拉如何合作——她会让你挑选颜色还是勾画构思？
questions.answer_en: When Samira and I team up on a piece it always feels like a conversation rather than one of us leading. Usually she’ll spread out jars of pigment in every shade she’s mixed and invite me to point out the two or three colors that speak to me most—sometimes I’ll surprise her by picking a dusty rose or a deep teal she hadn’t planned to use. Then I’ll sketch a few rough shapes on scrap paper—often inspired by the plants or insects I’ve been observing—while she watches, nods, then lightly traces over my lines to show me how they might flow into a final composition. Once we’ve settled on a palette and a basic layout, she shows me how to blend the paints, but I’m the one who presses the brush to the canvas and fills in the shapes with my own strokes. She never shuts down my ideas; instead she shares tips on how to make a hue glow or how to layer in texture, and I watch in awe as my simple sketches evolve into something richer. By the end, it feels like the painting is equally hers and mine—a true collaboration born from our different strengths.
questions.answer_ch: 每次当我和萨米拉合作创作一幅作品时，总感觉像是在对话，而不是由某一方主导。通常她会把各种她调好的颜料罐摊开，邀请我挑出两三种最打动我的颜色——有时我会让她惊喜地发现我选了一种她原本没打算用的尘玫瑰或深青色。然后我会在废纸上随手勾勒几个粗略的形状——往往受到我最近观察的植物或昆虫的启发——她一边看一边点头，然后轻轻沿着我的线条描绘，示范这些线条如何流向最终的构图。确定了调色板和基本布局后，她教我如何混合颜料，但是真正把笔触按在画布上，用我的笔法填充这些形状的还是我本人。她从不否定我的想法，而是分享如何让某种色调更亮更闪、如何层叠出纹理的技巧，而我则惊叹地看着我的简图逐渐变得丰富。到最后，这幅画看上去既像她的，也像我的——一场源于我们各自优势的真正合作。

questions.question_en: What gardening projects have you and Aunt Audrey done together, and what lessons did you learn about plants?
questions.question_ch: 你和奥黛丽阿姨一起做过哪些园艺项目？你从中学到了哪些关于植物的知识？
questions.answer_en: One Saturday Aunt Audrey and I built our first raised herb bed in her garden: we dug a square hole, mixed garden soil with homemade compost and leaf mold, then planted mint, basil and thyme. She showed me how mint’s roots spread underground like a hidden maze so we gave it its own pot; basil needed regular pinching back of its tips to make it bushy and keep flowering all summer. A few weeks later we set spring bulbs—daffodils and tulips—in neat lines, and Aunt Audrey explained that bulbs store everything they need to burst into color next year. In early summer we built a simple bean trellis from bamboo canes tied with string and watched runner beans climb toward the sun, teaching me that plants grow by reaching for light. We also tried propagating rosemary cuttings—stripping leaves from a stem, placing it in damp sand and waiting patiently for roots to form. From these projects I learned that healthy soil is full of life, that different plants need different spaces, and that watching a tiny seed or cutting grow into a full plant takes care, curiosity and time.
questions.answer_ch: 一个星期六，Audrey阿姨和我在她的花园里建造了我们的第一个高架草本植物床：我们挖了一个方形坑，将园土与自制堆肥和叶霉混合，然后种上了薄荷、罗勒和百里香。她给我演示了薄荷的根系如何在地下像迷宫一样扩散，所以我们给它单独配了一个花盆；罗勒则需要定期掐掉顶端，以促进分枝，让它整个夏天都开花。几周后，我们将春季花球——水仙和郁金香——整齐地排成行栽下，Audrey阿姨告诉我，花球里储存了来年绽放所需的一切。初夏时，我们用竹竿和绳子搭了一个简易的爬豆架，看着四季豆朝阳光攀爬，明白了植物通过向光生长。我们还尝试扦插迷迭香——去掉枝条下部的叶子，插入潮湿的沙子，然后耐心等待生根。通过这些项目，我学到健康的土壤充满生命，不同植物需要不同的空间，且看着一颗小种子或插条长成一株完整的植物，需要细心、好奇和时间。

questions.question_en: How do Audrey’s pets provide companionship, and have you helped her care for any of her five cats?
questions.question_ch: 奥黛丽的宠物如何提供陪伴，你有没有帮她照顾过她的五只猫中的任何一只？
questions.answer_en: Audrey’s five cats are her constant companions—rubbing against her legs as she gardens, curling up on her lap to purr away the day’s worries and greeting her with soft meows whenever she walks in the door—and yes, I’ve helped feed them their special kibble, topped up their water bowls, brushed their fur and even scooped out a litter tray or two when I visit so Aunt Audrey can focus on her plants.
questions.answer_ch: 奥黛丽的五只猫是她最亲密的伙伴——她在园艺时，它们会蹭着她的腿；它们会蜷在她的腿上，呼噜声带走一天的烦恼；每当她一进门，它们就会轻声喵喵地迎接。是的，我帮忙给它们喂特别的猫粮，添水，梳理毛发，甚至在我来访时铲过一两次猫砂盆，好让奥黛丽姑妈能专心照料她的植物。

questions.question_en: What have you learned from Jason (Audrey’s partner) about coding and software engineering in your daily routines?
questions.question_ch: 在日常工作中，你从Jason（Audrey 的伴侣）那里学到了哪些关于编码和软件工程的知识？
questions.answer_en: Jason often shows me that coding isn’t magic but a set of clear instructions—much like a recipe—to tell a computer exactly what steps to take. He’s taught me how engineers break big problems into smaller tasks, using “if…then” logic to decide outcomes and loops to repeat actions without rewriting the same lines again and again. Watching him write simple programs in Python or JavaScript, I’ve learned about variables as named containers for information, and how to test and “debug” by finding and fixing mistakes just like solving a puzzle. On weekends he’s even helped me automate a toy robot’s movements, explaining how software engineers plan, write, test and refine code so it works reliably. Through Jason I’ve discovered that coding requires both precise thinking and creativity—and that every app or game we use started as a few lines of code someone patiently crafted.
questions.answer_ch: Jason经常向我展示，编程并非魔术，而是一系列清晰的指令——就像食谱一样，告诉计算机具体的操作步骤。他教会了我，工程师如何将大问题分解成更小的任务，利用“如果……那么……”逻辑来决定结果，用循环重复执行操作，避免反复写相同的代码。看他用 Python 或 JavaScript 编写简单程序时，我了解到变量就像信息的命名容器，以及如何通过定位并修复错误来进行测试和“调试”，就像解谜一样。周末他甚至帮我让玩具机器人自动化动作，向我讲解软件工程师如何规划、编写、测试并完善代码，使其可靠运行。通过 Jason，我发现编程既需要严谨的思维，也需要创造力——而我们使用的每个应用或游戏，都源于某个人耐心编写的几行代码。

questions.question_en: What coding or technology project did Jason help you with, and how did it spark your interest in programming?
questions.question_ch: Jason 在什么编码或技术项目上帮助了你？这如何激发了你对编程的兴趣？
questions.answer_en: Jason, Aunt Audrey’s partner, showed me his little robot car after Sunday Roast one weekend. He’s a software engineer and he brought it into Uncle Irvin’s studio, opened up the hood and explained how the Raspberry Pi inside talks to the wheels. He helped me write my very first Python script—just a handful of commands to make the motors turn forward, pause, then reverse—and we watched the car obey every line I typed. Seeing code spring into motion like that felt like magic. In that moment I understood that programming isn’t just typing words on a screen but giving instructions to build something real. I couldn’t stop smiling, and from then on I begged Jason to teach me more. That first robot project sparked my curiosity: I wanted to learn how every bit of code could become a tool or a toy. I signed up for the school coding club the next week and I haven’t looked back since.
questions.answer_ch: Jason——奥黛丽阿姨的伴侣——在一个周末的周日烤肉后向我展示了他的小机器人车。他是个软件工程师，把车带到欧文叔叔的工作室，掀开引擎盖，向我讲解里面的Raspberry Pi如何与车轮通信。他帮我写了我的第一个Python脚本——仅用几条命令让电机前进、暂停，然后倒退——我们看着小车严格执行我输入的每一行指令。看到代码变成动作的那一刻，感觉就像魔法。那一刻我明白了，编程不仅仅是在屏幕上敲字，而是通过指令创造真实的东西。我笑得合不拢嘴，从那以后我就不停地央求Jason多教我。那个第一个机器人项目点燃了我的好奇心：我想了解每一行代码如何都能变成工具或玩具。下周我就报名参加了学校的编程俱乐部，从此再也没有回头。

questions.question_en: How do you and Jason explore cultural traditions together, given his Chinese heritage and family customs?
questions.question_ch: 鉴于杰森的中国血统和家庭习俗，你们如何一起探索文化传统？
questions.answer_en: I remembered how Jason and I used to share our family festivals. At Chinese New Year he showed me how to fold dumplings at his flat – we spent an afternoon pinching the skins, laughing when our shapes burst. He taught me to say “Gong Xi Fa Cai” and I taught him “Happy New Year!” in English. We went together to Trafalgar Square’s Lunar New Year celebrations, watched the dragon dance and tried eating tangyuan and spring rolls from the street stalls. Jason’s mum would invite me over afterward for real home-made jiaozi, while I begged Mum to let me repay her with my marmalade toast. At Mid-Autumn we lit paper lanterns in the garden and munched on mooncakes, Jason explaining the legend of Chang’e as I practised writing his favourite characters with ink and brush. We even cut paper-windows together on Workshop Wednesdays, Jason showing me the delicate patterns his grandmother used in Beijing. Through those shared meals and simple crafts I began to see how his family customs fit together with my Christmas tree and Sunday roasts. Exploring his Chinese heritage side by side made me feel like a true world citizen learning two cultures at once.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得我和杰森曾经一起分享我们的传统节日。春节时他在他公寓里教我包饺子——我们花了一个下午捏皮，形状爆开时我们大笑。他教我说“恭喜发财”，我教他用英语说“Happy New Year!”。我们一起去特拉法加广场的农历新年庆典，观看舞龙表演，还在路边摊尝了汤圆和春卷。之后杰森妈妈会请我去她家吃真正的手工饺子，而我则央求妈妈让我用自制的柑橘果酱吐司回请她。中秋节时，我们在花园里点亮纸灯笼，边吃月饼边听杰森讲嫦娥的传说，我则练习用毛笔写他最喜欢的汉字。我们甚至在“手工坊星期三”一起剪纸，杰森给我看他祖母在北京用的精美图案。通过这些共同的餐食和简单手工，我开始看到他的家庭习俗如何与我的圣诞树和周日烤肉相结合。并肩探索他的中国传统让我感觉自己像个真正的世界公民，同时在学习两种文化。

questions.question_en: What recipes has Edward the chef taught you to prepare, and how did you help him in the kitchen?
questions.question_ch: 厨师爱德华教你准备了哪些菜谱？你在厨房里是如何帮助他的？
questions.answer_en: Edward has shown me how to prepare a proper British Sunday roast from scratch – he taught me to brown the leg of lamb in a hot pan, season it with garlic, rosemary and sea salt, then slow-roast it until it’s tender. I helped by peeling and chopping the root vegetables for the roasting tray – carrots, parsnips and potatoes – and arranging them neatly around the meat so they cook in the lamb juices. Next he demonstrated making Yorkshire pudding batter: whisking eggs, flour and milk to just the right frothy consistency, and I took over the deafening hot tin to pour the batter in and pop it under the grill until each one rose into a golden, puffed parcel. He then showed me how to deglaze the roasting pan with red wine and stock to create a rich gravy, and I stirred it patiently until it was smooth and glossy. Edward also taught me to taste and adjust seasoning, explaining how a pinch more salt or a splash of acid can transform the flavor. After dinner I washed up the pans and utensils, learning proper kitchen hygiene and organization. Working alongside him felt like being part of a real kitchen brigade, and I loved discovering the science behind each technique – the Maillard reaction when searing meat, the steam-leavening in the Yorkshire batter – so it’s food, but also a magic experiment.
questions.answer_ch: 爱德华教我如何从头开始准备一顿正宗的英式周日烤肉——他教我先在热锅里给羊腿煎至上色，然后用大蒜、迷迭香和海盐调味，再慢烤至酥嫩。我帮忙去皮并切块根茎蔬菜——胡萝卜、欧洲防风和土豆——并把它们整齐地摆在肉周围，让它们在羊肉汁中一起烤。接下来他示范了如何制作约克郡布丁面糊：将鸡蛋、面粉和牛奶打至恰到好处的起泡稠度，然后我接过烫手的烤盘，把面糊倒入并放入烤架下烤至每一个都膨胀成金黄酥脆的包裹。他接着示范如何用红酒和高汤为烤盘去胶，做成浓郁的肉汁，我耐心地搅拌直到它光滑有光泽。爱德华还教我品尝并调整调味，解释多一撮盐或一点酸味如何能改变整体风味。晚餐后我洗刷了锅碗厨具，学习了正确的厨房卫生与整理。与他一起工作让我感觉仿佛置身真正的厨房团队，我也很喜欢探索每道工序背后的科学——煎肉时的美拉德反应、约克郡布丁面糊的蒸汽膨松——所以这不仅是烹饪，更像一次神奇的实验。

questions.question_en: How does Edward’s hometown of Manchester influence the way he cooks British dishes for your family?
questions.question_ch: 爱德华的家乡曼彻斯特如何影响他为你的家人烹饪英式菜肴？
questions.answer_en: That winter when Edward first cooked for us I noticed he brought a bit of Manchester into every dish. He made shepherd’s pie the way his mum taught him back on Rusholme’s Curry Mile, rounded out with a thick layer of buttery mashed potato and Yorkshire‐style gravy made richer by a splash of local dark ale. When he braised lamb shanks he slow-cooked them in stout and root veg from the nearby market, just as they do in his home pubs north of the Pennines. For pudding he revived a childhood favourite, the Manchester tart—sweet flaky pastry filled with raspberry jam and topped with coconut and custard. Even in simple breakfasts he’d serve bacon butties with a dollop of tangy Eccles cake jam, a nod to the old bakery stalls his grandparents loved on Sunday mornings. It wasn’t flashy, but it was honest, hearty food—exactly the practical, unpretentious cooking that comes from growing up in a city that built its spirit on industry and community. Each bite tasted like a proper northern welcome.
questions.answer_ch: 那年冬天，爱德华第一次为我们下厨时，我注意到他在每道菜里都带进了曼彻斯特的风味。他按母亲在拉什霍尔姆咖喱一条街上教他的做法做牧羊人馅饼，上面铺着一层厚厚的黄油土豆泥，再淋上掺了当地黑啤的约克郡风味肉汁。炖羊膝时，他像彭宁山北部家乡酒馆那样，用烈性黑啤和附近市场的根茎蔬菜慢炖。甜点是他儿时最爱的曼彻斯特馅饼——酥脆香甜的糕点皮，夹着覆盆子酱，顶部铺满椰丝和卡士达酱。就连简单的早餐，他也会做培根三明治，抹上一勺带酸味的埃克尔斯蛋糕果酱，向他祖父母周日早晨常去的老面包摊致敬。虽然不华丽，却真诚而厚实，正是从以工业和社区精神著称的城市成长起来的务实与朴素的烹饪。每一口都像北方人的热情欢迎。

questions.question_en: How has Diana’s career as a YouTube fashion blogger influenced your own sense of style or creativity?
questions.question_ch: Diana作为一名YouTube时尚博主的职业生涯如何影响了你自己的风格或创造力？
questions.answer_en: Diana’s fearless mix-and-match style on YouTube taught me that clothes can tell a story just like a painting, so I’ve started experimenting with my own “outfit art” before school projects—pairing my red rain boots with my green school uniform trousers or tucking a bright scarf into my jacket to see how unexpected colors play together, the same way she layers punk accessories over a satin dress; watching her reject fashion “rules” gave me the courage to break my own rules in art class—using glitter on my nature sketches or adding paper feathers to a clay sculpture—because now I know creativity isn’t about perfect technique, it’s about finding joy in what you make and wearing your imagination on your sleeve.
questions.answer_ch: 戴安娜在YouTube上那种无畏的混搭风格教会了我，衣服就像一幅画一样能讲故事，所以我开始在学校项目之前先做我的“造型艺术”实验——把红色雨靴和绿色校服裤搭配，或者把亮色围巾塞进夹克，看看这些意想不到的颜色如何碰撞，就像她把朋克配饰叠在缎面连衣裙上一样；看着她打破时尚“规则”让我有了勇气在美术课上也打破自己的规则——在我的自然写生里撒上闪粉，或者给粘土雕塑加上纸羽毛——因为现在我知道，创造力不在于完美的技法，而在于在创作中找到快乐，并把想象力穿在身上。

questions.question_en: What tips have you picked up from Diana’s videos about presenting yourself on camera or telling a story?
questions.question_ch: 你从戴安娜的视频中学到了哪些关于在镜头前展示自己或讲述故事的技巧？
questions.answer_en: I’ve noticed from watching Aunt Diana that confidence on camera comes from clear, honest storytelling and a strong visual identity. She always starts with a hook—sometimes a question or a bold statement—to draw you in right away. Her pacing is measured: she speaks slowly enough to be understood, but with enough energy to keep you interested. She uses simple, structured language—“First we’ll talk about… then we’ll explore…”—so viewers always know where they are in the story. Visually, she layers in personality with bright, contrasting accessories or a signature color scheme so her videos are instantly recognizable. Eye contact with the lens and natural gestures make her seem approachable, and she often shows real “behind-the-scenes” moments to build trust. Finally, she closes each video with a clear takeaway or call-to-action—something viewers can try themselves or think about—so her stories feel complete and leave a lasting impression.
questions.answer_ch: 我从观看戴安娜阿姨那里注意到，镜头前的自信来源于清晰、真诚的叙事和鲜明的视觉形象。她总是以一个引子开始——有时是一个问题，有时是一个大胆的说法——让你一开始就被吸引。她的节奏掌握得很恰当：说话足够慢以确保听得懂，但又充满活力以保持观众的兴趣。她使用简单、有条理的语言——“首先我们会谈……然后我们将探讨……”——让观众始终清楚自己在故事的哪个部分。在视觉上，她通过鲜艳、对比强烈的配饰或标志性色彩方案来增添个性，使她的视频一眼就能被认出。与镜头的眼神交流和自然的手势让她显得平易近人，她也常常展示真实的“幕后”片段来建立信任。最后，她在每个视频的结尾都会给出一个明确的要点或行动号召——让观众可以自己尝试或去思考——因此她的故事显得完整，并留下深刻的印象。

questions.question_en: What have you learned from Daniele’s studies at Central Saint Martins about fashion design or trends?
questions.question_ch: 你从丹尼埃莱在中央圣马丁的学习中学到了哪些关于时装设计或趋势的内容？
questions.answer_en: From talking with Daniele I’ve realised that fashion design isn’t just about pretty dresses but about ideas, history and people. At Central Saint Martins he studies how to research a culture or era and then translate that into fabrics, shapes and colours. He’s shown me how mood-boards collect photographs, textiles and sketches to explore a theme—for example punk safety-pin details or 1930s bias cuts—and how he learns to drape cloth on a mannequin before drawing precise technical patterns. He’s explained trend forecasting as a kind of detective work: watching what people choose on the street, online and in movies, then predicting which colours or textures will become popular next season. Daniele also talks about sustainability, experimenting with recycled fibres or zero-waste cutting so a single length of cloth can be cut into many pieces. He says designers at CSM learn to work quickly, sketching in ten minutes or using digital software to share ideas around the world. Above all he taught me that great design asks questions: Why this fabric? Why this silhouette? Why now? And that by learning to break rules you can invent a new style that feels both surprising and strangely familiar.
questions.answer_ch: 通过与Daniele的交谈，我意识到时装设计不仅仅是漂亮的裙子，更是关于理念、历史和人。在中央圣马丁学院，他学习如何研究一种文化或时代，然后将其转化为面料、款式和色彩。他向我展示了情绪版如何收集照片、纺织品和草图来探索主题——例如朋克风格的安全别针细节或1930年代的斜裁——以及他如何学习在人体模型上垂褶布料，然后绘制精确的技术纸样。他把趋势预测解释为一种侦探工作：观察街头、网络和电影中人们的选择，然后预测下个季度哪些颜色或质地会流行。Daniele还谈到可持续性，尝试回收纤维或零废料裁剪，以便将一整块布料裁出多件作品。他说中央圣马丁的设计师学会快速工作，在十分钟内速写，或使用数字软件与全球分享创意。最重要的是，他教会我优秀的设计会提出问题：为什么选这种面料？为什么选这种廓形？为什么要在此时此刻？通过学习打破规则，你可以发明出既令人惊喜又让人感到熟悉的新风格。

questions.question_en: How does Daniele’s Italian background influence the way they and Aunt Diana celebrate family events?
questions.question_ch: 丹尼埃莱的意大利背景如何影响他们和戴安娜阿姨庆祝家庭活动的方式？
questions.answer_en: Daniele’s Italian roots show up most clearly in the way he and Aunt Diana turn every family gathering into a kind of mini-feast and design showcase: instead of a quick tea or a single roast, they’ll lay out multiple antipasti like bruschetta and marinated olives, serve a long pasta or risotto course, follow with a platter of cheeses and charcuterie, then finish with a homemade tiramisù or panettone and tiny espressos. They greet guests with two kisses on the cheeks, fill the table with fresh seasonal flowers and bold, elegant table linens, and always pause to make heartfelt toasts—“Alla famiglia!”—before eating. I’ve noticed that since Daniele arrived, Christmas Eve has grown into an Italian style “cenone,” with seafood antipasti, mother-made meatballs and handmade pasta, and that Easter now involves an Italian colomba cake as well as hot cross buns. Their style is warm, unhurried and food-centric, with plenty of laughter, fashionably designed decorations and, of course, late-night coffee—quite different from the more restrained Sunday Roast I’m used to, but wonderful in its own lively, generous way.
questions.answer_ch: 丹尼尔的意大利血统最明显地体现在他和戴安娜阿姨如何把每次家庭聚会变成一场小型盛宴和设计展示：他们不会只是匆匆喝杯茶或吃一只烤肉，而是摆出多种开胃菜，如意式蒜香面包和腌橄榄；接着上长长的意面或烩饭；再来一盘奶酪和熟食拼盘；最后则以自制提拉米苏或潘娜托尼配上一小杯浓缩咖啡结束。他们迎接客人时会在脸颊上亲两下，桌上摆满新鲜时令花卉和大胆优雅的桌布，用餐前总要停下来举杯真诚地祝酒——“为家庭干杯！”我注意到，自从丹尼尔来到后，平安夜变成了意大利式的“cenone”，有海鲜开胃菜、妈妈做的肉丸和手工意大利面；复活节也不仅有热十字面包，还要有意大利鸽子蛋糕。他们的风格热情、不慌不忙，以美食为中心，笑声不断，时尚的装饰随处可见，当然还有深夜咖啡——和我习惯的较为克制的周日烤肉大不相同，却有着自己那种热烈而慷慨的美好。

questions.question_en: What stories did Philip S. Newton share about growing up between 1928 and 2009 that taught you about history?
questions.question_ch: 菲利普·S·牛顿分享了哪些关于他在1928年至2009年间成长的故事，这些故事让你学到了历史？
questions.answer_en: Grandfather Philip often told me what it was like to grow up in Britain between the Depression and the 21st century, and those stories taught me more history than any textbook. He spoke of standing by candlelight during the wartime blackouts, huddled in the Anderson shelter as Luftwaffe sirens wailed overhead, then waking to tally up vegetable rations—six ounces of meat a week and nothing sweeter than a spoonful of honey. He remembered cheering in Trafalgar Square on VE Day, crowded with strangers weeping with relief, and later queuing in endless lines to buy a slice of cake at a newly opened pub. He described the early days of the NHS, when his family paid nothing for doctor’s visits or medicine, and how he rode his bicycle past bombed-out buildings on his way to work in a factory that turned from producing munitions to making washing machines. He told me about listening to Churchill’s broadcasts on a wind-up radio and, decades later, seeing the first television in his living room—an incredible wonder. Through his eyes I learned not only dates and events but the everyday resilience, resourcefulness and hope of ordinary people shaping history.
questions.answer_ch: 菲利普爷爷常常给我讲他在大萧条与二十一世纪之间的英国成长经历，那些故事比任何教科书都教会了我更多历史。他说起战时停电时在烛光下站立的情景，躲在安德森防空洞里，德国空军警报在头顶呼啸，他醒来后还要清点蔬菜配给——每周六盎司肉，甜食只有一勺蜂蜜。他记得在特拉法加广场为胜利日欢呼，成千上万素不相识的人因松了口气而泪流满面；后来又在无尽的队伍中排队，只为在新开的酒馆买一块蛋糕。他描述了国民健康服务体系初创时的日子，那时家人看医生或买药都不用花一分钱；他还说起自己骑自行车路过被炸毁的建筑，去那家从生产军火转为制造洗衣机的工厂上班。他告诉我用发条收音机收听丘吉尔的广播，几十年后又在客厅里看到第一台电视——那真是不可思议的神奇。通过他的眼睛，我不仅了解了那些历史日期和事件，还看到了普通人塑造历史时的日常坚韧、机智与希望。

questions.question_en: How has hearing about Philip’s life experiences influenced your own sense of family tradition?
questions.question_ch: 听到菲利普的生活经历后，这如何影响了你对家族传统的看法？
questions.answer_en: Hearing how my great-grandfather Philip Newton rose from a working-class background to become a respected public servant taught me that our family tradition isn’t just about repeating the same holiday meals every year but about carrying forward values of hard work, curiosity and kindness; knowing Philip built a life of service and learning makes me want to ask more questions, preserve our stories and be proud of the path my family has paved.
questions.answer_ch: 听到我的曾祖父菲利普·牛顿从工人阶级家庭中崛起，成为一名受人尊敬的公务员，这让我明白，我们的家族传统不仅仅是每年重复相同的节日餐点，更在于传承勤勉、好奇和善良的价值观；知道菲利普用一生来服务和学习，使我渴望提出更多问题、保存我们的故事，并为家族铺就的道路感到自豪。

questions.question_en: What did Isabella Newton’s generation teach your grandparents that they passed down to you?
questions.question_ch: 伊莎贝拉·牛顿那一代人教了你的祖父母什么，又将这些传给了你？
questions.answer_en: My great-grandmother Isabella’s generation lived through rationing, rebuilding after the war, and a very different pace of life.  From stories Grandpa George told me, she taught him three things that I’ve come to cherish myself.  First, the value of family togetherness: every Sunday she insisted on a big family meal—no excuses—so that no one ever felt overlooked or unimportant.  Second, the art of making do: she saved every scrap of fabric and bit of food, and taught Grandpa that you could turn the simplest ingredients into a feast if you cared enough.  And third, a deep respect for tradition: she passed down the “G-name” game, so that each of her children’s names began with the same letter, signing every birthday card with the lace-edged stationery she’d embroidered by hand.  Those lessons in hospitality, thrift and honoring the past were so important to Grandpa that he kept the Sunday Roast tradition alive—and now I, in turn, know that gathering around the table, wasting nothing and celebrating our roots are gifts Isabella’s generation passed down to all of us.
questions.answer_ch: 我曾祖母伊莎贝拉那一代人经历了定量配给、战后重建和截然不同的生活节奏。根据乔治爷爷的回忆，她教给他三件我自己也倍加珍惜的事情。首先是家人团聚的重要：每个周日她都坚持举行盛大的家庭聚餐——不容任何借口——让每个人都不会感到被忽视或无足轻重。其次是巧用资源的本领：她会节省每一块布料和每一点食物，并教导爷爷，只要用心，就能把最简单的食材变成丰盛的盛宴。第三是对传统的深深敬重：她将“G字母姓名游戏”传给后代，让她每个子女的名字都以同一个字母开头，并用她手工绣制的镶边信纸为每张生日贺卡签名。对爷爷而言，这些好客、节俭和尊敬传统的教诲至关重要，以致他将周日烤肉的传统延续下来——而如今我也明白，围坐一桌、不浪费任何东西、庆祝我们的根源，都是伊莎贝拉那一代传给我们的宝贵礼物。

questions.question_en: Are there any heirlooms or keepsakes from Isabella that you’ve seen and asked about?
questions.question_ch: 你见过并打听过任何来自伊莎贝拉的传家宝或纪念品吗？
questions.answer_en: I did notice one small treasure from Great-Grandma Isabella at Grandpa’s house—a silver locket he always wears on special occasions. One afternoon I asked him, “Why do you keep that old locket, Grandpa?” He smiled and gently opened it to show me a tiny sepia photograph of Isabella as a young bride. He said she carried it everywhere, even during air raids in the war, and that it stopped ticking on the very day she passed away. Holding it felt like touching a piece of her story, so I asked him to tell me more about her every time he puts it on.
questions.answer_ch: 我在爷爷家发现了曾祖母伊莎贝拉留给我们的一个小宝物——一只他只在特殊场合才戴的银质怀表。一天午后，我问他：“爷爷，您为什么一直留着这只旧怀表？”他笑着轻轻打开，给我看里面一张棕褐色的小照片，是年轻时的新娘伊莎贝拉。他说无论走到哪里她都带着它，甚至在战争时期的空袭中也不曾离身，而且那只怀表在她去世的那天便停止了走时。触摸它，就像触碰到她生命的一部分，所以每次爷爷戴上怀表时，我都要他多给我讲讲她的故事。

questions.question_en: What stories did Sean O’Connor share from his life between 1938 and 2001, and how did they shape your family’s values?
questions.question_ch: 肖恩·奥康纳在1938年到2001年间分享了哪些人生故事？这些故事如何塑造了你们家庭的价值观？
questions.answer_en: Sean O’Connor loved to talk about growing up in rural Ireland during the Emergency years, how as a boy he cycled through snow‐choked lanes to school, learned to repair his father’s old tractor by candlelight, and foraged for blackberries and wild mushrooms in the bogs to help feed his family. He’d tell us about the bitter winter when he trudged ten miles through a blizzard to rescue his sister’s pony, and about his apprenticeship in a Dublin garage, where he discovered that no nut or bolt was ever truly useless. He was endlessly proud of the little three-room cottage he and Orla built by hand, yet even prouder of the neighbors who shared firewood and tea when times were hardest. From those tales we inherited a belief in honest, patient workmanship, in the magic of small kindnesses, and in staying open-minded to the mysteries of the world. His stories taught us that real strength lies in helping others, caring for the land, and learning something new every day.
questions.answer_ch: 肖恩·奥康纳喜欢谈论在“紧急状态”时期（即二战期间）在爱尔兰乡村长大的经历：他小时候骑着自行车穿过被大雪堵住的小路去上学；他在烛光下学会修理父亲的旧拖拉机；他还会到沼泽地里采摘黑莓和野生蘑菇来帮助养家。他会给我们讲述那个严冬——他顶着暴风雪徒步十英里去救他妹妹的小马；也讲他在都柏林一家汽车修理厂当学徒的经历，在那里他发现没有哪个螺母或螺栓是完全没用的。他对他和奥拉亲手建造的那座三间小屋引以为豪，但更为自豪的是在最艰难时刻，邻居们会分享柴火和茶。从这些故事中，我们学会了诚实而耐心的工匠精神，体会到小小善举的温暖魔力，以及对世界奥秘保持开放的心态。他的故事告诉我们，真正的力量在于帮助他人、关爱土地，并且每天学习新事物。

questions.question_en: How do your parents honor Sean’s memory in your daily life or family traditions?
questions.question_ch: 你们的父母如何在日常生活或家庭传统中纪念肖恩？
questions.answer_en: Ever since Grandpa George told us stories about his father Sean, Mum and Dad have quietly woven Sean’s memory into our everyday lives. Every Sunday at Grandma and Grandpa’s roast, they’ll pause over tea and ask me to recall one of Sean O’Connor’s favourite Irish legends or describe the old farmhouse where he and Orla raised the family. In our own home, Mum still bakes Sean’s recipe for Irish soda bread each December—she says the crackle of the crust reminds her of his laughter. Dad often hangs one of Sean’s old pocket watches on the living-room mantle, and we wind it together on Isaac’s ninth birthday, just as Sean used to wind it for Grace when she was small. In spring we plant bluebells—the wildflower Sean loved most—along our garden path, and every time I tuck a handkerchief into my pocket before school, I think of his tidy habits and the treasured handkerchiefs he passed down. Most of all, Mum and Dad speak of Sean’s kindness whenever I’m nervous or sad, reminding me that his gentle spirit lives on in our family’s care for one another.
questions.answer_ch: 自从乔治爷爷给我们讲起他的父亲肖恩的故事以来，妈妈和爸爸就悄悄地把肖恩的记忆融入我们的日常生活中。每个星期天在奶奶和爷爷家的烤肉聚会上，他们喝茶的时候都会停下来，让我回忆肖恩·奥康纳最喜欢的爱尔兰传说，或描述他和奥拉一起抚养家人的那座老农舍。在我们家里，妈妈每年十二月还会烤肖恩的爱尔兰苏打面包——她说那酥脆的面包皮会让她想起他的笑声。爸爸常常把肖恩的旧怀表挂在客厅壁炉架上，我们会在艾萨克九岁生日那天一起上发条，就像肖恩小时候常给小格蕾丝上发条一样。春天我们会在花园小径旁种上肖恩最爱的风铃草，每次我上学前把手帕揣进口袋时，就会想起他的整洁习惯和他传下来的珍贵手帕。最重要的是，每当我紧张或难过时，妈妈和爸爸都会提起肖恩的善良，提醒我，他那温柔的精神正通过我们一家人对彼此的关爱继续流传。

questions.question_en: What did Great-Grandma Orla’s clairvoyant heritage teach you about imagination and dreams?
questions.question_ch: 曾曾祖母奥拉的通灵传承教会了你有关想象力和梦想的什么？
questions.answer_en: Great-Grandma Orla’s clairvoyant heritage taught me that imagination and dreams are not mere fantasies but windows into hidden realms of thought and emotion; that the line between waking and dreaming can blur, inviting us to explore memories and feelings in new ways; that trusting our visions, even if they seem strange, can spark creativity and deepen our curiosity about the world; and that honoring these inner experiences can reveal truths science cannot yet measure, guiding us to ask better questions and to invent new possibilities—showing me that dreams feed our imagination, shaping our art, our science, and our most daring adventures.
questions.answer_ch: 曾祖母奥拉的千里眼传承教会我：想象和梦境不仅仅是幻想，而是通往隐藏思维与情感领域的窗户；醒与梦之间的界限可以模糊，邀请我们以新方式探索记忆与感受；即便异乎寻常，也要信任我们的异象，因为它们能激发创造力，深化我们对世界的好奇；尊重这些内在体验能够揭示科学尚无法衡量的真理，指引我们提出更好的问题，发明新的可能——让我明白，梦境滋养想象，塑造我们的艺术、科学和最大胆的冒险。

questions.question_en: How did Orla’s upbringing in rural Ireland influence your sense of connection to nature?
questions.question_ch: 奥拉在爱尔兰乡村的成长经历如何影响了你对自然的联结感？
questions.answer_en: Orla grew up wandering the misty fields and hedgerows of rural Ireland, and her ease among trees, stones and wild creatures taught me that nature isn’t just scenery but a living, breathing world to explore. Every summer at her old stone cottage I watched her gather herbs, whisper to the wind and tend her garden with a fierce gentleness, as if each plant were an old friend. She’d tell me how foxgloves and ferns carry stories older than any book, how the great oaks remember our ancestors’ footsteps—her tales sparked in me an urge to watch every bird, every insect, to learn their names and habits. From her, I learned that a forest isn’t silent but full of distant conversation; that floating above her kitchen once was no dream but a glimpse of that hidden dialogue; and that when I press my palm to tree bark or crouch beside a spider’s web, I am following the path she showed me—into the heart of the natural world.
questions.answer_ch:
Orla在爱尔兰乡村那弥漫着薄雾的田野和树篱间长大，她在树木、岩石和野生生物之间如鱼得水，这让我明白自然不仅仅是风景，而是一个值得探索的有生命、有呼吸的世界。  
每年夏天，在她那座古老的石头小屋里，我看着她采集药草，对着风轻声低语，以一种强烈的温柔打理花园，仿佛每一株植物都是老朋友。  
她告诉我，毛地黄和蕨类植物承载着比任何书籍还古老的故事，伟大的橡树铭记着我们祖先的足迹——她的故事激发了我渴望去观察每一只鸟、每一只昆虫，去了解它们的名字和习性。  
她让我明白，森林并不寂静，而是充满了遥远的对话；那次漂浮在她厨房上方并非梦境，而是对那隐秘对话的一瞥；当我将手掌贴在树皮上，或蹲在蜘蛛网旁时，我正沿着她为我指引的道路——进入自然世界的核心。

questions.question_en: What stories did Lucas Smith tell about life in the 1920s and 1930s, and how do they compare to your own childhood?
questions.question_ch: 卢卡斯·史密斯讲述了哪些关于1920年代和1930年代生活的故事？它们与你自己的童年相比如何？
questions.answer_en:
Lucas Smith, my great‐grandfather, used to paint a vivid picture of growing up in the 1920s and 1930s. He spoke of waking before dawn to fetch coal for the kitchen stove and of ration books clipped to his mother’s coat during hard winters. He described long queues outside church halls for free soup, and how the whole family gathered every evening around a single oil lamp to listen to the wireless. At school, there was no running water—he’d carry a pail from the hand pump at morning break—and his playground was a muddy farm field. He learned to mend his own bicycle in a neighbor’s workshop because new parts were unaffordable. His tales always carried a sense of shared hardship, where neighbors depended on one another and nothing was wasted.

By contrast, my childhood is full of comforts he could hardly imagine. I wake up to an alarm, toast pops up in a toaster, and central heating chases away any chill. I choose my breakfast from a shelf of cereals, shower with hot water at the turn of a tap, and my library fits on a tablet. Instead of queuing for soup, I rush to after-school clubs or explore the Natural History Museum with my binoculars. Yet I feel the same spark of discovery in his stories and in my own adventures—repairing my model kites or watching a rare butterfly emerge. Though our worlds differ in technology and ease, we share that curiosity and delight in small wonders.
questions.answer_ch:
卢卡斯·史密斯，我的曾祖父，常常生动地描绘他在二十世纪二三十年代的成长经历。他讲述天未亮就起床为厨房炉子取煤，艰寒的冬天他母亲外套上别着的配给券。他描述教堂礼堂外领免费汤的长龙，以及全家每晚围坐在一盏油灯旁听无线电广播。在学校里没有自来水——他得在课间用水泵打水提桶——操场则是一片泥泞的农田。他在邻居的作坊里学会修自行车，因为买新零件根本负担不起。他的故事总是带着那种共度艰难的氛围，邻里互相依靠，物尽其用。

相比之下，我的童年充满了他难以想象的便利。我被闹钟叫醒，吐司机里的面包片噗地弹起，中央暖气驱走寒意。我可以从一排麦片中挑选早餐，扭开水龙头就有热水冲澡，我的藏书都装在一个平板电脑里。不用排队领汤，我则赶去课后社团或带着望远镜去自然历史博物馆探险。然而，我在修玩具风筝或观察稀有蝴蝶破蛹而出的过程中，仍能感受到与他故事中同样的发现之乐。尽管我们的世界在科技与便利上天差地别，我们却共享那份好奇心与对微小奇迹的喜悦。

questions.question_en: How do your parents describe the lessons they learned from Lucas, and have any of those lessons stuck with you?
questions.question_ch: 你的父母如何描述他们从Lucas那里学到的教训？这些教训中有没有哪一些对你产生了影响？
questions.answer_en: My parents say that from Grandpa Lucas they learned the power of hands-on problem-solving—he’d fix any machine by listening to its whirr and poring over manuals—and the quiet confidence born of lifelong learning, as he’d spend winter afternoons lost in books yet always ready with a calm answer. My mum still recalls how he’d hug a tree to steady his nerves and never shy from getting his hands dirty, and my dad still marvels at how he balanced being a devoted family man with teaching himself new skills. Those lessons stuck with me: I dive straight into experiments without fear of mistakes, I always carry a handkerchief to collect tiny treasures, and I keep a stack of reference books by my bed, because I’ve learned that curiosity and perseverance are the best tools for any challenge.
questions.answer_ch: 我的父母说，他们从卢卡斯爷爷那里学到了动手解决问题的力量——他只要听机器的嗡鸣声、翻阅说明书，就能修好任何机器——以及他终身学习所带来的淡定自信。每到冬日下午，他常沉浸在书中，却总能给出从容的答复。妈妈至今还记得，他会抱着树来稳定情绪，从不怕弄脏双手；爸爸则仍然惊叹于他如何既是个全身心投入家庭的好男人，又能自学新技能。这些教诲影响了我：我无需畏惧错误，便敢直接投身实验；我总随身带着手帕，用来收集那些微小的“宝藏”；床头还堆着一摞参考书，因为我已明白，好奇心和坚韧不拔才是应对一切挑战的最佳工具。

questions.question_en: What did Ethel Smith’s life between 1930 and 1998 teach your family about resilience or community?
questions.question_ch: 埃塞尔·史密斯在1930年至1998年间的生活教会了你的家庭哪些关于坚韧或社区的道理？
questions.answer_en: Ethel Smith never sought the spotlight—she was a quiet force in our family’s story from 1930 until her death in 1998—but her example of steadfast care and neighbourly generosity taught us more about resilience and community than any grand gesture ever could.  Growing up in a working-class home during wartime austerity, she raised her children with the same gentle persistence she used to tend her garden: day after day she patched, cooked, swept and listened to neighbours’ troubles over tea.  Family lore paints her kitchen table as a hub where strangers became friends and small kindnesses—mending a coat, sharing vegetables, offering a cup of soup—wove people into a tight-knit circle of mutual support.  From Ethel we learned that true strength isn’t loud or dramatic but instead lives in the simple, daily acts of care that bind a community together and carry us through even the toughest times.
questions.answer_ch:
埃塞尔·史密斯从不追求聚光灯——她在我们家族的故事中是一股安静的力量，从1930年到1998年去世——但她那始终如一的关怀和邻里慷慨的榜样，比任何惊天动地的壮举都更教会了我们关于坚韧和社区的意义。  
在战时节俭的工人阶级家庭长大，她用对待花园的温柔坚持抚养孩子：日复一日地缝补、做饭、打扫，泡茶时倾听邻居的烦恼。家族传说中，她的厨房餐桌是一个枢纽，陌生人在这里变成朋友，而修补衣服、分享蔬菜、端上一碗热汤等小小善意，将人们编织成紧密相连的互助圈子。  
我们从埃塞尔身上学到，真正的力量不在于喧嚣和戏剧化，而在于那些将社区紧紧联结、让我们度过最艰难时刻的简单日常关怀。

questions.question_en: Have you seen any photographs of Ethel as a child, and what questions did you ask about her life?
questions.question_ch: 你看过埃塞尔小时候的照片吗？你都问过她哪些关于她生活的问题？
questions.answer_en: Yes, I’ve seen a handful of faded black-and-white snapshots of Ethel when I looked through Grandma Mary’s old photo album one rainy afternoon. In those pictures she’s a small girl in a simple dress, her hair in ringlets, standing barefoot on a muddy country path or seated on a wooden gate beside her beloved sheepdog. I peppered Grandma with questions: What games did Ethel play with her friends among the hedgerows? Did she ever sneak off to pick blackberries or learn to milk the family cow? How did she cope during the blackout and rationing of the war years—was she ever frightened by the air-raid sirens? I asked whether she dreamed of cities beyond the fields of County Cork or of adventures she never got to have. Hearing Grandma’s stories, I felt as if I’d walked beside young Ethel down that winding lane, and I treasure those glimpses of her childhood more than any picture alone could show.
questions.answer_ch:
是的，那天下午我在玛丽奶奶的老相册里翻看时，看到几张泛黄的黑白快照。她在那些照片里还是个穿着简朴连衣裙的小女孩，头发卷成环状，赤脚站在泥泞的乡间小路上，或是坐在木制栅栏旁，身边是她心爱的牧羊犬。

我向奶奶连珠炮似地提问：伊瑟尔跟朋友们在树林篱边玩了哪些游戏？她有没有偷偷跑去摘黑莓，或学着给家里的奶牛挤奶？在战争年代的停电和配给制下，她是怎样度过的——她有没有被防空警报吓到过？我还问她是否曾梦想过科克郡田野之外的城市，或那些从未能实现的冒险。

听着奶奶讲述，我仿佛与年幼的伊瑟尔并肩走过那条蜿蜒的小路，而我比任何一张照片都更珍视那些关于她童年的点滴记忆。

questions.question_en: What stories did John Bush share about his era, and how does knowing his lifespan (1925–2001) help you understand history better?
questions.question_ch: 约翰·布什分享了哪些关于他那个时代的故事？知道他的生卒年份（1925–2001）如何帮助你更好地理解历史？
questions.answer_en: John Bush, my great‐grandfather who lived from 1925 to 2001, used to tell us vivid first‐hand accounts of life in Britain’s mid‐20th century: what it felt like to grow up amid the austerity and rationing of the 1940s, the thrill of seeing the first cars roll off postwar factory lines where he worked, the excitement of Queen Elizabeth II’s coronation in 1953, the crackle of wireless news reporting D‐Day landings, the heady mix of Windrush arrivals in the late 1940s, the rise of rock ’n’ roll and the Beatles in the Sixties, and the social upheavals of the Swinging London era. He described the cold, concrete council estates built to replace bombed-out neighborhoods, the nervous optimism of the 1969 moon landing, and the early stirrings of the digital age in the 1980s—stories you simply don’t get from textbooks. Knowing that he was born between the World Wars and died at the start of the internet millennium helps me anchor these anecdotes in time: I can map his personal memories directly onto key historical milestones, which makes history feel immediate and human rather than just dates and facts. By tracing his lifespan alongside Britain’s broader social, political, and technological changes, I’m better able to understand how ordinary people lived through—and helped shape—extraordinary events.
questions.answer_ch: 我的曾祖父约翰·布什（John Bush）生于1925年，卒于2001年，他经常给我们讲述二十世纪中叶英国生活的生动第一手见闻：1940年代在节俭和配给制中长大的感觉；他所在的战后工厂下线首批汽车时的激动；1953年伊丽莎白二世加冕的兴奋；无线电里关于诺曼底登陆的噼里啪啦新闻声；40年代末“温德拉什”号到来带来的异彩纷呈；60年代摇滚乐和披头士崛起；以及“嬉皮”时代伦敦的社会动荡。他描绘了为取代被轰炸的街区而修建的冰冷混凝土公屋，1969年登月时那种既紧张又乐观的氛围，以及80年代数字时代初露端倪的故事——这些都不是课本里能读到的。知道他生于两次世界大战之间，逝世于互联网千禧年伊始，让我能给这些轶事找准时间坐标：我可以把他的个人记忆直接对应到关键历史节点，让历史不再只是冰冷的日期和事实，而变得鲜活有人情味。通过将他的生命历程与英国更广泛的社会、政治和科技变迁并置，我更能理解普通人在这些非凡事件中如何生活——并助力塑造它们。

questions.question_en: Do you have any family heirlooms or letters that belonged to John Bush, and what did you learn from them?
questions.question_ch: 您是否拥有任何属于约翰·布什的家传遗物或信件？您从中学到了什么？
questions.answer_en: Yes—Grandma Mary keeps a small wooden box of things that belonged to her father, John Bush. Inside are three faded letters he wrote to her when she was very young and the silver pocket watch he gave her on her twelfth birthday. In his letters he praised her curiosity—“Never stop asking why,” he wrote—and he sketched simple diagrams of the stars and trees they’d explored together in Ireland. From those letters I learned that John Bush was quietly proud of Mary’s smarts and kindness long before anyone else noticed. The pocket watch taught me how much he valued time spent with family: he engraved “To my little princess” inside the lid. Holding those heirlooms makes me feel connected to a gentle, thoughtful man whose written words and small gifts continue to guide our family’s life.
questions.answer_ch: 是的——奶奶玛丽保存着一个装有她父亲约翰·布什遗物的小木盒。里面有三封他在她年幼时写给她的褪色信笺，以及他在她十二岁生日时送给她的银质怀表。在信中，他称赞她的好奇心——“永远不要停止问为什么，”他写道——还勾画了他们在爱尔兰一起探险时观察到的星辰和树木的简图。从那些信里我了解到，约翰·布什早在别人注意到之前，就默默为玛丽的聪慧与善良感到自豪。那只怀表让我明白了他对与家人共度时光的重视：他在表盖内侧刻着“献给我的小公主”。捧着这些传家宝，我仿佛与这位温柔体贴的男士相连，他的文字和小礼物至今依旧指引着我们家族的生活。

questions.question_en: What memories do your parents share about Kate Bush’s life around 1929–2002, and how do those stories inspire you?
questions.question_ch: 你的父母分享了哪些关于凯特·布什在1929–2002年间生活的回忆？这些故事如何激励你？
questions.answer_en: My parents often tell me how Kate Bush, born in 1929 into a working-class family, quietly became the heart of her home. They speak of her two years as a maid in a grand English estate, where she first fell in love with gardening, and of her resilience when my mother Grace arrived in 1960 and my Uncle Patrick tragically died, yet Kate calmly soothed her young daughter and steadied my grandfather through long, anxious nights. They recall how she learned to juggle part-time work as a GP with raising three daughters, turning every spare minute into a chance to tend her garden or host family gatherings, always nurturing warmth wherever she went. They laugh about her endlessly rewatching “Roman Holiday” for its simple joy, and they remember her tears at Princess Diana’s funeral, revealing a deep empathy. These stories inspire me to face each challenge with quiet determination, to find beauty in small daily acts—like planting seeds or helping a friend—and to believe that caring for others, even in the toughest times, is one of the greatest strengths anyone can show.
questions.answer_ch: 我的父母常常告诉我，凯特·布什出生于1929年，家境工薪阶层，却默默成为了家庭的核心。他们提起她在英国一座宏伟庄园当了两年女仆，那是她第一次爱上园艺；又提到1960年我母亲格蕾丝到来时我叔叔帕特里克不幸去世，凯特却依然泰然自若，安抚年幼的女儿，度过漫长而焦虑的夜晚，支撑着我的祖父。他们回忆她如何一边做兼职全科医生，一边抚养三个女儿，把每一个空闲的瞬间都用来打理花园或招待亲朋好友，无论到哪里都散发着温暖。他们笑谈她无数次重看《罗马假日》，沉浸于那简单的欢乐；他们也记得她在戴安娜王妃葬礼上落泪，展现了她深沉的同理心。这些故事激励着我以平静的决心面对每一次挑战，在日常小事中寻找美好——像种下一粒种子或帮助朋友——并相信在最艰难的时刻照顾他人，是人性中最伟大的力量。

questions.question_en: Are there any traditions or recipes passed down from Great-Grandma Kate that you still enjoy today?
questions.question_ch: 从曾祖母凯特那里流传下来的哪些传统或食谱是您至今仍然喜爱？
questions.answer_en: Yes—I still love baking Great-Grandma Kate’s soda bread each winter. She taught my Mum the simple recipe she learned as a young bride in Dublin—just self-raising flour, buttermilk and a pinch of salt, gently mixed and baked until the crust is crackly and the crumb is soft and tight. Every year around Christmas and again at Easter I follow her instructions almost exactly, and I swear I can taste her kitchen in every slice. And I’ve inherited her Sunday-afternoon-tea ritual too, serving the soda bread warm with clotted cream and jam, just as she and her mother did back in Ireland. Those moments, sharing bread and tea, connect me straight to her.
questions.answer_ch: 是的——每到冬天我依然喜欢烤曾祖母凯特的苏打面包。她把这道简单的食谱传给了妈妈，那是她作为都柏林新娘时学到的——只用自发面粉、酪乳和一点点盐，轻轻混合后烘烤，直到外皮酥脆、内部松软紧实。每年圣诞节前后和复活节时，我几乎一字不差地按照她的指示来做，我发誓每一片面包都能尝出她厨房的味道。我也继承了她周日下午茶的习惯，将苏打面包趁热搭配凝脂奶油和果酱一起上桌，就像她和她母亲在爱尔兰时那样。那些分享面包和茶的时刻，让我仿佛与她直接相连。

questions.question_en: What is your favorite thing to observe about your guppies and angelfish, and how do you care for their tank?
questions.question_ch: 关于孔雀鱼和神仙鱼，你最喜欢观察它们什么？你是如何照顾它们的鱼缸的？
questions.answer_en: I love watching how the guppies and angelfish move so differently in the same water. The guppies flit around in little shoals, their tails flashing neon orange and blue when they chase each other in playful courtship dances, while the angelfish glide almost motionless, like graceful sailboats, fanning out their fins to explore every corner of the tank. At feeding time the guppies zoom up like a tiny tornado, then the angelfish drift in to pick at flakes with surprising gentleness. To keep their home healthy I check the water temperature every morning (around 25 °C), test pH and ammonia with a little kit, and do a 20–30 percent water change each week using a gravel vacuum so debris doesn’t pile up. I clean the filter media once a month in old tank water so I don’t kill the good bacteria, trim any overgrown java ferns, and feed them a mix of high-quality flakes, frozen brine shrimp, and the occasional bloodworm. That way the water stays clear, the fish stay active, and I get to enjoy their little underwater world every day.
questions.answer_ch: 我喜欢看孔雀鱼和天使鱼在同一水体中动作截然不同的样子。孔雀鱼成群游动，尾巴在嬉戏求偶时闪耀着霓虹般的橙色和蓝色光芒；而天使鱼几乎静止地滑行，宛如优雅的帆船，张开鱼鳍探索鱼缸的每个角落。喂食时间，孔雀鱼像小龙卷风般冲上来，随后天使鱼温柔地漂过来啄食鱼粮。为了保持它们的家园健康，我每天早晨都检查水温（大约25°C），用小套件测试pH值和氨含量，每周用吸砂器换20%–30%的水，以免污物堆积。我每月用旧缸水清洗过滤材料，以保护有益细菌，修剪过度生长的爪哇蕨，并喂它们高品质鱼粮、冷冻盐水虾和偶尔的红虫。这样水质保持清澈，鱼儿保持活力，我每天都能享受它们的小小水下世界。

questions.question_en: How did you learn to maintain water quality for the fish, and what challenges have you encountered?
questions.question_ch: 你是如何学会维护鱼缸水质的？你遇到过哪些挑战？
questions.answer_en: I learned about keeping our fish tank water clean from my grandfather, who showed me how to use a small test kit to check pH, ammonia and nitrate levels. He taught me to change about a quarter of the water every week by siphoning out the cloudy water into a bucket and gently topping up with fresh, dechlorinated water. Dad also showed me how to clean the filter sponge without using soap so I didn’t kill the good bacteria that break down fish waste. I practised reading the numbers on the test strips until I could spot when something was off. My biggest challenge was an algae bloom last spring: the tank turned green in two days and the fish became sluggish. I had to learn to reduce light, check our tap’s hardness and adjust feeding so leftovers didn’t rot. Another time, an ammonia spike happened after I forgot to rinse a new decoration—I nearly lost a guppy until I did an emergency water change. Keeping water quality right meant paying attention every day to how the fish swam, testing regularly and not overloading the tank with too many fish or too much food.
questions.answer_ch: 我从祖父那里学到了如何保持鱼缸水质清洁。他教我用一个小型试剂盒检测pH值、氨和硝酸盐水平。他还教我每周抽掉大约四分之一的浑浊水，用虹吸管吸到水桶里，然后轻轻加注新鲜、去氯的水。爸爸则教我如何在不使用肥皂的情况下清洗过滤海绵，以免杀死分解鱼类废物的有益细菌。我不断练习读取试纸上的数值，直到能够及时察觉异常。去年春天发生的藻类暴发是我面临的最大挑战：鱼缸在两天内变得一片绿色，鱼儿也游得迟缓。那时我学会了减少光照，检测自来水的硬度，并调整投喂量以免残饵腐烂。还有一次，因为我忘了清洗一个新装饰品导致氨浓度飙升——我差点失去一条孔雀鱼，直到紧急换水才挽回。要保持水质良好，就得每天留心鱼的游动状态，定期检测，并且不要放太多鱼或投喂过量。

questions.question_en: What is Colonel Rock’s favorite type of food, and how did you come up with his name?
questions.question_ch: 洛克上校最喜欢的食物类型是什么？你是如何想出他的名字的？
questions.answer_en: Colonel Rock’s absolute favorite treats are fresh leafy greens—especially dandelion leaves, spinach and kale—and he’ll even nibble at a slice of strawberry when he’s feeling bold. I named him Colonel Rock the day I caught him perched rigidly on his favorite basking stone, head held high as if he were a little officer on guard duty—hence “Colonel” atop his “Rock.”
questions.answer_ch: 洛克上校最喜欢的零食是新鲜的绿叶蔬菜——尤其是蒲公英叶、菠菜和羽衣甘蓝；当他心情大胆时，甚至会啃一片草莓。我给他取名“洛克上校”那天，是因为我看到他僵硬地趴在他最爱的晒背石上，昂首挺胸，就像一个执勤的小军官——于是有了“上校”在“石头”上的“洛克上校”之名。

questions.question_en: How do you make sure Colonel Rock’s environment mimics his native Brazil, and what have you noticed about his behavior?
questions.question_ch: 您如何确保洛克上校的环境与他在巴西的本土环境相似？您注意到他的行为有什么变化？
questions.answer_en: I help make Colonel Rock’s tank feel like a bit of Brazil by giving him a large glass aquarium split into a deep-water section and a dry “riverbank” area with smooth stones and pieces of Brazilian driftwood. We keep the water at about 26 °C with a clear filter to mimic the warm, slow-moving streams of his homeland. Above the basking area there’s a UVB lamp and a heat lamp so he can stretch his limbs under a gentle sun-like glow, and we gently mist the land side every morning to maintain 60–70 % humidity, just like the rainy season along the Amazon’s edge. Inside I’ve packed in lush, hardy plants—Java fern, pennywort and creeping ivy—so he can explore and hide. Since we set this up, I’ve noticed he spends longer basking, sometimes tucking one leg up like he’s snoozing on a riverbank, then swims with a sudden burst of energy as if chasing small fish. He also scratches at the sandy substrate to nibble on fallen leaves or hunt tiny snails, and he’s more adventurous around new logs or rocks, poking his head into every crevice. All of these little behaviors make me think he really feels at home.
questions.answer_ch: 我帮郎克上校的水族箱营造出一点巴西的气息：用一个大玻璃缸，一边是深水区，另一边是铺着光滑石头和巴西漂流木的干“河岸”区。我们将水温保持在约26°C，并配备高效过滤器，模拟他家乡温暖、流速缓慢的溪流。晒背区上方装有UVB灯和加热灯，让他能在柔和的“阳光”下伸展四肢；每天早晨我们还会轻雾喷洒陆地部分，保持60%–70%的湿度，就像亚马逊边缘的雨季。一盆盆茂盛耐阴的植物——爪哇蕨、铜钱草和爬山虎——填满了缸内，让他可以探索和躲藏。自从这样布置后，我发现他晒背的时间更长了，有时还会像在河岸上打盹一样把一条腿缩起来，然后突然一阵猛力游动，仿佛在追逐小鱼。他还会在细沙底基上刨动，啃食落叶或捕捉小蜗牛，对新放入的木头和石块也更感兴趣，不断把头伸进每个缝隙。所有这些小动作都让我觉得他真的找到了家的感觉。

questions.question_en: What differences have you observed between Leopard and Cleopatra in their behaviors or favorite foods?
questions.question_ch: 在它们的行为或喜欢的食物方面，你观察到豹和克利奥帕特拉有什么区别？
questions.answer_en: Leopard tends to be the bolder of the two: he’s the first to emerge from his hide at feeding time, eagerly hunting down larger crickets and mealworms, whereas Cleopatra often peeks out more cautiously and seems to prefer smaller prey she can catch with minimal effort. Leopard also spends more time exploring the terrarium at night, climbing on rocks and inspecting corners, while Cleopatra often opts to sit near her favorite basking spot or curl up under the faux bark shelter. In handling sessions Leopard will usually stay in one spot and let you stroke his back, but Cleopatra often darts away after a few seconds if she’s not in the mood. These little quirks mean Leopard’s favorite “snack” is a hefty cricket he can chase, whereas Cleopatra seems happiest when offered tiny dubia roaches or pinhead crickets she can nibble at her leisure.
questions.answer_ch: 在这两只中，Leopard更大胆：喂食时间他总是第一个从藏身处出来，急切地捕捉较大的蟋蟀和黄粉虫，而Cleopatra则更谨慎地探出头来，看起来更喜欢那些她可以轻松捕捉的小猎物。Leopard在夜间还会花更多时间探索栖息箱，爬到岩石上、检查角落，而Cleopatra往往选择待在她最喜欢的晒太阳处，或蜷缩在假树皮下。在抱玩时，Leopard通常会待在一个地方让你抚摸他的背；而Cleopatra如果心情不佳，常常几秒钟后就迅速逃开。这些小习性意味着Leopard最喜欢的“零食”是他可以追捕的大蟋蟀，而Cleopatra则最开心吃那些她可以悠闲啃食的小杜比亚蟑螂或针头蟋蟀。

questions.question_en: How did you choose their names, and what do they teach you about responsibility when caring for reptiles?
questions.question_ch: 你是如何为它们取名字的？在照顾爬行动物时，它们教会了你哪些关于责任心的道理？
questions.answer_en: I picked their names the first time I saw them explore their new home: the male’s spotted skin reminded me of a leopard prowling through tall grass, so he became Leopard, and the female’s dark ring around each eye made me think of Cleopatra’s famous eyeliner. Naming them helped me feel connected, but caring for reptiles taught me that affection isn’t enough—you must learn the science behind their needs. I had to study how to keep their tank at just the right temperature day and night, create a warm hideout for shedding, offer live insects on a careful feeding schedule, change water regularly and clean their enclosure without stressing them. I learned to watch their behavior closely—Leopard’s bursts of activity meant it was hunting time, Cleopatra’s slower movements meant she might be preparing for a shed. When I joined their habitat upkeep to my daily routine, I understood responsibility: reptiles demand consistency, patience and respect for their rhythms. In return, seeing them thrive and trust me made every early-morning temperature check and evening feeding worth it.
questions.answer_ch: 我在第一次见到它们探索新家的时候就给它们取了名字：雄性的斑点皮肤让我想起在高草中潜伏的猎豹，于是我叫它“猎豹”；雌性眼周那圈深色让我联想到克利奥帕特拉著名的眼线，就叫它“克利奥帕特拉”。给它们命名让我倍感亲切，但照顾爬行动物教会我，仅有感情是不够的——你必须学习它们需求背后的科学。我不得不研究如何昼夜保持水箱在恰当温度，为换皮提供温暖藏身处，按照严格的喂食时间表提供活昆虫，定期换水并在不惊扰它们的情况下清洁栖息地。我学会了仔细观察它们的行为：猎豹的突然活动意味着它在觅食，克利奥帕特拉的动作放缓则可能是在准备换皮。当我把它们的环境维护融入日常，我才真正理解责任：爬行动物需要持续性、耐心和对它们生理节奏的尊重。作为回报，看到它们茁壮成长并信任我，让每一次清晨的温度检查和夜晚的喂食都变得值得。

questions.question_en: How did you and your family cope when Peter was killed by a predator, and how did you help Cotton-tail adjust afterward?
questions.question_ch: 当彼得被捕食者杀死时，你和你的家人是如何应对的？之后你又是如何帮助棉尾适应的？
questions.answer_en: When Grandma phoned to tell us Peter had been fatally injured, I remember feeling my legs go wobbly as if I’d been punched in the chest, so Mum and Dad gently guided Lucy and me into the kitchen where they lit a candle on the table and we sat together talking about how much we’d loved him. That evening, we agreed to have Peter cremated and his ashes buried beneath the old oak in our garden, so that whenever we watered the flowers there we could think of him still part of our family. Over the next few days Mum and I took extra care of Cotton-tail: we cleaned her hutch more often, added fresh hay and a little cardboard tunnel to hide in, and every afternoon I’d sit in the living room with her on my lap, softly talking to her and letting her hop about the carpet under my watch. At first she seemed unsettled, thumping her hind legs once or twice as if missing her brother, but with gentle words and a bit of extra playtime — letting her nibble dandelions in the garden and offering her extra cuddles — she soon grew calmer, as if she too understood that our home was still safe and full of love even without Peter.
questions.answer_ch: 当奶奶打电话来告诉我们彼得受了致命伤时，我记得腿一软，仿佛被人重重捶了一拳，爸妈便轻轻搀着我和露西到厨房，在桌子上点燃了一支蜡烛，我们坐在一起，谈论我们是多么地爱他。那天晚上，我们决定给彼得火化，并将他的骨灰葬在花园那棵老橡树下，这样每当我们给那里浇花时，就能想到他依然是我们家庭的一份子。接下来的几天里，我和妈妈对棉尾格外用心：我们更勤快地清理她的笼子，补上新鲜的干草，还放了一个纸板隧道让她藏身。每天下午，我都会抱着她坐在客厅，轻声跟她说话，让她在我的看护下在地毯上跳来跳去。起初她有些不安，时不时用后腿重重跺地，好像在想念哥哥，但在温柔的抚慰和额外的玩耍时间——让她在花园里啃蒲公英，多给她几次拥抱——她很快就平静下来，仿佛她也明白，即使没有彼得，我们的家依然安全，依然充满爱。

questions.question_en: What is Cotton-tail’s favorite treat, and how do you and your family bond over caring for her?
questions.question_ch: 棉尾最喜欢的零食是什么？你和家人如何通过照顾她来拉近彼此的感情？
questions.answer_en: Cotton-tail’s absolute favorite treat is fresh carrot sticks paired with sprigs of parsley—I chop the carrots into matchsticks so she can nibble them easily. Every weekend, Dad, Lucy and I gather in the garden with a little basket of these treats and call her over; watching her hop down the lawn is always our cue to start laughing and cooing. We turn feeding time into a family ritual: Grandma and Grandpa join in when she’s staying with them, Mom times us as we replace her bedding and hang fresh hay, Dad shows Lucy how to clean her water bottle, and I carefully count her seeds to make sure she gets just enough. Even chores like scrubbing her hutch become a game we share. These simple moments—stroking her soft fur, offering her carrot tops, swapping stories while we work—are how we all bond over caring for Cotton-tail and remind ourselves that kindness and togetherness grow in the smallest acts.
questions.answer_ch: 棉尾最喜欢的零食绝对是新鲜的胡萝卜条和几根欧芹——我把胡萝卜切成火柴棍一样，让它啃得更轻松。每个周末，爸爸、露西和我都会带着一小篮零食到花园里，喊它过来；看着它在草坪上蹦蹦跳跳就是我们开始笑和发出咯咯声的信号。我们把喂食时间变成了家庭仪式：奶奶和爷爷过来照顾它时也会一起参加，妈妈在我们换它的垫料和挂新干草时给我们计时，爸爸教露西怎么清洗水瓶，我则仔细数它的种子量，确保它吃得刚好。就连给它刷笼子的家务活，我们都当作游戏来一起完成。这些简单的时刻——轻抚它柔软的毛发，递给它胡萝卜叶，一边干活一边聊故事——正是我们通过照顾棉尾来增进感情，并提醒自己：善意和团结就藏在这些小小的举动中。

questions.question_en: How did Pikachu, Psyduck, Peanut, and Pine nut each develop their unique personalities, and what do you enjoy most about them?
questions.question_ch: 皮卡丘、可达鸭、花生和松子是如何各自形成独特个性的？你最喜欢它们身上的什么特点？
questions.answer_en: Each of our four budgies grew into their own little person because of how they interacted with me and our home. Pikachu, the first budgie, was fearless from day one—she’d dive into my open hand and chatter nonstop whenever she spotted me in the room, so she became our bold little leader; I love her confident “good morning” whistle most of all. Psyduck, by contrast, was shy and gentle—he’d hide in the corner of his cage for days after moving in, until I coaxed him out with millet spray; now I cherish his soft, sleepy coos when he finally settles on my finger. When their babies, Peanut and Pine Nut, hatched, each showed a new spark: Peanut was endlessly curious, flitting from perch to perch and exploring every tiny corner—I adore his tiny wings fluttering with excitement—while Pine Nut was more cautious, preferring to watch the world from her favorite leaf-shaped swing until she felt safe—and her slow, contented chirp whenever I passed by always makes me smile. Together their four unique personalities—Pikachu’s confidence, Psyduck’s sweetness, Peanut’s curiosity and Pine Nut’s thoughtful calm—fill the house with joy.
questions.answer_ch:
我们家的四只虎皮鹦鹉因为与我和这个家的互动，各自长成了小小“人儿”般的性格。

皮卡丘，第一只虎皮鹦鹉，从第一天起就无所畏惧——只要在房间里看到我，她就会一头扎进我张开的手中，不停地叽叽喳喳，所以她成了我们大胆的小领袖；我最喜欢她自信的“早安”口哨声。

可达鸭则相反，害羞又温柔——刚搬来时他会在笼子角落躲上好几天，直到我用小米喷雾把他哄出来；现在每当他终于落到我的指尖，发出那轻柔带睡意的咕咕声，我就特别珍惜。

等到他们的宝宝花生和松果孵出来时，又各自展现了新的火花：花生好奇心无穷，总是在栖木间飞来飞去，探索每一个小角落——我爱看他兴奋地扑动小翅膀——而松果则谨慎得多，更喜欢待在她最爱的叶子形秋千上观察世界，直到觉得安全——每次我路过，她那慢悠悠、满足的啾啾声总能让我会心一笑。

皮卡丘的自信、可达鸭的温柔、花生的好奇和松果的沉稳，这四种独特个性一起把整个家都填满了欢乐。

questions.question_en: What challenges do you face in caring for multiple parakeets and chicks, and how do you keep them healthy?
questions.question_ch: 在照顾多只虎皮鹦鹉和雏鸟时，你面临哪些挑战？你如何保持它们的健康？
questions.answer_en: Caring for a family of parakeets and their newly hatched chicks means juggling feeding routines, hygiene, social dynamics and health checks so that each bird thrives. First, diet can be a challenge: adults need a mix of high-quality pellets, fresh greens and occasional seeds, but chicks require warm, protein-rich “egg food” or soft seed gruel several times a day until they’re fledged. I prepare homemade mixes of hard-boiled egg yolk mashed with soaked seed and a tiny dash of fruit or finely chopped vegetables, offering it in a shallow dish where both parents and chicks can eat safely. Second, hygiene is vital: droppings build up quickly, so I line the cage floor with paper I change daily, scrub perches and feeders weekly with bird-safe disinfectant and ensure fresh water at all times to prevent bacterial or fungal growth. Third, temperature and draft control matter more for chicks: I cover half the nesting box with a soft cloth to trap warmth and position the cage away from cold windows or fans. Fourth, as birds are highly social, I watch for signs of bullying or stress—sometimes one parakeet guards the food—or when a chick is lagging behind the others; in that case I gently hand-feed or temporarily isolate it until it’s stronger. Finally, I monitor health by checking plumage, appetite and activity every morning; if a bird looks fluffed up or lethargic, I consult a vet without delay. By combining careful feeding, thorough cleaning, temperature control, social supervision and daily health checks, I keep my parakeets and chicks healthy and happy.
questions.answer_ch:
照顾一群虎皮鹦鹉及其新孵出的雏鸟，意味着要同时兼顾喂食、卫生、社交动态和健康检查，以确保每只鸟都能茁壮成长。  
第一，饮食可能是个挑战：成鸟需要高品质颗粒饲料、新鲜蔬菜和偶尔的种子，而雏鸟则需每天多次喂食温热、高蛋白的“蛋食”或软种子糊，直到它们长到能够离巢自主觅食为止。我会自制将熟鸡蛋黄捣碎，与浸泡后的种子和少许水果或切细的蔬菜混合的饲料，放在浅盘中，方便父母和雏鸟都能安全进食。  
第二，卫生至关重要：鸟粪堆积很快，所以我在笼底铺上纸张，每天更换，周用对鸟类安全的消毒剂清洗栖木和喂食器，并始终保持清洁饮水，以防细菌或真菌滋生。  
第三，温度和防风对雏鸟尤为重要：我用柔软的布覆盖巢箱一半，以蓄热，并将鸟笼放在远离冷窗或风扇的地方。  
第四，鸟类非常社交，我会留意霸食或压力的迹象——有时会有个体守在食物边——或者当发现有雏鸟落后时，会将它轻轻手喂或临时隔离，直到它更强壮。  
最后，我每天早晨检查羽毛、食欲和活动情况；如果发现有鸟蓬松无精打采，就会立即咨询兽医。通过结合精心喂养、彻底清洁、温度控制、社交监督和每日健康检查，我让虎皮鹦鹉一家保持健康快乐。

questions.question_en: What is your favorite memory of receiving the rainbow stag beetle from Gerald, and how did you name it?
questions.question_ch: 你最喜欢关于从杰拉尔德那里收到彩虹锹甲的哪段回忆？你是怎么给它命名的？
questions.answer_en: My favorite memory was the exact moment Gerald reached into his pocket, grinned, and carefully lifted the tiny rainbow stag beetle from its little vial, then handed it to me as my birthday gift. I’d never expected a living treasure like that—its shell shimmered with every color of the rainbow under my bedroom light. I remember feeling a fizz of wonder in my chest as I cradled it gently, and even Mom and Dad stopped what they were doing to watch. Despite Mom’s earlier warning about no more pets, she couldn’t help but smile at how entranced I was. I decided to name him “Rainbow” because that’s exactly what his glossy shell looked like—a living spectrum of colors I’d been gifted by my best friend.
questions.answer_ch: 我最难忘的记忆是杰拉尔德伸手到口袋里，咧嘴一笑，小心翼翼地从小瓶子里捧出那只微型彩虹锹甲，然后把它当作我的生日礼物递给我。我从没想到会收到这样一个活生生的珍宝——在我卧室的灯光下，它的甲壳闪现出彩虹的每一种色彩。我记得当我轻轻捧着它时，胸口涌起一阵惊奇，就连爸爸妈妈都停下手头的事，围过来观看。尽管妈妈早先还警告过不能再养宠物，她也忍不住对我那入迷的模样露出了微笑。我给它取名“彩虹”，因为它那光滑的甲壳看起来就像一条活生生的色谱，它是我最好的朋友送给我的礼物。

questions.question_en: How do you care for your collection of flower beetles, rhinoceros beetles, ground beetles, and the giraffe stag beetle?
questions.question_ch: 你如何照顾你的花甲虫、独角仙、步甲和长颈鹿锹甲收藏？
questions.answer_en: I keep each species in its own ventilated plastic or glass terrarium with a layer of moist hardwood mulch and leaf litter to mimic the forest floor; flower beetles get extra patches of fresh blossoms or sugar-water–soaked cotton, rhinoceros beetles and the giraffe stag beetle each have half-rotten logs for burrowing and larvae, and I supplement with pieces of banana, apple or commercial beetle jellies for both nutrition and hydration; ground beetles prefer a cooler, slightly drier soil-sand mix and live prey like small mealworms or springtails. I spritz daily to maintain around 60–75 percent humidity for the scarabs, watch temperatures carefully (ideally 22–26 °C), spot-clean moldy spots weekly, and never overcrowd their tubs. I handle them only when necessary, using soft tweezers or a leaf to guide them, and I rotate natural hideouts—bark, stones and hollow stems—to keep them stimulated. Every few months I sift out old substrate and refresh it, saving a little of the old material to preserve beneficial microbes. Monitoring their activity and feeding them live or gel-based diets has kept all nine of my beetles healthy and exhibiting their natural behaviors.
questions.answer_ch: 我将每个物种分别饲养在带通风口的塑料或玻璃饲养箱中，底部铺一层潮湿的硬木碎屑和落叶，以模拟森林地面；花甲额外提供新鲜花朵或浸糖水的棉球，独角仙和长颈鹿锹甲各自放入半腐木供它们钻洞产卵及幼虫生活，我还补充香蕉片、苹果片或市售甲虫果冻以提供营养和水分；步甲则偏爱较凉、稍干的土沙混合基质，以及活饵如小黄粉虫或跳虫。我每日喷雾，保持金龟子属湿度在60–75%左右，注意控制温度在22–26°C的理想范围，每周清理霉变点，并且绝不让它们的容器过度拥挤。除非必要，我才用软镊子或树叶引导它们，平时不随意抓捏；我定期更换天然躲藏物—树皮、石块和中空茎—以保持它们的好奇心。每隔几个月，我会筛出旧底材并更换，同时保留少量旧底材以维持有益微生物。通过监测它们的活动和喂食活饵或果冻状食物，我的九只甲虫都保持健康，并展现出自然行为。

questions.question_en: How do you and Luthien decide together which princess stories to read or dress-up for when she wants to be a princess?
questions.question_ch: 你和露西恩是怎么一起决定要读哪些公主故事或者打扮成公主的？
questions.answer_en: Whenever Lucien announced she wanted to play princess, we turned it into a little game: first she rattled off the names of every fairy-tale heroine she knew—Cinderella, Moana, Elsa—while I leafed through our picture-book collection and held each cover for her to inspect. As she studied Belle’s golden gown or Merida’s bow, I watched her eyes light up or flicker in hesitation, and together we narrowed it down to two or three contenders. Then we checked the weather—no point dressing as Rapunzel if the wind was whipping—and sorted through her costume box to see which dresses matched our picks. If none quite fit, we kept our favorite story on standby and improvised: a silky white dress became Aurora’s gown with a ribbon from my art supplies, or we added a woolen cape and bonnet to make Snow White’s cloak warm enough for the chill. Once she made her final choice, I read the opening pages aloud as she fastened her accessories in front of the mirror, and we spent the rest of the afternoon acting out our favorite scenes until both our voices were hoarse and our hearts felt every bit as regal as true royalty.
questions.answer_ch: 每当露西安宣布她想扮演公主时，我们就把它变成一个小游戏：首先，她快速列出了她知道的每个童话女主角的名字——灰姑娘、莫阿娜、艾莎——同时我翻阅我们的图画书收藏，把每本书的封面给她看。当她观察贝儿的金色裙子或梅莉达的弓时，我看着她的眼睛闪烁着光芒或犹豫，然后我们一起缩小选择范围，选出两个或三个候选者。接着我们查看天气——如果风很大，就没必要打扮成长发公主——然后在她的服装盒里挑选与我们的选择相匹配的裙子。如果没有一种合适的，我们就把最喜欢的故事保留作为备用，进行即兴创作：一条丝绸白裙在我艺术用品的丝带装点下变成了奥罗拉的裙子，或者我们加上一件毛绒斗篷和 bonnet，让白雪公主的斗篷足够温暖，抵御寒冷。一旦她做出了最终选择，我在她镜子前系好配饰的时候，大声朗读开头的几页，我们把余下的下午都用来演绎我们最喜欢的场景，直到我们的声音沙哑，心中感受到的每一份都是王室的尊贵。

questions.question_en: When Luthien feels emotional or expressive, how do you comfort her and help her understand her feelings?
questions.question_ch: 当露西恩感到情绪激动或表现得很 expressive 时，你如何安慰她并帮助她理解自己的感受？
questions.answer_en: I always knelt beside Luthien, put a hand gently on her shoulder and looked her in the eyes so she knew I was really listening, then I asked her to tell me what she felt—“Are you sad? Angry? Scared?”—and waited quietly while she found words; if she couldn’t yet, I offered guesses—“It seems like you’re upset because you miss Grandma’s stories,”—so she could learn to name her feelings; once she nodded or shook her head, I would say, “That makes sense,” to let her know her feelings were valid, then I’d share a small story of my own worry or excitement to show her she wasn’t alone, and finally we’d draw or build something together—sometimes a quick sketch of a storm cloud or a bright sun—so she could see that feelings change, and I’d remind her that whatever she felt was just one part of her day, not all of her.
questions.answer_ch: 我总是跪在露西恩身边，轻轻地把手放在她的肩膀上，直视她的眼睛，让她知道我真的在倾听。然后我问她想告诉我她的感受——“你是难过吗？生气吗？害怕吗？”——静静地等待她找到词语；如果她还不能表达出来，我会提供一些猜测——“看起来你有些不开心，因为你想念奶奶的故事，”——以帮助她学会命名自己的感受；一旦她点头或摇头，我会说，“那很合理，”让她知道她的感受是有效的。然后，我会分享我自己的一小段担忧或兴奋的故事，以向她表明她并不孤单，最后我们会一起画画或搭建东西——有时是一个暴风云的快速素描或一个明亮的太阳——让她看到感受是会变化的，我会提醒她，无论她的感受是什么，只是她一天中的一部分，而不是全部。

questions.question_en: What games or activities do you play with Luthien that help her burn off her energy when she wants to sprint around?
questions.question_ch: 你和露西恩玩什么游戏或活动可以帮助她消耗精力，尤其是她想奔跑的时候？
