questions.answer_en: I find that the best way to help Luthien channel her urge to sprint is to turn running into a game. At home I often set up “cushion hurdles” down the hallway—she dashes over sofa cushions I’ve lined up, then it’s my turn, and we time each other to see who’s fastest. In the garden we play “rocket launch,” where I pick a tree or a garden gnome as the finish line and count down “3-2-1 blast off,” and she races me to it and back. At Hampstead Heath we use landmarks—“first to that big oak wins”—and she loves weaving between the trunks in a makeshift obstacle course. We also invent versions of tag like “statue tag,” where when I shout “statue!” she freezes in mid-stride until I say “go,” so she sprints, freezes, and sprints again, giggling all the way. Turning running into a playful challenge helps her burn off steam and keeps us both laughing.
questions.answer_ch: 我发现帮助露西安控制她的冲刺欲望的最好方法是把跑步变成一个游戏。在家里，我常常在走廊上设立“沙发垫障碍”，她会冲过我排列好的沙发垫，然后轮到我，我们相互计时，看谁最快。在花园里，我们玩“火箭发射”，我会选择一棵树或一个花园侏儒作为终点，然后倒计时“3-2-1发射”，她和我一起跑到终点再跑回来。在汉普斯特德希思，我们用地标——“第一个到那棵大橡树的人赢”——她喜欢在树干之间穿梭，变成一个临时的障碍赛道。我们还发明了像“雕像抓人”这样的游戏，当我喊“雕像！”时，她会在半路上停住，直到我说“开始”，然后她就会冲刺、停住，再冲刺，一路上笑得不停。把跑步变成一个有趣的挑战，帮助她释放精力，也让我们俩都乐在其中。

questions.question_en: When Gerald is disruptive in class, what do you do to help him focus and still be creative?
questions.question_ch: 当杰拉德在课堂上干扰时，你会做什么来帮助他专注并保持创造力？
questions.answer_en: When Gerald got restless in class I quietly slipped him a small sketchbook and a stubby pencil so he could draw what we were learning instead of blurting out answers. I’d smile at him and whisper, “Show me how you see it,” and he’d calm down just enough to fill the margins of his pages with quick diagrams of plant cells or cartoon versions of Sir Isaac Newton. If he still wriggled, I’d suggest he count off the key points of the lesson on his fingers—“one gravity, two inertia, three action‐reaction”—and then draw each one in a box. This little game turned his impulse into a challenge: he could be as creative as he liked, but he had to capture the facts in pictures before bouncing back to his chatter. Sometimes I asked the teacher if he could help lead a five-minute “draw-and-tell” segment so Gerald felt in charge of his creativity. By giving him a structured way to express his ideas, I helped him focus on the lesson and let his imagination fly in the margins where it belonged.
questions.answer_ch: 当杰拉尔德在课堂上心神不宁时，我悄悄递给他一本小素描本和一支短铅笔，这样他就可以画出我们所学的内容，而不是突然冒出答案。我会对他微笑并低声说：“告诉我你是怎么想的。”他会稍微冷静下来，快速在页面边缘填满植物细胞的图解或牛顿爵士的卡通形象。如果他仍然扭动，我会建议他用手指数出课程的要点——“一个重力，两个惯性，三个作用‐反作用”——然后在框内画出每一个要点。这小小的游戏将他的冲动变成了一个挑战：他可以尽情发挥创造力，但必须先用画来捕捉事实，然后再回到他的喋喋不休。有时我会问老师是否可以让他带领一个五分钟的“画与讲”环节，这样杰拉尔德就会觉得自己掌控了创造力。通过给他提供一种结构化的表达方式，我帮助他专注于课堂内容，让他的想象力在属于的边缘尽情飞翔。

questions.question_en: Which sport do you and Gerald like to play together, and how does he help you when you’re building or drawing something?
questions.question_ch: 你和杰拉尔喜欢一起玩什么运动，当你在建造或绘画时他如何帮助你？
questions.answer_en: I often played soccer with Gerald after school, dodging around cones on the field behind the gym and cheering each other on as we tried to score; and whenever I later sat down to build a model or sketch in my notebook he’d be right beside me, handing me the ruler or an extra pencil when mine rolled away, pointing out that a beam might be stronger if I shifted it just a little, or suggesting a splash of color that made a drawing come to life—his fresh ideas and willingness to help always made my creations better and the whole process more fun.
questions.answer_ch: 我经常放学后和杰拉尔德一起踢足球，在体育馆后面的场地上躲避锥桶，互相加油，希望能进球；每当我坐下来做模型或在笔记本上画画时，他总是在我身边，递给我尺子或额外的铅笔，当我的铅笔滚走时，他会指出如果我稍微移动一下，梁可能会更强，或者建议加一点颜色，让画作栩栩如生——他的新颖想法和愿意帮助总是让我的作品更好，整个过程也更加有趣。

questions.question_en: How do you and Gerald decide what to eat when he wants pizza or chicken wings—do you ever cook together at home?
questions.question_ch: 你和杰拉德怎么决定吃什么，当他想吃比萨或鸡翅时——你们有没有在家一起做饭？
questions.answer_en: When Gerald and I decide what to eat, we usually start by checking our calendars—if it’s a school night and Mom needs a break, we’ll agree to cook together; on weekends we might order in. For homemade pizza we pull out my cooking books, measure flour and yeast for the dough, then Gerald spreads the tomato sauce and picks pepperoni and extra cheese while I slice peppers and sprinkle oregano. We slide the pizza into the oven, set the timer together, and watch it turn golden. If he still wants chicken wings, we try an oven or air-fryer recipe: Gerald tosses the wings in spices and I turn them halfway through to get them crisp. Cooking side by side, planning toppings and timing, has become our way to compromise and learn—by the time we sit down to eat, whether pizza or wings, the meals taste even better because we made them ourselves.
questions.answer_ch: 当杰拉德和我决定吃什么时，我们通常会先查看日历——如果是上学的晚上，妈妈需要休息，我们就会同意一起做饭；而周末我们可能会点外卖。做自制披萨时，我们会拿出我的烹饪书，量好面粉和酵母，然后杰拉德涂抹番茄酱，选择意大利香肠和额外的奶酪，而我则切好辣椒并撒上牛至。我们把披萨放进烤箱，一起设置定时器，观看披萨变成金黄色。如果他还想要鸡翅，我们会尝试烤箱或空气炸锅的食谱：杰拉德把鸡翅放入香料中，而我则在烹饪到一半时翻面以使其变得酥脆。肩并肩地烹饪，计划配料和时间，已经成为我们妥协和学习的方式——当我们坐下来吃饭时，无论是披萨还是鸡翅，菜肴都因为我们亲手制作而更加美味。

questions.question_en: What’s a time you and Gerald stayed after school to build or create something together, and how did you decide what to make?
questions.question_ch: 你和杰拉尔德一起留校后制作某样东西的经历是什么时候？你们是如何决定做什么的？
questions.answer_en: Once, after school on a drizzly Friday, Gerald and I slipped down to his kitchen and set out to make cold-process soap, inspired by the factory visit we’d taken for our science club. We’d seen how fresh fruit and fragrant oils turned into cleansing bars and knew we wanted to try something unusual. Sitting at his chopping board, we tossed around ideas. I remembered how Dad always brewed coffee in the mornings and saved the grounds; Gerald’s mum loved rose-petal sachets; I still had that small bag of oatmeal from home; we argued briefly over whether to add mint leaves from Gerald’s garden. In the end we agreed on coffee grounds, oatmeal and a handful of crushed pink rose petals—each ingredient had to reflect something we loved or someone we knew. We carefully measured olive oil, coconut oil and lye under Gerald’s mum’s watchful eye, whisked until the mixture thickened into a custardy trace, then gently folded in our chosen additions. As the soap rested in its mold for the next forty-eight hours, we cleaned up the drips and lingering scent of lye, marveling at how our simple cooking-style brainstorming had produced something that really felt like "ours." When we unmolded the first bar a couple of days later, rough-edged and flecked with dark brown and pale pink, we beamed with pride. It tasted terrible of course—but smelled almost wonderful—and we’d learned that an experiment born of friendship, curiosity and a dash of creativity could turn ordinary kitchen scraps into something new.
questions.answer_ch: 一次，在一个细雨绵绵的星期五放学后，杰拉尔德和我滑进他的厨房，决定制作冷制香皂，灵感来自我们为科学俱乐部参观工厂的经历。我们看到新鲜水果和芬芳油脂如何变成清洁皂条，知道我们想尝试一些不同的东西。坐在他的切菜板前，我们交换着想法。我记得爸爸早上总是冲咖啡，并保存咖啡渣；杰拉尔德的妈妈喜欢玫瑰花瓣香包；我仍然有一小袋家里的燕麦；我们还为是否要加入杰拉尔德花园里的薄荷叶进行了简短的争论。最后，我们决定使用咖啡渣、燕麦和一把压碎的粉色玫瑰花瓣——每种成分都要反映我们所爱的东西或我们认识的人。在杰拉尔德妈妈的关注下，我们小心地测量了橄榄油、椰子油和氢氧化钠，搅拌直到混合物变稠成浓厚的痕迹，然后轻轻地折入我们选择的成分。当香皂在模具里静置四十八小时后，我们清理了滴落的液体和余留的氢氧化钠的气味，惊叹于我们简单的烹饪风格头脑风暴竟然产生了让我们感觉“属于我们”的东西。当我们几天后拆模取出第一块香皂时，粗糙的边缘上点缀着深棕色和淡粉色，我们都满脸自豪。它的味道当然糟糕无比——但气味几乎美妙——我们学到了一个实验，由友谊、好奇心和一点创造力所孕育，可以把普通的厨房废料变成新东西。

questions.question_en: How do you and Gerald support each other when one of you is nervous—like before a class presentation or a sports game?
questions.question_ch: 你和杰拉尔在其中一个人紧张的时候，比如在课堂演讲或体育比赛之前，如何相互支持？
questions.answer_en: Gerald and I had our own little rituals whenever one of us felt the butterflies before a presentation or a football match: we’d meet in a quiet corner of the playground, he’d tap his foot gently and I’d rub my palms together, and we’d run through our lines or moves once more, swapping roles so I could present his slide and he could coach my dribble. After a few rehearsals we’d share a soda cracker or a piece of citrus jam and breathe slowly to settle our hearts. I’d remind him of the facts he knew inside out and he’d tell me to trust my instincts – sometimes with a serious nod, sometimes with a silly joke about his latest cooking experiment, just enough to make us both smile. Then, right before stepping up to speak or join the game, we’d exchange a quick thumbs-up—our secret signal meaning “I’ve got you”—and somehow knowing we weren’t alone turned our nerves into quiet confidence.
questions.answer_ch: 杰拉德和我在每次演讲或足球比赛前，都会有自己的小仪式：我们会在操场一个安静的角落碰面，他轻轻地敲打着脚，我则摩擦着手掌，然后再次默念我们的台词或动作，互换角色，以便我可以展示他的幻灯片，他可以指导我的运球。经过几次排练后，我们会分享一块苏打饼干或一块柑橘酱，慢慢地呼吸，让我们的心情平静下来。我会提醒他他了如指掌的事实，他会告诉我要相信自己的直觉——有时是认真地点头，有时则是讲个有关他最新烹饪实验的搞笑笑话，恰到好处地让我们都笑了。然后，在准备上台发言或加入比赛的瞬间，我们会快速交换一个竖起大拇指，这是我们的秘密信号，意思是“我支持你”——知道我们并不孤单，使得我们的紧张情绪变成了平静的自信。

questions.question_en: When Gerald comes up with an impulsive idea, how do you balance his creativity with making sure things stay safe?
questions.question_ch: 当杰拉德想出一个冲动的主意时，你如何平衡他的创造力与确保安全之间的关系？
questions.answer_en: When Gerald bursts in with a wild idea—whether it’s rigging a pulley to lift paint buckets or testing homemade soap in the bathtub—I start by listening closely, asking him exactly what he wants to achieve. Then I pause the excitement long enough to talk through potential risks: What could spill, break, or pinch? Which tools will we need, and do we know how to use them safely? Next I suggest practical safeguards—protective gloves, goggles, a sturdy work surface—and we sketch a quick step-by-step plan on paper so nothing’s forgotten. If power tools or chemicals are involved, I call in Dad or Uncle Owen to supervise. We agree on clear “stop” signals if something feels wrong, and we choose a location where any accidents can’t cause serious harm—outdoors or in the garage, never inside the living room. By turning Gerald’s impulse into a careful experiment, I help him keep his inventiveness alive while making sure we both stay safe.
questions.answer_ch: 当杰拉尔德带着狂野的想法闯进来时——无论是用滑轮架起油漆桶，还是在浴缸里试验自制肥皂——我首先会仔细倾听，问他到底想要实现什么。然后，我暂停兴奋，长时间讨论潜在风险：可能会洒、破碎或夹伤什么？我们需要哪些工具，并且我们知道怎样安全使用它们吗？接下来，我建议一些实用的安全措施——保护手套、护目镜、坚固的工作台面——然后我们在纸上快速勾画一个逐步计划，以便不会遗漏任何东西。如果涉及到电动工具或化学品，我会叫上爸爸或欧文叔叔来监督。我们达成一致，如果感觉有问题，就使用明确的“停止”信号，并选择一个可以避免严重伤害的地点——户外或车库，绝对不在客厅内。通过把杰拉尔德的冲动转变为一个谨慎的实验，我帮助他保持创造力，同时确保我们都安全。

questions.question_en: What’s Gerald’s favorite way to cheer you up when you’re feeling down, and how did that first happen?
questions.question_ch: 杰拉尔德最喜欢用什么方式让你开心，当你感到沮丧时，这种情况是怎么开始的？
questions.answer_en: Gerald’s favorite trick when I’m feeling low is to launch into his full-blown penguin impersonation—flapping his arms like flippers, waddling across the room with a high-pitched “honk” and an earnest, too-serious face that makes me giggle every single time. I still remember the first time it happened: I’d come home in tears after accidentally smashing my latest soap-making batch and was sulking on the floor in the kitchen when Gerald burst in, borrowed a pair of my rubber gloves as “penguin wings,” and proceeded to “rescue” me by staging a little one-penguin parade right there by the stove. I was so astonished—and so tickled—that I forgot all about my ruined soap and ended up laughing so hard I could barely breathe. Ever since, whenever I’m down he’s honked up, flapped in, and turned my frown into a grin.
questions.answer_ch: 杰拉德最喜欢的把戏就是在我情绪低落时，开始他的全套企鹅模仿——像鳍一样拍动手臂，迈着小步子走过房间，发出高亢的“哼”声，并带着一副认真得有些过于严肃的表情，每次都让我忍俊不禁。我仍然记得第一次发生这种情况：我因为不小心砸坏了我最新做的肥皂，泪流满面地回家，正坐在厨房的地板上闷闷不乐。这时杰拉德冲了进来，借了我一双橡胶手套当“企鹅翅膀”，然后就在炉子旁为我“救援”，上演了一场小型的单企鹅游行。我惊讶得说不出话，也被逗得捧腹大笑，完全忘了我那毁掉的肥皂。从那以后，每当我心情低落时，他就会高声叫唤，扇动着翅膀，把我的愁眉苦脸变成笑容。

questions.question_en: How do you settle disagreements with Gerald when you both want to lead a project or choose the rules of a game?
questions.question_ch: 你如何解决与杰拉尔的分歧，当你们都想领导一个项目或选择游戏规则时？
questions.answer_en: I remembered once Gerald and I both insisted on being captain of our homemade cardboard airship, so we paused, gathered our ideas and drew a little map on my notebook. We each took turns explaining why our plan would work best—he talked about wind currents and stronger glue, I described better lookout positions and extra ballast—and then we weighed the pros and cons aloud. When neither of us convinced the other, we suggested a simple coin flip to choose who would lead the first day and agreed that tomorrow we’d switch roles, so each of us would get a turn. We also wrote down a few basic rules together—no hiding the scissors, respect the captain’s calls during “flight” and share the map—so no one felt left out. By listening to Gerald’s ideas, offering mine, making a fair random choice and promising to swap leadership, we found we both felt heard and excited to sail our cardboard skies side by side.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得有一次，杰拉尔德和我都坚持要成为我们自制纸板飞船的船长，于是我们暂停，汇聚我们的想法，在我的笔记本上画了一个小地图。我们轮流解释我们的计划为什么会更好——他谈到了风流和更强的胶水，我描述了更好的瞭望位置和额外的压舱物——然后我们一起大声权衡利弊。当我们都没有说服对方时，我们提议简单的抛硬币来决定谁在第一天带队，并约定明天互换角色，以便让每个人都有机会。我们还一起写下了一些基本规则——不藏剪刀，尊重“飞行”期间船长的决定，以及共享地图——让没有人感到被排除在外。通过倾听杰拉尔德的想法，提出我的意见，做出公平的随机选择并承诺互换领导权，我们发现彼此都感到被倾听，并兴奋地期待并肩在纸板天空中航行。

questions.question_en: What’s the funniest prank you and Gerald have ever pulled together, and how did your classmates react?
questions.question_ch: 你和杰拉尔一起搞过的 funniest 恶作剧是什么，你们的同学如何反应？
questions.answer_en: The trick I remember best was when Gerald and I secretly made “onion soap” for Kirk Fraser—to teach him a lesson about all his bullying. We stole a plain glycerin soap base from my mum’s bathroom, grated an onion into it and remelted it on the stove before pouring it into a mould so it looked like an ordinary bar. The next morning Gerald “found” it in his locker and wrapped it up as a “secret admirer” gift for Kirk. At break time he strutted into the boys’ toilets, unwrapped it, and began to wash his hands—only to recoil as a terrible onion stench filled the cubicle. We could hear him spluttering, banging on the door and cursing, and before long half the class had gathered outside, covering their noses and laughing so hard they nearly fell over. Even the teachers heard the commotion and rushed down to see what was going on. Kirk was furious at first, then embarrassed, but once he realized it was Gerald and me he couldn’t help laughing too. After that he stopped picking on us—for a while at least—and our classmates still call that little stunt “the great onion atrocity,” which makes us grin every time.
questions.answer_ch: 我最记得的恶作剧是我和杰拉德偷偷为柯克·弗雷泽做的“洋葱肥皂”，目的就是给他上一课，因为他总是霸凌别人。我们从我妈妈的浴室偷了一块普通的甘油肥皂基，把洋葱擦成丝放进去，然后在炉子上重新融化，再倒入模具，让它看起来像一块普通的肥皂。第二天早上，杰拉德在他的储物柜里“发现”了它，并包装成“秘密崇拜者”的礼物给柯克。课间时，他得意洋洋地走进男厕，拆开包装，开始洗手，结果一股可怕的洋葱气味充满了隔间，让他吓得退了回去。我们能听到他哽咽着拍打门，骂骂咧咧，不久班上有一半的人聚集在外面，捂着鼻子笑得快要摔倒。连老师们也听到了骚动，赶来看看发生了什么。柯克最开始非常生气，然后感到尴尬，但当他意识到是杰拉德和我干的，他也忍不住笑了。从那以后，他就不再欺负我们了——至少有一段时间是这样——而我们同学现在还称那个小把戏为“伟大的洋葱惨案”，每次提起都让我们忍俊不禁。

questions.question_en: How do you and Gerald set goals for yourselves—like learning a new skill or improving at a sport—and how do you track progress?
questions.question_ch: 你和杰拉尔是如何为自己设定目标的，比如学习一项新技能或提高运动水平，以及你们如何跟踪进展？
questions.answer_en: When Gerald and I decide to get better at something—say, I want to learn a new cooking technique and he wants to master a skateboard trick—we usually begin by naming the skill clearly and agreeing on a simple measure of success: for me it might be “cook a perfect omelette by myself,” for him “land a kick-flip three times in a row.” I then open my notebook and write down the goal, break it into smaller steps (“learn how to whisk eggs without splashing,” “practice pan control”), and schedule short practice sessions after school. I tick off each step when I finish it and note anything that went well or needs fixing. Gerald prefers a looser approach—he’ll announce, “I’m going to land it today!”—but I’ve helped him keep a tally on my whiteboard in his bedroom, so every time he tries the trick he adds a mark. At the end of each week we compare notes: I check my notebook to see how many steps I’ve completed and review my brief diary entries, while Gerald counts his marks on the board and shows me a video of his best attempt. That way, we each have a record—mine in writing, his in video and tally marks—and we celebrate every small improvement together.
questions.answer_ch: 当杰拉尔德和我决定在某个领域变得更好时——比如我想学一种新的烹饪技巧，而他想掌握一个滑板招式——我们通常会首先清楚地列出要学习的技能，并达成一个简单的成功标准：对我来说可能是“独立做出完美的煎蛋卷”，对他来说是“连续三次成功完成踢翻”。然后我会打开我的笔记本，写下目标，将其分解成更小的步骤（“学习如何打蛋而不溅出液体”、“练习控锅”），并在放学后安排短时间的练习。我在完成每个步骤后会勾掉，并记录下任何进展或需要改进的地方。杰拉尔德更喜欢一种较为随意的方法——他会宣布：“我今天要成功！”——但我帮助他在他卧室的白板上做了个记录，所以每次他尝试这个招式时都会加一个记号。在每周的结尾，我们会对比各自的进展：我查看我的笔记本，看我完成了多少步骤，并回顾我的简短日记，而杰拉尔德则数数白板上的记号，然后给我展示他最好的尝试的视频。这样，我们都有了记录——我的以文字为主，他的以视频和记号为主——我们一起庆祝每一个小进步。

questions.question_en: When Gerald is being disruptive in class, what do you say or do to help him focus without getting in trouble?
questions.question_ch: 当杰拉尔在课堂上打扰时，你会说什么或怎么做来帮助他集中注意力而不惹麻烦？
questions.answer_en: I remembered that when Gerald started doodling wildly or tapping his desk, I would lean over and quietly whisper a short question about the lesson—“Gerald, do you know why the frog’s skin is so slimy?”—so his curiosity kicked in and he stopped fidgeting. If that didn’t work I’d slide him a tiny folded note saying, “When Mrs. Harris calls on you next, mention the water cycle,” and suddenly he was alert and reading along instead of distracting everyone. Sometimes I even handed him an extra worksheet I’d made at home so he could channel his energy into solving puzzles rather than talking out loud—Mrs. Harris never realized I was helping him, and Gerald stayed out of trouble while still feeling engaged.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得当杰拉德开始疯狂涂鸦或敲打桌子时，我会靠过去，轻声问他一个关于课程的简短问题——“杰拉德，你知道为什么青蛙的皮肤这么滑吗？”——这样他的好奇心被激发了，他就不再坐立不安。如果这不管用，我会递给他一张小折纸条，上面写着：“当哈里斯老师下次叫你时，提到水循环。”突然间，他变得警觉，跟着阅读，而不是分心。有时我甚至会给他一份在家里准备的额外练习，让他能把精力集中在解谜上，而不是大声聊天——哈里斯老师从未意识到我在帮助他，杰拉德在参与的同时也避免了麻烦。

questions.question_en: What’s one thing Gerald has taught you about being bold or taking risks, and how did you apply it to something you tried afterward?
questions.question_ch: 杰拉德教会你关于勇敢或冒险的一件事是什么？你是如何将其应用到你之后尝试的事情上的？
questions.answer_en: Gerald once told me that real courage isn’t the absence of fear but the decision to act despite it: when we saw that little squirrel lying motionless in the grass, he froze, afraid to help, while I gently wrapped it in my handkerchief and checked for injuries. He later grinned and said, “Isaac, you’re an animal expert!”—and in that moment I learned that boldness means stepping forward, even if your heart pounds. A week later at our school’s insect club, I remembered Gerald’s words and volunteered to give the first-ever “Beetle Basics” talk—standing in front of classmates, I described habitat, diet and care for my nine beetles. My voice trembled at first, but as questions came, I felt proud rather than scared, all because I chose to act.
questions.answer_ch: 杰拉尔曾经告诉我，真正的勇气不是没有恐惧，而是在恐惧中选择行动。当我们看到那只小松鼠躺在草地上时，他僵住了，害怕去帮助，而我则轻轻地用手帕包裹住它并检查伤势。他后来咧嘴一笑，说：“以赛亚，你是动物专家！”——那一刻我明白了，勇敢意味着向前迈步，即使你的心在狂跳。一周后，在我们学校的昆虫俱乐部，我想起了杰拉尔的话，主动申请做首次“甲虫基础知识”的演讲——站在同学面前，我介绍了我九只甲虫的栖息地、饮食和护理。一开始我的声音颤抖，但随着问题的出现，我感到自豪而不是害怕，这一切都因为我选择了行动。

questions.question_en: How do you and Gerald plan your weekends—what do you usually agree on, and what do you compromise on?
questions.question_ch: 你和杰拉德如何计划你们的周末——你们通常达成什么共识，在哪些方面妥协？
questions.answer_en: I usually start by checking my calendar and asking Gerald what he’s keen on—he often wants to try a new sport or pop over to an Arsenal match on TV, while I’m more excited about bird-watching in Hampstead Heath or seeing a new exhibit at the Natural History Museum. We always agree on one big outdoor adventure—last weekend we both wanted to visit Kew Gardens—then carve out an afternoon for our individual passions: he’ll have a kickabout with friends or practice karting, I’ll sketch insects or fly kites on the hill. Snacks are another compromise—he votes for pizza or chicken wings, I pack marmalade toast and soda crackers, so we bring both and share. If I’ve planned a visit to Uncle Owen’s studio for painting, he’ll come along for the first hour before heading off to his own project, then we regroup for tea and a board game—Rummikub or Snakes & Ladders—and swap stories until it’s time to head home.
questions.answer_ch: 我通常先查看我的日历，问杰拉德他想做什么——他经常想尝试新的运动，或者在电视上看阿森纳的比赛，而我则更期待在汉普斯特德荒野观鸟，或者去自然历史博物馆看新展览。我们总是会达成共识，安排一次大型户外冒险——上个周末我们都想去基尤花园，然后留出一个下午来追求各自的兴趣：他会和朋友们一起踢球或练习卡丁车，我则会在山上素描昆虫或放风筝。小吃也是一种妥协——他投票支持比萨或鸡翅，我则准备橘子酱吐司和苏打饼干，所以我们各自带一点，最后共享。如果我计划去欧文叔叔的工作室画画，他会陪我一起去一小时，然后去做自己的项目，之后我们再聚在一起喝茶和玩桌游——可能是拉米库布或蛇梯游戏——交换故事，直到该回家了。

questions.question_en: What’s the most memorable impromptu performance John has given, and how did you and your family react?
questions.question_ch: 约翰进行的最难忘的即兴表演是什么，你和你的家人是如何反应的？
questions.answer_en: The most unforgettable impromptu performance John ever gave happened one rainy Friday evening after dinner, when he suddenly stood on our living-room coffee table, grabbed a wooden spoon as a makeshift microphone and launched into a perfect Olaf impression belting out “Let It Go.”  He switched seamlessly into Elsa’s soaring notes, then surprised us all by breaking into a rapid geography rap—naming every capital in South America in time to an imaginary beat.  Dad nearly choked on his tea laughing, Mom slapped her knee and hooted applause, Luthien leapt up and down cheering, and I felt like bursting with pride and astonishment at John’s talent and fearless showmanship.  Even Duke the Labrador sat there wagging his tail as if he understood every word.  That spontaneous mini-concert turned an ordinary evening into a night our whole family still talks about whenever we hear a spoon clink against a plate.
questions.answer_ch: 约翰给的最难忘的即兴表演发生在一个雨天的周五晚餐后，那时他突然站上我们的客厅咖啡桌，抓起一根木勺当麦克风，开始完美模仿奥拉夫高唱《放开》。他无缝切换到艾尔莎的高音，然后让我们所有人惊讶的是，他开始快速地做地理说唱——按节拍把南美洲的每个首都都一一列举出来。爸爸笑得差点呛到茶，妈妈拍打着膝盖欢呼，露西恩激动得跳来跳去，而我则为约翰的才华和无畏的表演感到无比骄傲和震惊。就连拉布拉多犬杜克也坐在那里摇着尾巴，仿佛他明白每一个字。这场即兴小音乐会把一个平凡的晚上变成了我们全家仍然会谈论的一个夜晚，每当我们听到勺子碰到盘子的声音时。

questions.question_en: How do you and John compare your experiences of being new to a household—what advice do you give him when he’s missing home?
questions.question_ch: 你和约翰如何比较你们作为新成员的经验——当他想家时，你给他什么建议？
questions.answer_en: When John first arrived at our house he seemed as shy and homesick as I once was on my first day at primary school—both of us clutching something familiar (him a small photo of his family in Xi’an, me a ragged jellycat apple) and staring out of place in a room that wasn’t really ours. I remember feeling a hollow ache in my chest when I walked into school without my usual routine, and John told me he feels the same emptiness when he wonders what his mother is doing or what his favourite Xi’an snack tastes like. The advice I give him is something I wish someone had given me: bring a little piece of home with you—his bamboo calligraphy brush or a favourite Zhengzhou magazine—and keep it on your bedside table so that when you miss home you can touch it and remember why you’re here. I’ve shown John how to carve out a “China corner” on my desk where he can leave postcards and draw maps of Xi’an; in return, he taught me how to whisper “ni hao” and “xie xie” properly, which made me feel closer to his world. We schedule a video‐call every Wednesday evening with his parents so that a familiar voice reaches him, and I taught him how to make simple whole wheat toast with Bonne Maman marmalade—he adapted it with a bit of Chinese tea instead of butter, and sharing it with us seemed to soothe him. When he’s missing home I tell him to join our family routines—help fold the laundry, water the plants, read aloud a page from his storybook—because small, ordinary tasks can turn a strange house into somewhere you belong. Finally, I tell him that just as I grew used to the laughter echoing down the school corridor, he’ll grow used to the footsteps on our creaky stairs, and soon this will feel less like someone else’s house and more like his own.
questions.answer_ch: 当约翰第一次到我们家时，他看起来和我在小学第一天时一样害羞和思乡——我们俩都紧握着一些熟悉的东西（他手里是一张家在西安的照片，我则握着一只破旧的果冻猫苹果），在一个并不属于我们的房间里显得格格不入。我记得在没有了平常习惯的情况下走进学校时，感到心中有一种空虚的疼痛，而约翰告诉我，当他想知道妈妈在做什么或他最喜欢的西安小吃是什么味道时，他也有同样的空虚。我给他的建议是我希望有人当时能给我的：带上一小块家乡的东西——他的竹字画刷或一本喜欢的郑州杂志——放在床头柜上，这样当你想家时就可以触摸到它，记住你为什么在这里。我给约翰展示了如何在我的书桌上开辟一个“中国角”，让他可以留明信片和画西安的地图；作为回报，他教我如何正确地低声说“你好”和“谢谢”，这让我更接近他的世界。我们每周三晚上安排一次与他父母的视频通话，让他听到熟悉的声音，我还教他怎么做简单的全麦吐司配Bonne Maman果酱——他用一点中国茶代替黄油改良了这个食谱，和我们分享时似乎让他感到安慰。当他想家的时候，我告诉他加入我们的家庭日常——帮忙折洗好的衣服，浇花，从他的故事书中大声朗读一页——因为这些小而普通的任务可以将一个陌生的房子变成一个你属于的地方。最后，我告诉他，就像我逐渐习惯于学校走廊回荡的笑声，他也会习惯我们吱吱作响的楼梯声，很快这里会感觉不再像别人的家，而更像他自己的家。

questions.question_en: What’s a favorite geography fact John taught you, and how did that spark your curiosity to learn more about that place?
questions.question_ch: 约翰教过你的一个最喜欢的地理事实是什么？那是如何激发你对那个地方更深入了解的好奇心的？
questions.answer_en: My favorite geography fact John taught me was that Xi’an, the ancient capital he grew up near, sits in a broad basin surrounded by the Qinling Mountains to the south and the Loess Plateau to the north—so the rivers flowing south become the Yangtze and those flowing north feed the Yellow River. He showed me on his atlas how that mountain ridge really divides China’s climate and culture into two whole halves, like an invisible line drawn by nature. Hearing that made me rush for our big wall map at home, trace every bend of those rivers and every peak of the range with my finger, then borrow a children’s book on Chinese geography from the mobile library so I could learn about the valley towns, the terraced farms along the foothills and how the Silk Road snaked out of that basin to the west. I felt as if I were standing on the pass myself, looking out over a land of mysteries waiting to be explored.
questions.answer_ch: 我最喜欢的地理事实是约翰教我的，他告诉我，西安——他成长的古都——坐落在一个宽广的盆地中，南边是秦岭山脉，北边是黄土高原，因此，向南流的河流成为长江，向北流的河流则汇入黄河。他在他的地图册上给我展示了那条山脊如何真正将中国的气候和文化分成两个完整的部分，仿佛是一条自然划出的无形线。听到这些让我急忙跑去我们家的大墙地图，指着那些河流的每一个弯道和山脉的每一个峰顶，然后从流动图书馆借了一本儿童书籍，学习中国地理，以便了解山谷小镇、沿山脚的梯田，以及丝绸之路如何从那个盆地蜿蜒向西。我感觉仿佛自己正站在山口上，俯瞰着等待被探索的神秘土地。

questions.question_en: When John feels clumsy or makes a mistake, how do you encourage him to keep trying and not feel embarrassed?
questions.question_ch: 当约翰感到笨拙或犯错误时，你如何鼓励他继续尝试而不感到尴尬？
questions.answer_en: When John feels awkward after tripping or botching something I remind him that I’ve had plenty of clumsy moments too—like the time I tangled myself in my kite string and face-planted into the grass—then I share how each stumble taught me something new and made me braver the next time; I lean close in a low, friendly voice, point out something he’s good at (like how his impersonations make everyone smile), and tell him that making mistakes is just one step on the path to getting better, so it’s far more impressive to dust yourself off and try again with a grin than never to try at all.
questions.answer_ch: 当约翰在绊倒或搞砸了什么事情后感到尴尬时，我会提醒他我也有很多笨拙的时刻——比如我曾经在放风筝时缠住了风筝线，脸先着地摔倒在草地上的那次——然后我会告诉他，每一次绊倒都让我学到了新的东西，下次也让我变得更加勇敢；我会靠近他，用低沉友好的声音指出他擅长的事情（比如他的模仿总能让大家微笑），并告诉他犯错只是通往进步道路上的一步，因此，能够抖掉灰尘再带着微笑继续尝试，比从来不尝试要令人印象深刻得多。

questions.question_en: How do you and John celebrate successes—like finishing a project or winning a game—so you both feel proud?
questions.question_ch: 你和约翰是如何庆祝成功的，比如完成一个项目或赢得一场比赛，以便你们都感到自豪？
questions.answer_en: When John and I wrap up a big project or win a game, the first thing we do is slap a high-five and grin at each other as if we’ve just discovered a new planet. Then we steal away to our favourite spot—usually the little café courtyard after school—order a pot of hot chocolate and a scone (John likes his with extra jam, I prefer mine plain), and sit in the sun or under the awning to talk through what went right and what we’d do even better next time. Most of the time we take a photo of our work or of the two of us celebrating, pin it to our “victory wall” in my room and text it to our parents so they can share in the excitement too. By naming exactly what we’re proud of, sharing a special treat and marking the moment on our wall, we both end up feeling truly proud—like we’ve earned every crumb of that scone.
questions.answer_ch: 当约翰和我完成一个大项目或赢得一场比赛时，我们首先做的就是击掌庆祝，彼此露出得意的笑容，仿佛我们刚刚发现了一个新星球。然后我们会偷偷溜到我们最喜欢的地方——通常是放学后的那个小咖啡馆庭院——点一壶热巧克力和一个司康（约翰喜欢加额外的果酱，我喜欢原味），然后坐在阳光下或遮阳篷下讨论这项工作的成功之处以及下次我们可以做得更好的地方。大多数时候，我们会拍下我们的作品或我们庆祝的合影，把它贴在我房间的“胜利墙”上，并发给我们的父母分享我们的兴奋。通过明确列出我们感到自豪的事情，分享一份特别的美食，并在我们的墙上标记这个时刻，我们都感到非常自豪——就像我们每一口都值得那块司康的美味。

questions.question_en: What’s a time you and John stayed up late talking about your dreams or goals, and how did that conversation change your friendship?
questions.question_ch: 你和约翰有哪个时刻熬夜聊关于你们的梦想或目标，这段对话如何改变了你们的友谊？
questions.answer_en: One Friday after Dad dropped John off for a sleepover I pulled out my star charts and we ended up lying by my bedroom window until midnight talking about what we wanted to be—me I sketched rocket blueprints, John described mapping lost cities in China—and by the time the clock struck twelve our childish jokes had grown into serious plans because John promised to teach me Mandarin so I could read his topography books and I promised to help him calculate rocket trajectories When we finally fell asleep the next day it felt like something had shifted: we stopped teasing each other and instead began pushing each other toward our ideas Whenever I shared a new cooking experiment he asked whether it might fuel interplanetary travel and whenever John hesitated on a geography project I reminded him of that night under the stars That conversation turned us into true partners in dreaming
questions.answer_ch: 有一个星期五，爸爸把约翰送到朋友家过夜后，我拿出了我的星图，我们一直躺在我的卧室窗边聊到午夜，谈论着我们想成为什么。我要画火箭蓝图，而约翰则描述在中国绘制失落城市的计划。当时钟敲响十二点，我们的儿童玩笑变成了严肃的计划，因为约翰承诺教我普通话，好让我能读他的地形书，而我承诺帮助他计算火箭轨迹。当我们终于入睡时，第二天感觉好像有什么改变：我们不再互相取笑，而是开始推动彼此朝着自己的想法前进。每当我分享一个新的烹饪实验时，他就会问这个是否能推动星际旅行；每当约翰在地理项目上犹豫时，我就会提醒他那晚星空下的对话。那次谈话使我们真正成为了梦想的伙伴。

questions.question_en: How do you help John practice English or other subjects when he struggles, and what “teaching tricks” do you use to help him learn?
questions.question_ch: 你是怎么帮助约翰在他的英语或其他科目遇到困难时练习的，你使用了哪些“教学技巧”来帮助他学习？
questions.answer_en: I usually sit next to John at the kitchen table after school and turn our lesson into a game: I ask him to read a short English recipe aloud while we bake, tapping each syllable on the counter so he hears the rhythm, then we act out the words—“stir,” “pour,” “whisk”—as if they were magic spells. When we tackle geography, I chalk a map on the pavement and hide flashcards under each country; every time he finds a card he must read the capital in English to win a point. If he struggles with a sentence, I suggest we sing it to the tune of one of his favourite songs, because John loves to sing and that helps him remember the words. For grammar, I’ll write a funny story with blanks and we fill them in together, choosing verbs and adjectives as if picking toppings for a pizza. I also let him teach me a few Chinese characters in return—he beams with pride and relaxes when his knowledge is respected. At the end of each mini-challenge I give him a cracker or a sip of tea and heaps of praise, because nothing builds confidence faster than a small treat and knowing he’s done well.
questions.answer_ch: 我通常在放学后坐在厨房桌子旁，和约翰一起把我们的课程变成游戏：我让他在我们烘焙时大声读一份简短的英文食谱，每读一个音节就拍一次台面，让他听到节奏，然后我们把词语“搅拌”、“倒入”、“打蛋”表现出来，好像它们是魔法咒语。当我们学习地理时，我在路面上画一张地图，并在每个国家下面藏闪卡；每当他找到一张卡片时，他必须用英语读出首都才能赢得一分。如果他在一个句子上挣扎，我建议我们把它唱成他最喜欢的一首歌的旋律，因为约翰喜欢唱歌，这有助于他记住单词。对于语法，我会写一个有空白的搞笑故事，然后我们一起填空，选择动词和形容词，就像为比萨饼挑选配料一样。我还让他教我几个汉字作为回报——当他的知识受到尊重时，他会自豪地笑，放松下来。在每个迷你挑战结束时，我会给他一块饼干或一口茶，和很多赞美，因为没有什么比小奖励和知道自己做得好更能快速建立自信。

questions.question_en: When John misses his family, what activities or foods do you share to help him feel more at home?
questions.question_ch: 当约翰想念他的家人时，你们分享什么活动或食物来帮助他更有归属感？
questions.answer_en: When John felt homesick, I often invited him into our kitchen to cook something he loved—Xi’an-style lamb pao mo—while he told me stories of his mother’s recipe. We’d crumble warm flatbread, pour rich lamb broth and watch the steam curl between us. Sometimes I’d make stone-baked cakes (Shizi Mo) on a griddle and we’d pull them apart, laughing at the crackle, as he explained how they bake them back home. After dinner we’d settle in the living room with a hot water bottle tucked under his blanket and video-call his family, sharing the screen so he could wave to his mother and sister. Then I’d take him to Hampstead Heath to fly the little swallow kite he’d brought from Xi’an; watching it soar made him smile. Those small rituals—cooking, calling home, and feeling the wind lift his kite—always helped him breathe easier.
questions.answer_ch: 当约翰感到思乡时，我经常邀请他到我们的厨房里做他喜欢的西安羊肉泡馍，他会给我讲述他母亲的食谱。我们会把温热的饼掰成碎片，倒上浓郁的羊肉汤，看着蒸汽在我们之间缭绕。有时我会在煎盘上做石头烤饼（石子馍），我们一边拉开它们，一边笑着听他解释在家是怎么烤的。晚餐后，我们会在客厅里安顿下来，他把热水袋塞在毯子下，视频通话他的家人，分享屏幕，让他能向他的母亲和妹妹挥手。之后我会带他去汉普斯特德希思，放他从西安带来的小燕子风筝；看着风筝高高飞起，让他露出了笑容。这些小仪式——做饭、打电话回家、感受风助着他的风筝起飞——总是让他的呼吸变得更为顺畅。

questions.question_en: What’s the biggest surprise you’ve seen from John’s hidden talents—like a song he wrote or a trick he performed?
questions.question_ch: 你见过约翰隐藏才华中最大的惊喜是什么——比如他写的歌或表演的把戏？
questions.answer_en: The biggest surprise wasn’t a magic trick at all but a song John quietly wrote and then performed on my sister’s ukulele at lunchtime.  I’d never seen him touch an instrument before, yet he stepped to the front of the hall, strummed through a perfectly timed melody and sang verses in both English and Chinese about the zoo’s animals—bees, lions and all—adding a soft vocal harmony that made everyone go completely silent.  Watching him reveal that side of himself in one breath-stopping moment showed me there’s so much more to John than anyone guessed.
questions.answer_ch: 最大的惊喜根本不是魔术，而是约翰安静地写了一首歌，然后在午餐时用我妹妹的尤克里里演唱。我从未见过他碰过乐器，但他走到大厅前，演奏出完美时机的旋律，用英语和中文演唱关于动物园动物——蜜蜂、狮子等——的 verses，并加入柔和的和声，让每个人都变得安静。看到他在那令人屏息的时刻展现出自己这一面，让我意识到约翰远比任何人想象的要丰富得多。

questions.question_en: How do you and John decide on chores or responsibilities at home—like who does which task and when?
questions.question_ch: 你和约翰是如何决定家务或责任的——例如，谁做哪个任务以及什么时候做？
questions.answer_en: At our house my parents set out a simple weekly chart on the fridge each Sunday evening, and John and I sit down with them to divvy up tasks: I usually make breakfast and pack picnic lunches, John takes on unloading groceries and tidying the living room, and we alternate who folds the laundry or helps Dad wash the car. We look at our school and activity timetable—if John has violin practice or I have swimming, we avoid scheduling a big chore on that day—then we each choose the jobs that fit our energy and time. If someone has too much homework, we politely swap chores (with a thumbs-up from Mom or Dad) so it stays fair. Every time we finish a task, we put a sticker beside it on the chart, and at the end of the week the reward is an extra half hour of game time. This system means John and I both know exactly what to do and when, and our parents are always happy.
questions.answer_ch: 在我们家，每个星期天晚上，我父母会在冰箱上贴出一个简单的周计划表，约翰和我会和他们坐下来分配任务：我通常负责做早餐和准备野餐午餐，约翰则负责卸货和整理客厅，我们轮流折叠洗好的衣物或帮爸爸洗车。我们会查看学校和活动时间表——如果约翰有小提琴练习或者我有游泳，我们就不在那天安排大任务——然后我们各自选择适合自己精力和时间的工作。如果有人作业太多，我们会礼貌地交换任务（得到爸爸或妈妈的赞许），以保持公平。每当我们完成一项任务，就会在表格旁边贴一个贴纸，周末结束时的奖励就是额外半小时的游戏时间。这个系统使得约翰和我都清楚该做什么和何时做，我们的父母也总是很开心。

questions.question_en: What’s the funniest impersonation John has done recently, and how did you react when he sang for you?
questions.question_ch: 约翰最近做的最搞笑的模仿是什么，你听他为你唱歌时的反应如何？
questions.answer_en: Recently John did a spot-on David Attenborough impression—he crouched beside my beetle tank and narrated every little antenna twitch as if unveiling a brand-new species, complete with hushed awe and excited gasps. Then without warning he burst into song, his clear, earnest voice drifting down the corridor as he softly sang “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.” I was so startled I doubled over laughing, clapped my hands, and begged him to sing it again—my whole body felt light with joy.
questions.answer_ch: 最近，约翰做了一个绝妙的戴维·阿滕伯勒模仿——他蹲在我的甲虫水族箱旁，像揭示一种全新物种一样叙述着每个小触角的晃动，满是低声的敬畏和兴奋的喘息。然后，毫无预兆地，他开始唱歌，他清晰而真诚的声音在走廊中飘荡，轻声唱着《星星掉落》。我惊得弯下了腰大笑，拍着手，恳求他再唱一遍——我的全身都充满了喜悦。

questions.question_en: When John gets homesick, what do you do to cheer him up, especially when he’s missing Xi’an food or family back in China?
questions.question_ch: 当约翰想家时，你会怎么做让他开心，特别是当他想念西安的食物或在中国的家人时？
questions.answer_en: When John starts to miss Xi’an, I first invite him into our kitchen and ask Mum if she’ll show us how to make his favourite roujiamo or yangrou paomo, so he can taste home here. While we cook, I suggest we video‐call his mum in Xi’an so he can hear her voice and catch up on family news. If it’s a special day, I’ll surprise him with the stone-baked cakes Jessica once sent—he says they remind him of Shaanxi snacks—and I’ll bring out my little Chinese globe so we can “fly” in our heads back to Xi’an’s winding streets. Then, to lift his spirits, I suggest a walk through Kew Gardens or Hampstead Heath, binoculars in hand, and we chat about the food markets he loves back home until he’s smiling again.
questions.answer_ch: 当约翰开始想念西安时，我首先邀请他进我们的厨房，问妈妈是否愿意教我们怎么做他最喜欢的肉夹馍或羊肉泡馍，这样他就可以在这里尝到家的味道。在我们烹饪的时候，我建议我们视频通话他的妈妈，让他听到她的声音，了解家庭的近况。如果是一个特别的日子，我会用杰西卡曾寄来的石烤蛋糕给他一个惊喜——他说这些让他想起陕西的小吃——然后我会拿出我的小型中国地球仪，这样我们可以在脑海中“飞回”西安的曲折街道。接着，为了振作他的精神，我提议带他去基尤花园或汉普斯特德荒野走一走，手里拿着望远镜，我们聊聊他在家乡最喜欢的食物市场，直到他再次展露笑容。

questions.question_en: Have you ever explored a geography project together, and what did you learn about a place you both found interesting?
questions.question_ch: 你们有没有一起探索过地理项目？你们对一个共同感兴趣的地方学到了什么？
questions.answer_en: Yes—I once did a mini-geography project at home with my friend Leslie after our family holiday in Dorset. We built a 3-D model of the Jurassic Coast out of clay and cardboard, marking places like Durdle Door, Lulworth Cove and Lyme Regis. In the process we learned how those tall chalk and limestone cliffs were sculpted by wave erosion over millions of years, why the coastline is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and how Mary Anning’s fossil discoveries there helped scientists understand ancient marine reptiles. We even mapped where the Purbeck Stone and Kimmeridge Clay layers appear, and found it amazing that the rocks under our feet are older than the very dinosaurs that once lived long before humans. It was a great way to see how geography, geology and history all link together in one spectacular place.
questions.answer_ch: 是的——我曾经在家里和我的朋友莱斯利一起做过一个迷你地理项目，那是在我们家族在多塞特的假期之后。我们用粘土和纸板制作了侏罗纪海岸的三维模型，标记了像达尔德门、卢尔沃斯湾和莱姆雷吉斯这样的地方。在这个过程中，我们了解到那些高耸的白垩石和石灰岩悬崖是如何经过数百万年的海浪侵蚀雕刻而成的，为什么这片海岸线是联合国教科文组织的世界遗产，以及玛丽·安宁在那里发现的化石是如何帮助科学家理解古代海洋爬行动物的。我们甚至绘制了普尔贝克石和金梅里奇粘土层出现的地方，发现脚下的岩石比在很久以前生活过的恐龙还要古老，真是令人惊讶。这个项目是观察地理、地质和历史在一个壮观的地方如何关联在一起的绝佳方式。

questions.question_en: What kind of imaginary flower did Maeve create with yarn last, and how did you help her bring that idea to life?
questions.question_ch: 梅芙最后用纱线创造了什么样的想象花朵，你是如何帮助她将这个想法变为现实的？
questions.answer_en: Maeve’s latest creation was a delicate, lantern-like bloom she dubbed the “Light of the Elves,” spun entirely from silvery-white yarn; I helped by digging out pale, iridescent threads from my art supplies, showing her how to wind them around a simple wire frame so each petal held its shape, and even tucking a tiny LED beneath the center so her imaginary flower actually glowed.
questions.answer_ch: 梅芙的最新创作是一朵精致的像灯笼一样的花，她称之为“精灵之光”，完全由银白色的纱线编织而成；我通过从我的艺术用品中挖出柔和的、闪烁的线材来帮助她，教她如何将这些线缠绕在一个简单的铁框上，以使每片花瓣保持形状，甚至在中心下面塞入一个微小的LED灯，让她想象中的花真的发光。

questions.question_en: When Maeve shares her dreams with you, what was the most surprising dream she described, and how did you respond?
questions.question_ch: 当梅芙与您分享她的梦想时，她描述的最惊人的梦是什么，您是如何回应的？
questions.answer_en: The most surprising dream Maeve described was one in which she wandered through a moonlit forest and discovered a single silvery blossom she called the “Light of the Elves.” She told me she’d never seen it in real life but knew its name from her sleep. My heart thudded because I’d dreamed of that exact flower too—handed to me by my great-grandmother Orla while I floated on a giant’s palm. When I shared this, Maeve smiled gently and said in the same quiet voice Orla had used, “They are messengers,” and in that moment we both knew our dreams were connected.
questions.answer_ch: 梅芙描述的最令人惊讶的梦是她在月光照耀的森林中漫游，发现了一朵她称之为“精灵之光”的银色花朵。她告诉我，她在现实中从未见过它，但在梦中知道了它的名字。我的心跳加速，因为我也梦见过那朵正是同样的花——是我的曾祖母奥尔拉在我漂浮在巨人的手掌上时递给我的。当我分享这个时，梅芙温柔地笑了，使用着奥尔拉曾用的同样低沉的声音说：“它们是信使。”那一刻，我们两人都知道我们的梦是相连的。

questions.question_en: Which art project have you and Maeve worked on together, and how did her quiet, dreamy nature influence the final piece?
questions.question_ch: 你和梅芙一起合作过哪个艺术项目，她安静而梦幻的性格是如何影响最终作品的？
questions.answer_en: I remember we teamed up during last spring’s Art Week to make a hanging “Dream Garden” installation in the corridor outside our classroom.  I painted long, sweeping arcs of sky and grass on canvas strips, and Maeve quietly wove dozens of tiny yarn flowers—none of which looked like real blooms but each carried her own gentle daydream.  Her stitches were so delicate and her colors so soft—pale lavender, misty green, whisper-white—that they made my bold brushstrokes feel almost too loud.  In the end, her floating blossoms drifted across my painted landscape like silent wishes carried on a breeze, giving the whole piece that unreal, drifting-in-dreams feeling only she could create.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得我们在去年的春季艺术周期间合作，在我们教室外的走廊里制作了一个悬挂的“梦幻花园”装置。我在画布条上绘制了长长的、弯曲的天空和草地，而梅芙则静静地编织了几十朵小毛线花——没有一朵看起来像真的花，但每一朵都承载着她温柔的白日梦。她的针脚非常精致，颜色柔和——淡紫色、雾霭绿色、轻柔的白色——使我的大胆笔触显得有些过于刺眼。最终，她漂浮的花朵在我绘制的风景上轻轻飘荡，就像被微风承载的无声愿望，赋予整个作品一种只有她能创造的超现实、如梦似幻的感觉。

questions.question_en: What’s the most imaginative story Maeve has shared about her yarn flowers, and how did you help turn it into a craft project?
questions.question_ch: 梅夫分享的关于她毛线花的最富有想象力的故事是什么，您是如何帮助将其变成一个手工艺项目的？
questions.answer_en: The most imaginative tale Maeve ever told me was that each of her yarn flowers sprang from the “Light of the Elves,” a silvery bloom that only appears in a secret meadow lit by moonbeams, and that these blossoms guide lost travelers back home. To help her bring that dream to life, I gathered some slender twigs from the garden to serve as tiny “forest branches,” taught her how to weave the yarn petals in moonlit hues, and we fastened the finished flowers onto the twigs. Then we painted a small wooden disk with a glowing moon motif, attached a battery‐powered LED behind it to cast a soft glow, and mounted the whole arrangement on a circular base. Finally, we wrote Maeve’s story on a little scroll of parchment hanging from one of the branches so anyone who sees the craft can read the legend of the Light of the Elves.
questions.answer_ch: 梅芙讲给我听的最富有想象力的故事是，她的每一朵毛线花都源自“精灵之光”，那是一种只有在月光照耀的秘密草地上才会出现的银色花朵，这些花朵能指引迷路的旅人回家。为了帮助她实现这个梦想，我从花园里收集了一些细长的树枝，作为微小的“森林树枝”，教她如何用月光色调编织毛线花瓣，我们把完成的花朵固定在树枝上。然后，我们在一个小木盘上画上发光的月亮图案，在后面装上一个电池供电的LED灯，让它散发柔和的光辉，并将整个装置固定在一个圆形底座上。最后，我们在一卷小卷轴上写下梅芙的故事，挂在其中一根树枝上，方便任何看到这个工艺品的人阅读精灵之光的传说。

questions.question_en: How do you and Maeve practice drawing or painting together—what tools or materials do you choose, and why?
questions.question_ch: 你和梅芙如何一起练习绘画或上色——你们选择哪些工具或材料，为什么？
questions.answer_en: Maeve and I usually claim one corner of my uncle Owen’s studio and set up a simple workspace: a sturdy drawing board propped against the wall, thick mixed-media paper taped down along the edges, and a little palette made from an old cereal box. We lay out a 24-colour wooden pencil set for fine lines and subtle shading, a small tin of oil pastels for rich, bold swathes of colour, and a pan of water-colours for washes that blend unpredictably when we drip extra water on them. I always bring my handkerchief to wipe brushes or fingers, and she brings a scrap of waxed cardboard for mixing pastel crumbs into smoky tones. We choose those materials because pencils let us capture tiny details—like the veins in a leaf or the curve of a petal—while oil pastels give us that sudden burst of brightness when we want to show sunlight. Water-colours teach us to embrace surprise: a spill becomes a cloud, a gradient becomes shadow. Together we share ideas—she’ll start a dreamy flower in pastel, and I’ll outline it in pencil or add a translucent water-colour glaze over it—so our pieces feel like something between her dreams and my observations. In that corner, with simple tools and our imaginations, drawing and painting become a game of discovery for both of us.
questions.answer_ch: 梅芙和我通常会占据我叔叔欧文工作室的一个角落，设立一个简单的工作空间：一块坚固的绘图板靠在墙上，厚厚的混合媒介纸沿边缘用胶带贴好，还有一个用旧麦片盒做的小调色板。我们摆出一套24色的木铅笔以便绘制细腻的线条和微妙的阴影，一小罐油画棒用来展示丰富大胆的色彩，还有一盘水彩，能在我们滴上额外的水时产生不可预测的混合效果。我总是带上手帕来擦拭画笔或手指，而她则带一块涂蜡的纸板，用来将油画棒的碎屑混合成烟雾般的色调。我们选择这些材料是因为铅笔能捕捉细微的细节——比如叶脉或花瓣的曲线——而油画棒在我们想展示阳光时能带来突如其来的明亮感。水彩则教会我们拥抱惊喜：一次溢出变成了云彩，渐变成了阴影。我们一起分享创意——她会用粉彩开始一朵梦幻的花，而我则用铅笔勾勒轮廓或者在上面加一层半透明的水彩釉——因此我们的作品感觉介于她的梦境和我的观察之间。在那个角落里，凭借简单的工具和我们的想象力，绘画和上色成为了我们共同探索的游戏。

questions.question_en: When Maeve feels shy about showing her art, what do you say or do to help her gain confidence?
questions.question_ch: 当梅夫对展示她的艺术感到害羞时，你会说什么或做什么来帮助她增强信心？
questions.answer_en: I remembered one afternoon Maeve tucked her drawing under her arm instead of showing it in our art club, so I knelt beside her and quietly told her that every line she drew was a story only she could tell and that I would be first in line to hear it. When she looked at me, still worried, I asked if I could draw alongside her on a scrap piece of paper, using the same colors but in our own way. As she watched my blue strokes appear, she smiled and whispered that it looked fun, so I gently encouraged her to add just one petal of her flower to the display board. When she did, I clapped softly and said I was proud of her courage—reminding her that even the greatest artists felt shy before sharing their work. After that, Maeve let me hang her drawing and stood back with her chest puffed out, beaming with pride.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得有一个下午，梅芙把她的画夹在腋下，没有在我们的艺术俱乐部展示。我便跪在她身边，轻声告诉她，她每一笔画都是一个只有她能讲述的故事，而我会第一个站出来倾听。当她看着我，仍然感到担心时，我问她是否可以在一张废纸上和她一起画，用相同的颜色，但以我们自己的方式。当她看到我蓝色的笔触出现时，她微笑着低声说看起来很有趣，于是我温柔地鼓励她在展示板上加上她花朵的一片花瓣。当她这样做时，我轻声鼓掌，告诉她我为她的勇气感到骄傲——提醒她，即使是最伟大的艺术家在分享作品之前也会感到害羞。在那之后，梅芙让我把她的画挂上去，并自豪地挺着胸膛站在一旁，满脸骄傲。

questions.question_en: What’s a dream Maeve described that really surprised you, and how did it change your own view of imagination?
questions.question_ch: 梅芙描述的哪个梦令你感到惊讶，它是如何改变你对想象力的看法的？
questions.answer_en: She told me about a dream in which a single, silver-glowing blossom drifted through midnight air and whispered secrets as it passed—a flower she named the “Light of the Elves.” I was stunned, because I’d seen the very same bloom in my own dream months earlier, though Maeve and I had never compared notes before. In that moment I realized imagination isn’t just a private trick of the mind but a vast, shared territory where dreams can echo one another, and that the most fantastical ideas can be as real and meaningful as what we see with our eyes. It taught me that inventing in my head isn’t mere play—it’s exploration of possibilities others might also discover.
questions.answer_ch: 她告诉我一个梦，梦中一朵单独的、银光闪闪的花朵在午夜的空气中漂流，经过时悄悄地低语着秘密——她称这朵花为“精灵之光”。我震惊了，因为几个月前我在自己的梦中也见过同样的花，尽管我和梅芙从未进行过比较。在那一刻，我意识到想象力不仅仅是心灵的私人把戏，它是一个广阔的、共享的领域，在那里梦想可以彼此共鸣，最奇幻的想法也可以与我们用眼睛看到的现实一样真实和有意义。这让我明白，在脑海中创造并不仅仅是玩耍——这是一种探索其他人可能也会发现的可能性。

questions.question_en: How do you and Maeve decide which art supplies to use when crafting—do you plan together or let each other choose freely?
questions.question_ch: 你和梅芙在制作时如何决定使用哪些艺术材料——是一起计划还是让彼此自由选择？
questions.answer_en: Maeve and I usually begin by talking quietly about what we’d like to express—sometimes a mood (joyful, mysterious) or a theme (forest, the sea), and from there we sketch a few ideas on scraps of paper. Once we’ve agreed on the rough direction we each browse my “corner” and her little stash of yarns, papers, paints and found objects, selecting whatever calls to us in that moment. I tend to gravitate toward bright paints and odd-shaped cardboard pieces, while she often reaches for delicate threads or translucent papers, and then we swap our favorites. We rarely map out an exact list of supplies; instead we trust that our initial conversation has steered us close to the right materials and then let intuition guide our hands as we gather. If one of us finds an unexpected treasure—a bit of twine or a shard of colored plastic—we’ll cheer and fold it into the project. In the end our pieces feel like a true blend of both our visions.
questions.answer_ch: 梅芙和我通常开始时会安静地讨论我们想要表达的内容——有时是情绪（快乐、神秘）或主题（森林、大海），然后我们在一些纸片上草拟几个想法。一旦我们对大致方向达成一致，我们各自浏览我的“角落”和她的小存货，包括纱线、纸张、颜料和发现的物品，选择当下吸引我们的任何东西。我倾向于选用明亮的颜料和形状奇特的纸板，而她则常常选择精致的线或透明纸，然后我们交换各自的最爱。我们很少详细列出材料清单；相反，我们相信最初的对话已经引导我们接近合适的材料，然后让直觉引导我们的双手去收集。如果我们中的一个人找到意想不到的宝藏——一段麻绳或一片彩色塑料——我们会欢呼并将其纳入项目中。最终，我们的作品感觉像是我们两人愿景的真正融合。

questions.question_en: What’s the longest art project you and Maeve have worked on over a weekend, and how did you keep each other motivated?
questions.question_ch: 你和梅芙在一个周末上做过的最长的艺术项目是什么？你们是如何相互激励的？
questions.answer_en: It was the spring weekend before Art Week last year when Maeve and I worked non‐stop from Saturday morning until Sunday evening on a giant “garden planet” collage for our classroom hall. I spent hours splattering paint across a huge board while she crocheted and stitched hundreds of tiny yarn flowers into my patterns. We kept each other going by sharing hot chocolate and soda crackers at regular breaks, reading aloud lines from our favorite nature poems to spark new ideas, and setting little goals—“let’s finish that flower cluster before lunch” or “five more paint splashes before we watch one episode of The Secret of Kells.” Whenever the glue refused to stick or our hands grew tired, one of us would remind the other of how amazing it would look hanging in the hall, and we’d exchange determined smiles and get right back to work. By Sunday evening we were exhausted and hungry but thrilled to see our secret garden come to life—our longest, most joyful art adventure together.
questions.answer_ch: 去年的艺术周前的春季周末，梅芙和我从周六早上到周日晚上不停地工作，为我们的教室走廊制作一个巨大的“花园星球”拼贴。我花了几个小时在一块大板上泼洒颜料，而她则在我的图案中钩织并缝制成百上千的小毛线花。我们在定期休息时分享热巧克力和苏打饼干，朗读我们最喜欢的自然诗句来激发新的想法，并设定小目标——“午餐前完成那一簇花”或“再泼五次颜料后再看《凯尔斯的秘密》的一集。”每当胶水不粘或我们的手感到疲惫时，其中一个会提醒另一个，想象它挂在走廊里的样子是多么惊艳，然后我们互相交换坚定的微笑，立刻回到工作中。到周日晚上，我们筋疲力尽，饥肠辘辘，但看到我们的秘密花园栩栩如生，感到无比兴奋——这是我们一起经历的最长、最快乐的艺术冒险。

questions.question_en: When Maeve invents a new imaginary flower, how do you and she assign its colors, shape, and name together?
questions.question_ch: 当梅芙发明一种新的虚构花朵时，你们是如何一起确定它的颜色、形状和名字的？
questions.answer_en: Whenever Maeve and I imagine a new flower we begin by talking about its story—does it grow in moonlight or deep beneath a hidden grotto?—and that tale tells us what colors it needs, so if it’s born of starlight we choose silvery blues and pale purples, but if it’s a sunset bloom we’ll use sunset reds, oranges and golds. Then, without sketching, Maeve twists and loops yarn into the petal shapes she sees in her mind—long and spiky like candelabras or fat and bell-shaped like lanterns—while I hold up colored pencils against her hands to find the perfect hue match. Finally we invent a name by blending syllables from places that inspire us—a Gaelic word Maeve once whispered in a dream, a Latin root I’ve read in my encyclopedia—and say the resulting name out loud again and again until it sounds as beautiful as the flower looks.
questions.answer_ch: 每当梅芙和我想象一种新花时，我们首先会讨论它的故事——它是在月光下生长，还是在隐藏的岩洞深处？——这个故事告诉我们它需要什么颜色，因此如果它是由星光而生，我们会选择银蓝和浅紫，但如果它是日落花，我们会使用日落红、橙和金色。然后，在不做草图的情况下，梅芙将纱线扭曲成她脑海中看到的花瓣形状——长而尖像烛台，或者肥而钟形像灯笼——而我则拿着彩色铅笔在她的手上寻找完美的色调搭配。最后，我们通过融合激励我们的地方的音节来创造一个名字——一个梅芙在梦中曾低语的盖尔语词汇，一个我在百科全书中读过的拉丁词根——并不断大声朗读这个结果，直到它听起来和花的外观一样美丽。

questions.question_en: How do you comfort Maeve if she’s frustrated during a creative block—what strategies help her find inspiration again?
questions.question_ch: 如果梅芙在创意障碍期间感到沮丧，你怎么安慰她——哪些策略能帮助她再次找到灵感？
questions.answer_en: I’d first sit close to Maeve and quietly tell her I’ve seen her make the most wonderful yarn-flowers and that everyone—even me—hits a wall sometimes; then I’d suggest we both take a five-minute break by stepping outside to spot shapes in the clouds or listen to birdsong, because fresh air and nature almost always spark new ideas for her. If she still feels stuck, I’d hand her a sheet of paper, invite her to doodle without thinking of “making art,” maybe draw a spiral or a single petal over and over, or pick three random words like “river,” “lamp,” “whisper” and ask her to combine them into a tiny story or sketch. Finally I’d remind her that art isn’t about perfection but about discovery, so it’s fine to make something silly or small—often a playful start leads to real inspiration.
questions.answer_ch: 我会先坐在梅夫身边，悄悄告诉她我看到了她做出的最美妙的毛线花，每个人—甚至我自己—有时都会碰壁；然后我建议我们一起休息五分钟，出去看看云彩中的形状或听听鸟鸣，因为新鲜空气和大自然几乎总能激发她的新想法。如果她仍然感到困扰，我会递给她一张纸，邀请她随意涂鸦，不用考虑“创作艺术”，也许画个螺旋或反复画一片花瓣，或者选三个随机的词，比如“河”、“灯”、“低语”，让她把它们组合成一个小故事或草图。最后，我会提醒她，艺术不是关于完美，而是关于发现，所以制作一些傻乎乎或小巧的东西是完全可以的—通常一个有趣的开始会带来真正的灵感。

questions.question_en: What’s a favorite place you and Maeve go to draw or create—like a quiet park bench or a sunny window spot—and why is it special?
questions.question_ch: 你和梅维最喜欢去哪里画画或创作，比如一个安静的公园长椅或阳光明媚的窗边，那为什么对你们来说特别呢？
questions.answer_en: My favorite spot with Maeve was the old stone bench tucked beneath the magnolia tree in our school’s walled garden; we’d carry our sketchpads there after class and settle under the dappled light. The bench overlooked a curve in the little stream where dragonflies skimmed the surface and tadpoles clustered among the reeds, and its moss-clad backrest felt like a comfortable armchair. It was special because it felt like our own secret studio in nature: the air was always cool and fragrant, birdsong echoed around us, and each time we looked up from our drawings we discovered something new—a curling leaf, a sunbeam dancing on water, a heron’s shadow passing by—so our sketches felt alive with the garden’s quiet magic.
questions.answer_ch: 我和梅芙最喜欢的地方是我们学校围墙花园里那张藏在木兰树下的旧石长椅；我们总是在课后把素描本带到那里，坐在斑驳的光影下。长椅面朝小溪的弯道，蜻蜓在水面滑翔，蝌蚪在芦苇间聚集，苔藓覆盖的靠背感觉就像一把舒适的扶手椅。这个地方特别，因为它就像我们在自然中的秘密工作室：空气总是凉爽而芳香，鸟鸣在我们周围回荡，每次我们从素描中抬头时，总能发现一些新奇的事物——一片卷曲的叶子，一缕阳光在水面上跳舞，一只苍鹭的影子经过——让我们的素描充满了花园的宁静魔力。

questions.question_en: How do you and Maeve share and celebrate each other’s art—do you hold mini “exhibitions,” give compliments, or frame your favorite pieces?
questions.question_ch: 你和梅夫是如何分享和庆祝彼此的艺术的——你们会举办小型“展览”、互相赞美，还是把喜欢的作品装框？
questions.answer_en: Maeve and I have turned sharing art into one of our favorite rituals: whenever we finish a drawing or a little yarn-flower creation she made in arts club or a paint-splatter piece of mine, we bring them to my “gallery wall,” which is really just the stairwell wall at home where everyone takes turns adding new artwork. We don’t have a fancy frame most of the time, so we simply secure our pieces with colorful washi tape, step back and talk about what we notice—the way Maeve’s petals curl or how the colors in my splatters seem to dance. Sometimes we host an impromptu “exhibition” in Uncle Owen’s studio corner: we lay out our work on a low table, invite Alex or Gerald to be our audience, and take turns explaining our inspirations. When we’ve picked a favorite from each other’s stack, we do mount it on construction-paper mats and hang it above my desk, so it feels as special as a real gallery piece.
questions.answer_ch: 梅芙和我将分享艺术变成了我们最喜欢的仪式之一：每当我们完成一幅画，或者她在艺术俱乐部制作的小毛线花，或者我做的溅色作品时，我们就把它们带到我的“画廊墙”，其实就是家里楼梯的墙，大家轮流添加新的艺术作品。我们大多数时候没有 fancy 框架，所以我们用彩色的和纸胶带简单固定作品，然后后退一步，讨论我们注意到的细节——梅芙的花瓣是如何卷曲的，或者我作品中的颜色是如何跳舞的。有时候我们会在奥文叔叔的工作室角落举办即兴“展览”：我们把作品摆在一个低桌子上，邀请亚历克斯或杰拉德当我们的观众，轮流解释我们的灵感。当我们从对方的作品堆中挑选出一个最喜欢的时，我们会把它装在彩色纸垫上，然后挂在我的书桌上，这样就像真的画廊作品一样特别。

questions.question_en: After Sophie’s accident, what reflections did she share with you about safety or taking care of yourself?
questions.question_ch: 索菲的事故后，她和你分享了什么关于安全或照顾自己的反思？
questions.answer_en: Sophie told me that her accident taught her the hard way never to take even the simplest things for granted: she’d been rushing across the street without really looking, and paid the price with a broken wrist and a week in plaster. She said she now always stops at the curb and looks both ways, even if there’s no car in sight, and that wearing a bike helmet or fastening a seatbelt isn’t “over-cautious,” it’s simply common sense. She also spoke about listening to your body—how she’d ignored a twinge of pain in her arm until it turned into something serious—and how important it is to rest or ask for help rather than pushing on until you break. Sophie reminded me that taking care of yourself isn’t just about avoiding scrapes and bumps on the playground but about respecting your own limits, speaking up when you feel unwell, and never being too proud to admit you need a hand.
questions.answer_ch: 索菲告诉我，她的事故让我明白了一个道理：千万不要把即使是最简单的事情也视为理所当然。她曾在没有真正观察的情况下匆忙过马路，付出了代价，骨折了手腕，感到痛苦了一周。她说，现在每次走到路边时都会停下来看看两边，即使没车经过，而且佩戴自行车头盔或系上安全带并不是“过于谨慎”，而是常识。她还谈到了倾听自己的身体——她忽视了手臂的一阵疼痛，直到变得严重——以及休息或请求帮助的重要性，而不是强忍着直到崩溃。索菲提醒我，照顾自己不仅仅是为了避免在游乐场受伤，而是要尊重自己的极限，感到不适时要表达出来，以及永远不要因为自尊心而不敢承认自己需要帮助。

questions.question_en: How do you and Sophie bond as equals when she babysits you—what stories or games do you enjoy together?
questions.question_ch: 你和索菲在她照顾你时如何以平等的方式建立联系——你们喜欢一起分享什么故事或游戏？
questions.answer_en: Whenever Sophie babysits me, we really connect as equals by sharing games and conversations that bridge her psychology studies and my endless curiosity. We often start with a round of Rummikub or Snakes & Ladders at the kitchen table—she lets me teach her my favourite strategies—and then settle down with my “Big Questions from Little People” book, taking turns reading aloud and debating everything from “Why are we alive?” to “Do dreams have meaning?” Sometimes we set up a makeshift lab in the living room: Sophie measures ingredients while I lead us through a soap-making experiment or a simple baking recipe, then we taste the results and analyse how texture and flavour change. On quieter afternoons we sit on the sofa with my 10× binoculars and a notebook, swapping stories about odd dreams—she listens just like a friend, never talking down to me—and helps me sketch what I saw, like the “Light of the Elves” flower and my visits from Great-grandma Orla. We’ll also venture out to Hampstead Heath, racing to spot woodpeckers or testing new crossword clues in the grass, and she always asks thoughtful questions that make me feel truly understood. By the time Sophie leaves, I’ve learned something new about myself, and she’s picked up a few wild-but-true facts about beetles and dreams—just two pals exploring the world together.
questions.answer_ch: 每当苏菲照顾我时，我们通过分享游戏和对话真的建立了平等的联系，这些对话既涉及她的心理学研究，又满足了我无尽的好奇心。我们通常会在厨房桌子旁开始一轮拉米牌或者蛇和梯子——她让我教她我最喜欢的策略——然后坐下来一起阅读我的《小朋友的大问题》书籍，轮流大声朗读，并讨论从“我们为什么活着？”到“梦有意义吗？”的各种问题。有时我们会在客厅里搭建一个临时实验室：苏菲负责称量材料，而我则带领我们进行制作香皂的实验或简单的烘焙食谱，然后我们品尝结果，分析质地和味道的变化。在安静的下午，我们坐在沙发上，拿着我的10倍望远镜和一本笔记本，互相讲述奇怪的梦境——她像朋友一样倾听，从不对我居高临下——还帮助我草绘我所看到的东西，比如“精灵之光”花和我与曾祖母奥尔拉的相遇。我们还会出去到汉普斯特德公园，比赛寻找啄木鸟，或者在草地上测试新的填字游戏线索，她总是提出深思熟虑的问题，让我感受到被真正理解。等苏菲离开时，我对自己又有了新的认识，而她也学到了关于甲虫和梦的一些奇妙但真实的事实——就像两个朋友一起探索世界。

questions.question_en: What’s the most interesting thing Sophie has taught you about psychology so far, and how did you apply it when talking about your feelings?
questions.question_ch: 索菲迄今为止教给你关于心理学的最有趣的事情是什么？你是如何在谈论你的感受时运用它的？
questions.answer_en: The most interesting thing Sophie taught me was that naming a feeling actually makes it less confusing and overwhelming—she said feelings are like wild animals you can’t chase if you don’t know their names. She showed me how to pause, ask myself exactly “What am I feeling?” and then say it out loud in an “I feel …” sentence instead of just letting the emotion swirl around inside me. I first used this when I couldn’t shake that strange boredom; I told Sophie, “I feel restless and a bit lost,” and just hearing myself say it helped me see what was really going on. Later, when I finally told Mum and Dad about Hassel, I said, “I feel excited and nervous,” and because I’d named those feelings clearly, they listened more calmly and understood me better.
questions.answer_ch: 索菲教给我的最有趣的事情是，给一种感觉命名实际上会让它变得不那么令人困惑和压倒——她说，感觉就像野生动物，如果你不知道它们的名字，就无法追逐它们。她教我如何暂停，问自己“我在感觉什么？”然后用“我感到……的句子”大声说出来，而不是让情绪在我内心盘旋。我第一次用这个方法时，无法摆脱那种奇怪的无聊感；我告诉索菲：“我感到不安和有些迷失。”光是听到自己这样说，帮我看清楚了真正发生的事情。后来，当我终于告诉妈妈和爸爸关于哈塞尔的事时，我说：“我感到兴奋和紧张，”因为我清晰地命名了这些感觉，他们更冷静地倾听了我，更好地理解了我。

questions.question_en: How do you and Leslie challenge each other in math or kite flying, and what was the hardest kite design you both tried?
questions.question_ch: 你和莱斯利在数学或放风筝方面是如何相互挑战的，你们尝试过的最困难的风筝设计是什么？
questions.answer_en: Whenever Leslie and I paired up, our friendly rivalry usually took two forms: in math, we’d sneak off after school to his desk and trade puzzles—he’d challenge me to mental multiplication of three‐digit numbers in under ten seconds, and I’d fire back with geometry riddles, like asking him to prove why the angles in a pentagon’s star add up to 180 degrees; sometimes we’d even devise our own little “Olympiad” problems, scribbling them on scrap paper and timing each other as we raced to solutions. In kite flying, we treated the wide expanse of Hampstead Heath like our laboratory—Leslie would tinker with tails and bridle points on his traditional swallow kite to see how many loops it could hold before spinning out, while I experimented with varying spine lengths and crossbars. The hardest design we ever tackled together was a self-supporting, six-cell box kite made of carbon dowels and ultralight ripstop nylon; every cell had to be perfectly square and the frames aligned to millimeter precision or the whole thing twisted in the wind. We spent an entire afternoon fitting each strut at exactly a ninety-degree angle, then pinning the panels with reinforced tape—when we finally launched it in a brisk north wind and saw it lift straight into the sky without another twitch, the pride we felt was as big as the kite itself.
questions.answer_ch: 每当莱斯利和我搭档时，我们的友好竞争通常有两种形式：在数学上，我们会在放学后偷偷去他桌子旁交换谜题——他会挑战我在十秒内进行三位数的心算乘法，而我则用几何谜语反击，比如问他为什么五角星的角度加起来是180度；有时我们甚至会设计自己的“小奥林匹克”问题，在废纸上潦草书写，并相互计时比赛解答。在放风筝时，我们把汉普斯特德希斯的宽阔空地当作我们的实验室——莱斯利会调试他传统的燕子风筝上的尾巴和缰绳点，看看能在翻转之前保持多少圈，而我则尝试不同的脊长度和横梁。我们一起处理过的最困难的设计是一个自支撑的六格箱形风筝，由碳棒和超轻撕裂防止尼龙制成；每个格子都必须完全是正方形，框架对齐到毫米精度，否则整个风筝在风中就会扭曲。我们花了整整一个下午将每根支柱准确地固定在九十度角，然后用增强胶带固定面板——当我们最终在一阵北风中放飞它，看到它直直升入天空而不再颤动时，我们的自豪感就像风筝本身一样巨大。

questions.question_en: When you work on homework together, what tips does Leslie give you to excel at math while still having fun?
questions.question_ch: 当你和莱斯利一起做作业时，她给你哪些建议让你在数学上表现出色，同时又能玩得开心？
questions.answer_en: When Leslie and I tackled our math homework side by side, he always reminded me that numbers are just another kind of puzzle and that solving them could be as much fun as flying a kite or inventing a game. He urged me to look for patterns first—if adding 7 + 8 felt tricky, he’d say “Watch how 7 + 7 works, then just add one more!”—and to color-code steps with different pencils so I could track my reasoning. He turned long multiplication into a race against the clock, suggesting we time ourselves with a timer and try to beat our previous record instead of stressing about mistakes. When geometry tripped me up, he encouraged me to draw the shapes physically with sticks or string, to see them with my hands. And whenever I got stuck, Leslie would propose we invent a short story around the problem—“If two knights collect apples from 8 trees each, how many apples altogether?”—so I was thinking about dragons and orchards instead of feeling anxious. By turning every exercise into a playful challenge and breaking problems into small, colorful, real-world steps, Leslie helped me see that math wasn’t just right or wrong but a series of adventures to enjoy.
questions.answer_ch: 当莱斯利和我并肩解决数学作业时，他总是提醒我，数字只是一种拼图，解它们和放风筝或发明游戏一样有趣。他鼓励我先寻找模式——如果加7 + 8感觉棘手，他会说“看看7 + 7是怎么回事，然后再加一个！”——并用不同的铅笔给步骤上色，以便我能跟踪我的推理。他把长乘法变成了一场与时间的比赛，建议我们用定时器计时，尝试打破之前的记录，而不是因为错误而感到压力。当几何让我感到困惑时，他鼓励我用棍子或绳子实际绘制形状，让我的手去感知它们。每当我陷入困境，莱斯利就会提议我们围绕这个问题编一个简短的故事——“如果两个骑士从8棵树上各自收集苹果，总共有多少个苹果？”——这样我就在想龙和果园，而不是感到焦虑。通过把每个练习变成一种有趣的挑战，把问题分解成小而丰富多彩的现实步骤，莱斯利帮助我看到数学不仅仅是对与错，而是一系列值得享受的冒险。

questions.question_en: How do you and Leslie balance being studious but still friendly—what activities do you enjoy outside of class?
questions.question_ch: 你和莱斯利怎么平衡认真学习和友好相处——你们在课外喜欢哪些活动？
questions.answer_en: Leslie and I always made a point of finishing our homework side by side before indulging in any play. We quizzed each other on spelling or mental arithmetic until our brains tingled, then we’d head out together. I remember one Tuesday we raced to Hampstead Heath with our kites—his graceful swallow design against my colourful delta—then collapsed on the grass to watch clouds drift by and compare Latin names of dragonfly species in my notebook. On another afternoon we’d meet at my house for Rummikub tournaments, with hot soda crackers on the side, or we’d experiment in my kitchen, whipping up soap with coffee grounds or attempting bread recipes from my Iranian cookbook. Weekends often meant early birdwatching sessions with my 10× binoculars, spotting robins and sparrowhawks, or museum trips where we’d pore over dinosaur bones and fossils until closing time. By weaving short bursts of shared discovery and simple fun between study sessions, we kept both our grades and our friendship strong.
questions.answer_ch: 莱斯莉和我总是坚持在一起完成作业，然后再去玩。我们互相考拼写或者心算，直到脑袋发麻，然后一起出门。我记得有一个星期二，我们带着风筝比赛去汉普斯特德希斯——他的优雅燕子设计和我色彩斑斓的三角风筝——然后瘫倒在草地上，看着云朵飘过，对比我笔记本里蜻蜓物种的拉丁名称。在另一个下午，我们会在我家聚会，举行 Rummikub 比赛，旁边还备有热苏打饼干，或者我们会在我的厨房里实验，用咖啡渣制作香皂，或者尝试我伊朗食谱里的面包食谱。周末通常意味着提早去观察鸟类，用我 10 倍的望远镜观察知更鸟和雀鹰，或者去博物馆，直到闭馆时我们才会仔细研究恐龙骨骼和化石。通过在学习期间穿插短暂的共享发现和简单的乐趣，我们保持了优异的成绩和牢固的友谊。

questions.question_en: What’s the best game you and Alex have played together when he visits, and how do you teach him to follow the rules?
questions.question_ch: 你和亚历克斯一起玩的最好游戏是什么？他来访时你是 怎么教他遵守规则的？
questions.answer_en: The best game Alex and I ever played together was Rummikub; one rainy afternoon he came over and we cleared the dining table, mixed the colorful tiles and each took our rack. I taught him by first showing a simple “run” of three consecutive numbers and then asking him to copy it, praising him when he got it right. Whenever he tried to bend a rule or hesitated about drawing a tile, I paused and quietly reminded him that melds must have at least three tiles and that if you can’t play, you must draw. I even jotted the key steps on a scrap of paper—“lay three or more in sequence or matching numbers,” “draw if you can’t play,” “take turns in order”—and kept it by his side. I explained that the real fun was in rearranging the table together, but it only worked if we both followed the same rules, and that fairness is as important as winning. He caught on quickly, grinned when he emptied his rack first, and we both felt that little thrill of playing by the book and still outsmarting each other.
questions.answer_ch: 亚历克斯和我一起玩的最好的游戏是拉米拼图；一个雨天的下午，他来我家，我们清理了餐桌，混合了五彩斑斓的牌，并各自拿了一个架子。我先教他展示一个简单的“三个连续数字的顺子”，然后让我他模仿，当他做对时，我会赞扬他。每当他试图违反规则或犹豫是否该抽牌时，我会停下来，安静地提醒他，组牌必须至少有三张牌，如果不能出牌，就必须抽牌。我甚至在一张纸的边角上写下了关键步骤——“排列三张或更多的连续数字或相同数字”，“如果不能出牌就抽牌”，“按顺序轮流出牌”——并把它放在他身边。我解释说，真正的乐趣在于我们一起重新排列桌子，但这只有在我们都遵循相同规则时才有效，公平和胜利一样重要。他很快就明白了，当他第一个清空了架子时，露出了笑容，我们都感到那种遵循规则却仍然能智胜对方的刺激。

questions.question_en: When Alex first learned to skateboard or ride a bike, how did you help him feel confident and safe?
questions.question_ch: 当亚历克斯第一次学滑板或骑自行车时，你是如何帮助他感到自信和安全的？
questions.answer_en: I remember the first time Alex clambered onto his skateboard in the park—his legs wobbled so badly I thought he’d topple immediately—so I knelt by his side and showed him exactly where to place his feet, then held his shoulder lightly as he pushed off. I reminded him to bend his knees like a spring and to keep his eyes on the path ahead, not on the pavement. When we switched to his bicycle a few weeks later, I borrowed my helmet and knee pads for him and ran alongside, barely touching the back of his saddle to steady him while he pedaled. Every time he veered or slowed, I’d cheer, “You’ve got this!” and let him feel he was doing it alone as soon as he found his balance. After each short ride I celebrated his smallest success—a wobble-free meter, a confident push—and soon he was zooming off on his own, his grin brighter than the afternoon sun.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得第一次亚历克斯在公园里爬上滑板的时候——他的腿摇摇晃晃的，我以为他会立刻摔倒——于是我跪在他身边，告诉他脚该放在哪里，然后轻轻握住他的肩膀，当他推开滑板时。我提醒他要像弹簧一样弯曲膝盖，并且要把目光放在前方的道路上，而不是地面上。几周后我们换成了他的自行车，我借来了我的头盔和护膝，陪在旁边，轻轻碰一下他的鞍座以保持他的平衡。当他偏移或减速时，我都会鼓励他说：“你可以的！”一旦他找到了平衡，我就让他感受到自己是在独自骑行。在每次短途骑行后，我都会为他最小的成功庆祝——无摇晃的一米，充满自信的一推——很快他就能自己飞驰而去，笑容比午后的阳光还要明亮。

questions.question_en: What stories does Alex like to hear about your family’s history, and how do you explain older relatives to him?
questions.question_ch: Alex喜欢听你们家庭历史中的哪些故事？你是如何向他介绍年长的亲戚？
questions.answer_en: Alex especially loves the tales of our great-grandmother Orla, the Irish “witch” who wandered the countryside talking to trees and whose hand-woven lace gift still drapes our fireplace; he laughs whenever I reenact how she once floated up to the ceiling to chide me back to my cradle. He also can’t get enough of Grandpa George and Grandma Grace’s story—how Grandpa won her heart with his middle name Patrick and their lifelong “G-name game,” and how they moved from the suburbs back to the Cotswolds so Papa could retire among the oaks. To explain each older relative, I draw a simple family tree on a scrap of paper, point to a photo or heirloom—Grandpa’s war-era pocket watch, Aunt Irene’s marine-biology field notebook, Uncle Owen’s carved deer sculpture—and tell Alex what made them special: their quirks, their work, the adventures that shaped them. I remind him these aren’t just names but real people who laughed, struggled, dreamed and became the links that connect us all.
questions.answer_ch: 亚历克斯特别喜欢听我们的曾祖母奥拉的故事。她是个被称作“女巫”的爱尔兰人，漫游乡间与树木交谈，那件她亲手织的蕾丝礼物至今还挂在壁炉上；每当我重演她飘到天花板上把我“训”回摇篮的样子时，他就笑个不停。他还听不够乔治爷爷和格雷斯奶奶的故事——爷爷用中间名帕特里克赢得了奶奶的心，他们还玩了一个终身的“G字游戏”，后来他们从郊区搬回科茨沃尔德，让爷爷可以在橡树丛中安享退休生活。为了给他讲每位长辈，我会在一张纸片上画一个简单的家谱，指着照片或传家宝——爷爷战争时期的怀表、艾琳阿姨的海洋生物学野外笔记本、欧文叔叔雕刻的鹿像——告诉亚历克斯他们的特别之处：性格特点、工作经历、塑造他们的冒险。我提醒他，这些不仅仅是名字，而是真实的人，他们曾欢笑、奋斗、追梦，正是他们串起了我们的血脉。

questions.question_en: What games do you and Margo play when Luthien invites her over, and how do you all decide on which activity to try next?
questions.question_ch: 当露西恩邀请她过来时，你和玛戈会玩什么游戏？你们如何决定下一个要尝试的活动？
questions.answer_en: I remember whenever Luthien invited Margo over, the three of us would often start by pulling out our favorite board games—Rummikub and Snakes & Ladders were our go-tos, but we’d also play Scrabble or Uno if we felt like practicing words. If the sky was clear, we’d grab a kite and head down to Hampstead Heath or the little garden to fly it, then chase each other in games of tag or hide-and-seek. To decide what to try next, we took turns suggesting an activity—each of us named one thing we wanted to do, then we’d vote with a thumbs-up for our favorite idea. Whoever’s choice got the most votes would win, and if there was a tie, we’d write our ideas on bits of paper and draw one out of a hat. It always felt fair, and it meant every play session was full of surprises and laughter.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得每当Luthien邀请Margo过来，我们三个人通常都会先拿出最喜欢的棋盘游戏——拉密和飞行棋是我们的首选，但如果想练习单词，我们也会玩拼字游戏或UNO牌。若天气晴朗，我们就带着风筝去汉普斯特德荒野公园或小花园放风筝，然后玩捉人游戏或捉迷藏。至于接下来要做什么，我们会轮流提议活动——每人说出一件想做的事，然后用竖大拇指投票选出最喜欢的点子。票数最多的获胜，如果出现平局，我们就把想法写在小纸条上，从帽子里抽签决定。这样总让人觉得很公平，也使每次游戏时光都充满惊喜和欢笑。

questions.question_en: How does Margo react when Luthien pushes her—what do you say to help both of them stay friends afterward?
questions.question_ch: 当露西恩推了玛戈一把时，玛戈是如何反应的——你会说些什么来帮助她们俩之后保持友谊？
questions.answer_en: Margo’s eyes widened and her bottom lip trembled when Luthien’s shove knocked her off balance; she stumbled, planted a hand on the ground, then looked up at Luthien with a hurt expression but didn’t burst into tears. I knelt between them and said, “Luthien, that push surprised Margo and it hurt her. Would you please tell her you’re sorry?” Luthien’s shoulders slumped, and she whispered, “I’m sorry, Margo,” while Margo nodded and gave her a small, forgiving smile. Then I added, “It takes real bravery to say sorry, and Margo, thank you for giving Luthien another chance. Friends stick together even when they make mistakes.” That little speech made them both relax, and soon they were giggling again, hand in hand.
questions.answer_ch: Margo的眼睛睁得大大的，下唇微微颤抖。Luthien的一推让她失去平衡，她踉跄了一下，手撑在地上，然后抬头看向Luthien，脸上带着受伤的表情，却没有哭出来。我跪在她们中间，说：“Luthien，那一下推得Margo很突然，也让她很疼。你能跟她说声对不起吗？”Luthien耷拉着肩膀，低声道：“对不起，Margo。”Margo点了点头，给了她一个小小的、宽容的笑容。然后我接着说：“能说对不起才是真正的勇气，Margo，谢谢你再给Luthien一次机会。朋友即使犯错也要彼此相伴。”这番话让她们都放松下来，不久便手拉手又咯咯地笑了起来。

questions.question_en: What’s something funny Margo said or did during your last playdate, and how did everyone laugh together?
questions.question_ch: 在你们上一次玩耍时，玛戈说了或做了什么有趣的事？大家是怎么一起笑的？
questions.answer_en: Last Saturday at Hampstead Heath, Margo found a stray ice lolly stick on the grass, held it aloft like a “unicorn horn,” and solemnly declared we must bow and chant “All hail the mighty horn!” as if it were enchanted. Luthien howled with giggles, Gerald tried to kneel so hard he tumbled off the bench, and I cracked up so badly my sides ached. We ended up in a giggling heap, our laughter echoing across the park until even the squirrels looked over in surprise.
questions.answer_ch: 上周六在汉普斯特德希思，玛戈在草地上捡到一根被遗弃的冰棍棍子，把它高高举起，像“独角兽的角”一样，庄严地宣布我们必须向它鞠躬并齐声呼喊“向强大的角致敬！”，仿佛它被施了魔法。卢西恩咯咯笑着放声大叫，杰拉尔德拼命想跪下，结果从长凳上摔了下来，我笑得肚子都疼了。最后我们笑成一堆，笑声在公园回荡，连松鼠都惊讶地探过头来看。

questions.question_en: When James visits, how do you and Gerald’s older brother decide which sport to play, and what makes it fun for both of you?
questions.question_ch: 当詹姆斯来访时，你和杰拉德的哥哥如何决定要玩哪项运动？是什么让你们俩都觉得好玩？
questions.answer_en: When James came over last Saturday, Gerald’s older brother and I each named our favourite sport—he chose cricket and Gerald picked football—so we settled it with rock-paper-scissors. Cricket won, so we set up stumps in the garden and used Gerald’s cricket bat. What made it so much fun was that James, although younger, swung the bat nearly as hard as Gerald and me; every time someone missed the ball we all burst out laughing, Dad cheered “Well bowled!” from the fence, and even when the ball landed in Mrs. Wong’s flowerbed we treated it like part of the game. Passing the bat to James, watching him beam when he finally hit a boundary, and Gerald lifting him up in celebration reminded me that it wasn’t about who was best but about playing together and sharing those silly, loud moments under the sun.
questions.answer_ch: 上周六詹姆斯来我们家时，杰拉尔德的哥哥和我各自说出最喜欢的运动——他选板球，杰拉尔德选足球——于是我们用猜拳决定。板球赢了，我们就在花园里架起球柱，拿出杰拉尔德的板球棒。最有趣的是，虽然詹姆斯年纪更小，但他挥棒的力道几乎跟我和杰拉尔德一样大；每次有人挥空我们都会笑得前仰后合，爸爸在篱笆后大喊“投得好！”。即使球落在黄太太的花坛里，我们也当作游戏的一部分。把球棒递给詹姆斯，看他终于打出界外球时满脸笑容，杰拉尔德把他高高举起庆祝，让我想起这游戏不在于谁最厉害，而是一起玩耍，共享那些蠢萌又热闹的阳光时光。

questions.question_en: What advice has James given you about school or sports, and how do you put that advice into action during your games?
questions.question_ch: James给你有关学校或运动方面的什么建议？在你的比赛中，你如何将这些建议付诸行动？
questions.answer_en: James Thompson once pulled me aside after football practice and said, “Isaac, the hardest thing is not the first kick but the next one—never let a mistake distract you.” He reminded me to treat every pass or shot as a fresh start. So during games I’ve learned to shake off a poor touch or a missed goal by turning my head, taking a deep breath, and refocusing on the ball instead of replaying the error in my mind. In school he gives similar advice about tests—don’t panic if you get one question wrong; move on and tackle the next one calmly. I put that into action by underlining key words in exam questions and checking my answers quickly before moving on.
questions.answer_ch: 詹姆斯·汤普森曾在足球训练后把我拉到一边，说：“艾萨克，最难的不是第一次射门，而是下一次——永远不要让一次失误分散你的注意力。”他提醒我要把每一次传球或射门都当作新的开始。所以在比赛中，我学会了在脚法不好或错过进球后，转过头来，深吸一口气，把注意力重新集中到球上，而不是在脑海中不停回放那次失误。在学校里，他对考试也有类似的建议——如果答错了一道题，不要慌张，继续往下做，冷静应对下一题。我将这点付诸实践：在考试题目中画出关键词，并在继续做题前快速检查自己的答案。

questions.question_en: How do you and James handle disagreements when you both want to use the same video game or toy?
questions.question_ch: 当你和詹姆斯都想玩同一个电子游戏或玩具时，你们如何处理分歧？
questions.answer_en: When James and I both want the same game or toy, we first tell each other how important it is—“I really need to finish this level” or “I promised I’d build that next tower.” Then we try to find a fair solution: sometimes we set a timer for ten or fifteen minutes each, or we play rock-paper-scissors to see who goes first today. If neither of us is happy, we suggest taking turns tomorrow instead and doing something else together now—like drawing or telling stories. If we still can’t agree, we ask Dad or Mum to help, and they usually remind us that sharing gives us more chances to play together in the long run. By speaking calmly about what we want and listening to each other, we usually end up both feeling that the solution is fair.
questions.answer_ch: 当我和James都想要同一个游戏或玩具时，我们先告诉对方这对自己有多重要——“我真的需要通关这关”或者“我答应过要建下一个塔”。然后我们尽量找到一个公平的解决方案：有时我们会给彼此设定十到十五分钟的计时器，或者今天用石头剪刀布决定谁先玩。如果我们都不满意，就建议改天轮流玩，现在一起做别的事情——比如画画或讲故事。如果还是无法达成一致，就请爸爸或妈妈帮忙，他们通常会提醒我们，共享能让我们长远来看有更多机会一起玩。通过平静地表达自己的需求并倾听对方，我们通常都会觉得这个解决方案很公平。

questions.question_en: What is Henry’s favorite toy or game when he visits, and how do you help him feel included when he’s younger?
questions.question_ch: 亨利来访时最喜欢的玩具或游戏是什么？当他年幼时，你如何帮助他感到被接纳？
questions.answer_en: Henry’s favorite toy when he visits is my wooden train set—he lights up the moment he sees the green engine and its little carriages. Because he’s still only three, I always crouch down to his level, hand him the chunky track pieces he can grip, and cheer him on as he clicks the engine onto the rails. When the carriages come loose I don’t swoop in and rebuild the whole line; instead I gently guide his hands to snap them back together so he feels proud of his own work. Then we push the train round and round together, laughing whenever it chuffs off at full speed. By giving him simple jobs, speaking in a cheerful but patient voice and making sure he “drives” the engine himself, I help Henry feel included every time he visits—even when he’s younger than everyone else.
questions.answer_ch: 亨利来访时最喜欢的玩具是我的木质火车套装——当他看到绿色机车和小车厢时，他立刻兴奋起来。因为他才三岁，我总是蹲下来与他平视，把他能抓得住的粗大轨道块递给他，并在他把机车扣到轨道上时为他加油。当车厢松动时，我不会冲上前去重建整列车，而是轻轻引导他的手把车厢重新扣好，让他为自己的成果感到自豪。然后我们一起推着火车绕圈跑，每当它“轰隆”全速驶过，我们就笑个不停。通过给他简单的任务、用愉快而耐心的语气交流，并确保他自己“驾驶”机车，我让亨利每次来访都能感受到被接纳——即使他比其他人都小。

questions.question_en: How do you keep Henry entertained when your mom’s friend brings him over, especially since he’s just a toddler?
questions.question_ch: 当你妈妈的朋友带亨利过来时，尤其他还只是个幼儿，你如何让他保持愉快？
questions.answer_en: I usually invited Henry into our art corner, spread a big blanket on the floor and gave him sturdy wooden blocks and chunky crayons so he could build towers and make bright scribbles without worrying about spills. I’d blow bubbles for him in the garden—he’d chase them under the apple tree, shrieking with delight—and let him peek at our parakeets through the aviary glass while I crumbled soda crackers for them to nibble. If the weather was fair, I guided him on a “treasure hunt” around the yard, pointing out smooth pebbles, big oak leaves and curious insects through my magnifier. Back inside, I read him board books about animals—his favorite was Maisy’s adventures—and we tapped out simple rhythms on the cajón drum in Irvin’s studio, where the low boom always made him laugh. By offering gentle, hands-on play and little moments with living creatures, Henry stayed happily busy even though he’s only two.
questions.answer_ch: 我通常会把亨利请到我们的艺术角，铺上一条大毯子在地板上，给他结实的木块和粗壮的蜡笔，这样他就可以搭建积木塔，涂涂画画，不用担心弄洒。我会在花园里给他吹泡泡——他在苹果树下追着泡泡跑，兴奋得尖叫——然后让他透过鸟舍的玻璃看我们的牡丹鹦鹉，我在旁边掰碎苏打饼干让鸟儿啄食。如果天气晴朗，我就带他在院子里进行“寻宝游戏”，用放大镜给他指认光滑的小鹅卵石、大橡树叶和奇特的小昆虫。回到室内，我会给他读关于动物的硬壳书——他最喜欢梅西的冒险故事——然后我们会在欧文的工作室里用箱鼓敲出简单的节奏，那个低沉的嗡鸣总是让他开怀大笑。通过这些温柔的、动手的游戏和与小动物相伴的时刻，尽管亨利只有两岁，他也能快乐地忙碌起来。

questions.question_en: What funny thing did Henry do last time he was here that made everyone smile?
questions.question_ch: 上次亨利在这里做了什么有趣的事情，让大家都笑了？
questions.answer_en: Last time Henry was here he toddled into the kitchen and decided to “help” make breakfast.
