He confidently picked up an egg, smashed it on the edge of the bowl—only for the yolk to dribble down his cheek and land in his hair. Then, without missing a beat, he tapped the empty shell on his head like a little hard-hat, looked around to make sure everyone saw, and gave us the proudest grin. We all cracked up at his impromptu egg-helmet—he paused as if waiting for applause—then went right back to “cooking.”
questions.answer_ch: 上次亨利在这儿，他蹒跚地走进厨房，决定“帮忙”做早餐。他自信地拿起一个鸡蛋，把它砸在碗沿上，结果蛋黄顺着他脸颊往下滑，还滴到头发上。然后，他毫不犹豫地把空蛋壳敲在头上，就像戴了个小安全帽，环顾四周确认大家都看见了，然后露出得意洋洋的笑容。我们都被他即兴的“蛋盔”逗得哈哈大笑——他好像在等掌声——接着又继续“做饭”了。

questions.question_en: What do you and Hal do when he visits—do you play outdoor games or show him your favorite backyard spots?
questions.question_ch: 当哈尔来访时，你们会做什么——是玩户外游戏，还是带他参观你最喜欢的后院景点？
questions.answer_en: When Hal comes over, we never sit still for long indoors—instead, we launch into a mix of backyard adventures and spontaneous games. Sometimes we’ll race each other barefoot across the lawn, then dive into a hide-and-seek contest among our neatly stacked woodpile and the old oak tree. Other times we’ll haul out our trusty kite, chase it down a gentle slope till it catches the breeze, then collapse on the grass and watch clouds drift by as we snack on soda crackers. When we need a quieter moment, I guide him to my secret bug-hotel under the hedge, where we peer through my magnifier at ladybirds and ground beetles, or we curl up in the hammock strung between the apple tree’s gnarled limbs and flip through my insect field guide. Whether we’re shrieking with delight over a perfect kite launch or whispering in the shade about which caterpillar might turn into a peacock butterfly, it’s always a little journey of discovery right in my own backyard.
questions.answer_ch: 当哈尔过来的时候，我们从不在室内待着不动——取而代之的是后院的各种探险和即兴游戏。有时我们会赤脚在草坪上比赛跑步，然后在整齐堆放的柴堆和那棵老橡树之间来一场捉迷藏。有时我们会拿出可靠的风筝，在缓坡上追着它跑，直到它迎风飞起，然后倒在草地上，一边看云朵飘过，一边吃苏打饼干。需要安静的时候，我就带他去树篱下我的秘密虫子旅馆，我们用放大镜观察瓢虫和步甲，或者躺在绑在苹果树扭曲树枝间的吊床上，翻看我的昆虫图鉴。无论是为一次完美的放风筝欢呼，还是在树荫下低声讨论哪条毛虫会变成孔雀蝶，我们的每一次相聚，总是在自家后院进行一次小小的发现之旅。

questions.question_en: How do you teach Hal about taking turns and sharing when you both want to play with the same toy?
questions.question_ch: 当你们都想玩同一个玩具时，你如何教哈尔学会轮流和分享？
questions.answer_en: I learned that the best way was to treat it like a little science experiment: first I’d tell Hal, “I really want the red car, and I know you do too,” to show I understood how he felt. Then we’d agree on a rule—often using my timer—I’d set it for two minutes and say, “I’ll race it first, then I’ll hand it to you when the timer beeps,” so it felt fair and precise. If he grew impatient, I’d offer him a different toy while he waited and praise him when he did wait: “You’re doing a great job sharing, Hal, thank you!” After he’d had his turn, I’d ask him, “Did you enjoy that? Now it’s my turn again,” keeping our agreement clear. Soon he saw that waiting brought fun, and sharing meant we could both play longer.
questions.answer_ch: 我发现，最好的方法就是把它当成一个小型的科学实验：一开始，我会对哈尔说，“我真的很想玩那辆红色小车，我知道你也很想玩”，这样能让他知道我理解他的感受。然后我们会制定一个规则——我常用我的计时器——我会把时间设定为两分钟，并说，“我先比赛两分钟，计时器响了我就把车交给你”，让规则既公平又精准。如果他等不及了，我就给他准备另一个玩具让他先玩，并在他耐心等待后表扬他：“哈尔，你在分享这块做得很好，谢谢你！”等他玩完后，我会问他，“你玩得开心吗？现在轮到我了”，这样我们对规则的约定就很清楚了。很快他就明白了，等待也可以很有趣，分享让我们能一起玩得更久。

questions.question_en: What’s something Hal said or asked that surprised you, and how did you answer him?
questions.question_ch: Hal说了什么或问了什么让你感到惊讶？你是如何回答他的？
questions.answer_en: One afternoon on the bus Hal suddenly leaned over and said, “Being a doctor isn’t really a profession, is it?” I was so surprised I nearly dropped my binoculars. I’d always thought “doctor” was a clear, grown-up job, but Hal’s question made me pause. I told her that to me a doctor wasn’t just any job—it was someone who used science and care to help people heal, and that’s exactly the kind of work I want to do. I said I believed it’s more than a profession— it’s a calling.
questions.answer_ch: 一天午后，在公交车上，Hal突然凑过来问道：“当医生并不是真正的职业，对吧？”我惊得差点把望远镜掉了。我一直以为“医生”是个明确而成熟的职业，可Hal的问题让我停了下来。我告诉她，对我来说，医生不仅仅是一份工作——那是用科学和关怀来帮助人们康复的人，而这正是我想做的工作。我说我相信这不仅仅是一种职业，而是一种使命。

questions.question_en: What animals do you and David like to watch together at the zoo, and what facts did you learn from him about those creatures?
questions.question_ch: 你和大卫在动物园里喜欢一起观看哪些动物？你从他那里学到了关于这些动物的哪些知识？
questions.answer_en: David and I always gravitate to the Asian lion enclosure, where we’ll stand for ages watching their slow, powerful stride and listening to their low roars. David taught me that Asiatic lions are critically endangered—there are fewer than 600 of them left in India’s Gir Forest—and that they live in tighter‐knit prides of only six to eight lions, compared with their African cousins. After the lions we head to the meerkat habitat: David explained how meerkats take turns as “sentries,” perching on their hind legs to scan for eagles and jackals while the rest of the mob forages, and how their warning chirps differ subtly depending on the kind of danger. Hearing how these small creatures rely on teamwork and precise calls makes the whole zoo feel alive in a new way.
questions.answer_ch: 我和大卫总是被亚洲狮园吸引，我们会在那儿站很久，看它们缓慢而有力的步伐，听它们低沉的吼声。大卫告诉我，亚洲狮已濒临灭绝——印度吉尔森林里不到600只——而且它们的狮群比非洲狮要紧密，只由六到八只组成。看完狮子后，我们就去猫鼬栖息地：大卫解释说猫鼬会轮流做“哨兵”，它们直立在后腿上，为觅食的同伴警戒老鹰和豺狼，而且它们的警告啁啾声会根据不同危险微妙变化。听到这些小生物如何靠团队合作和精准的叫声，让整个动物园在我眼中焕然一新。

questions.question_en: How does David help you feed or care for zoo animals during your visits, and what did you discover about their habitats?
questions.question_ch: 大卫在你参观动物园时如何帮助你喂养或照顾动物？你对它们的栖息地有什么发现？
questions.answer_en: On my last zoo visit David led me into the keeper’s area and lent me his gloves and bucket so I could help scatter chopped carrots for the pygmy goats, showing me how to break the carrots into safe, bite-size pieces and space them so each goat could feed without jostling. He then took me to the reptile house where we topped up the iguanas’ water bowls, wiped their heated logs, and dusted their mealworms with calcium powder, explaining that these lizards come from sun-drenched tropical forests and need warm, humid enclosures with UV-lamps, misted bark and climbing branches. Through these tasks I discovered that each species needs its own habitat recreated—from rocky, grass-strewn hills for goats to humid, bark-strewn rainforests for iguanas—and that feeding and caring for them means paying careful attention to those habitat details.
questions.answer_ch: 在我上次参观动物园时，大卫带我进入饲养员的工作区，借给我他的手套和水桶，让我帮忙把切碎的胡萝卜撒给侏儒山羊吃，并教我如何将胡萝卜掰成安全的一口大小、均匀分布，以免山羊因争抢而推搡。随后他带我去了爬行动物馆，我们给鬣蜥的水碗加水，擦拭它们的加热木桩，并在它们的虫食上撒上钙粉。他一边解释说，这些蜥蜴来自阳光充足的热带雨林，需要带紫外线灯、喷雾树皮和攀爬枝条的温暖潮湿环境。通过这些任务，我发现每个物种都需要重现各自的栖息地——从布满岩石和青草的山坡到布满树皮的潮湿雨林——而给它们喂食和护理则意味着要仔细关注这些栖息地的细节。

questions.question_en: What game or activity do you and David enjoy doing after visiting the animals, and how did that become a tradition?
questions.question_ch: 参观完动物之后，你和大卫喜欢玩什么游戏或进行什么活动？这个习惯是如何形成的？
questions.answer_en: After we’ve spent the morning at the zoo watching the lions and giraffes, David and I always duck into the little café by the gate, order hot chocolate and cookies, and set up a game of Snakes & Ladders. It became our ritual the very first time we met—there was a sudden downpour, the café only had one board game on the shelf, and to pass the time we gave it a try. We laughed so hard at how often our pieces slid down a snake that it just stuck. Now whenever we leave the animals behind, we can’t wait to roll the dice and see who climbs the ladders first.
questions.answer_ch: 在动物园看完狮子和长颈鹿之后，上午的时间一过，我和大卫总会溜进大门旁的小咖啡馆，点上一杯热可可和几块饼干，然后摆开“蛇梯棋”来玩。这成了我们第一次见面时就开始的仪式——那天天空突然下起倾盆大雨，咖啡馆货架上只有这一个棋盘游戏，为了打发时间我们就试了试。我们的棋子一路滑下蛇身把我们逗得前仰后合，从此这游戏就成了我们的常规项目。现在每次一离开动物区，我们就迫不及待地想要掷骰子，看看谁能先爬上梯子。

questions.question_en: How does Julie’s height help her in games like basketball or reaching things on high shelves, and do you ever ask her for help?
questions.question_ch: 朱莉的身高如何帮助她在像篮球这样的运动中或者在高处的架子上拿东西？你会向她寻求帮助吗？
questions.answer_en: Julie’s extra height gives her longer arms and a higher standing reach so in basketball she can grab rebounds, block shots and even dunk more easily than the rest of us, and when something’s on a top shelf in the classroom or library she just stretches up and brings it down, so yes—whenever I can’t reach something I always ask Julie for help and she kindly does it without even needing a stool.
questions.answer_ch: 朱莉额外的身高让她的手臂更长，站立触及高度更高，所以在篮球场上她比我们更容易抢篮板、盖帽，甚至扣篮；在教室或图书馆里，当东西放在顶层架子上时，她只要伸手就能拿到。所以，是的——每当我够不着东西时，我总会请朱莉帮忙，而她都会很热心地帮我，甚至根本不用凳子。

questions.question_en: Has Julie ever taught you a trick for staying tall and confident when playing with classmates?
questions.question_ch: 朱莉有没有教过你在和同学一起玩时保持挺拔自信的窍门？
questions.answer_en: No, Julie hasn’t ever shown me a specific trick. But I’ve noticed how she carries herself—standing up straight, shoulders back, head held high—and I try to copy that. Watching her confidence on the playground reminded me that good posture and keeping my chin up help me feel taller and braver when I play with friends.
questions.answer_ch: 不，朱莉从来没给我演示过什么具体的诀窍。不过我注意到她的仪态──站得笔直、肩膀向后、昂首挺胸──我就尽量模仿。看着她在操场上的自信，提醒我保持良好姿势和抬着下巴，能让我在和朋友玩耍时感觉更高、更勇敢。

questions.question_en: How do you help Colin when his allergies flare up—do you remind him to take medication or find a shady spot to rest?
questions.question_ch: 当科林过敏发作时，你如何帮助他——是提醒他服药，还是给他找个阴凉处休息？
questions.answer_en: I usually keep an eye on Colin at playtime and if I see him rubbing his eyes or sneezing, I quietly ask, “Do you need your hayfever tablets?” Then I slip him a tissue and lead him over to our favourite shady bench under the big oak tree by the playground so the pollen’s not so strong. I remind him to drink some water from his bottle and take a few slow breaths. If he still feels rough, I stay with him, draw little pictures on my notebook to distract him, and let our teacher know he might need a break.
questions.answer_ch: 我通常在课间留意科林，如果看到他揉眼睛或打喷嚏，我就轻声问：“你需要吃花粉过敏药吗？”然后我递给他一张纸巾，带他到操场旁大橡树下我们最喜欢的阴凉长凳上，这样花粉没那么浓。我提醒他从水壶里喝点水，慢慢深呼吸几次。如果他还是不舒服，我就陪在他身边，在笔记本上画些小图分散他的注意力，并告诉老师他可能需要休息一下。

questions.question_en: What is Colin’s favorite place to play outside, and how do you both avoid triggers for his seasonal allergies?
questions.question_ch: Colin最喜欢去哪里户外玩？你们怎么避免触发他的季节性过敏？
questions.answer_en: Colin absolutely loves racing across the wide meadow by Parliament Hill on Hampstead Heath—the open space, gentle slopes and clear sight-lines are perfect for him to sprint around with Gerald and me.  Because he has terrible springtime allergies, we’ve learned to beat the pollen: we check the daily pollen forecast and only head out after a good rain when levels are lowest, Colin takes his antihistamine before we set off, he wears a lightweight pollen mask and a long-sleeved top to keep grains off his skin, and we steer clear of the grassier banks and flowering hedgerows, sticking instead to the gravel paths shaded by tall oaks.  When we get home, Colin changes straight away and has a quick rinse to wash pollen off, which keeps his sneezing and itchy eyes at bay so he can enjoy running free.
questions.answer_ch: 科林非常喜欢在汉普斯特德希思国会山那宽阔的草地上飞奔——开阔的空间、缓坡和清晰的视野非常适合他和杰拉尔德以及我一起狂奔。由于他在春季花粉过敏严重，我们学会了避开花粉：我们会查看每日花粉预报，仅在一场大雨过后花粉浓度最低时出发；出发前科林会服用抗组胺药；他戴上轻便的防花粉口罩，穿长袖上衣以防花粉落到皮肤上；我们避开长满草的河岸和开花的树篱，改走被高大橡树遮荫的碎石小径。回到家后，科林会立刻换衣并快速冲洗，洗去身上的花粉，这样他就不会不停打喷嚏或眼睛发痒，可以尽情奔跑了。

questions.question_en: Why do you think Kirk sometimes acts like a bully, and have you found any way to talk to him and understand what’s bothering him?
questions.question_ch: 你认为柯克为什么有时表现得像个欺凌者？你有没有找到什么方法与他交谈并了解困扰他的原因？
questions.answer_en: Sometimes I think Kirk acts like a bully because he might be hurting inside; bullies often try to make themselves feel bigger by putting others down, so maybe he’s insecure about something at home or at school and doesn’t know how to say it. I once tried to talk to him quietly at recess, asking if anything was wrong, but he only shrugged and walked away. Another time I stood by him after class and told him I’d listen if he ever wanted to talk, but he didn’t respond. I haven’t found the right way to reach him yet, but I believe being calm, kind and patient is the best approach—if I keep showing him respect and a willingness to help, maybe one day he’ll trust me enough to share what’s bothering him.
questions.answer_ch: 有时候我觉得柯克表现得像个恶霸，是因为他可能内心受伤；恶霸常常通过贬低别人来让自己感觉更强大，所以也许他在家里或学校有不安全感，却不知道如何表达。我曾在课间安静地和他谈过，问他是不是有什么烦心事，但他只是耸耸肩走开了。还有一次下课后我站在他身边告诉他，如果他想说话，我愿意倾听，但他没有回应。我还没找到接近他的最好方式，但我相信保持冷静、友善和耐心是最好的方法——如果我不断对他表现出尊重和帮助的意愿，也许有一天他会信任我，告诉我困扰他的事情。

questions.question_en: What do you do when Kirk picks on someone—how do you stand up for that classmate and keep everyone safe?
questions.question_ch: 当柯克欺负某人时，你会怎么做——你如何为那位同学挺身而出并确保大家的安全？
questions.answer_en: When Kirk picks on someone, I first make sure my classmate is all right—checking they’re not hurt or too upset—and I stand between them and Kirk, looking him in the eye and firmly telling him “That’s not okay, stop it.” If Kirk won’t listen, I don’t try to fight him myself; instead I escort my friend away to a safe spot and find a teacher or Mr. Dany right away, because adults know how to keep everyone safe. I also invite other classmates to walk together so no one feels alone, and after school I check in with the person who was picked on to make sure they know they’re not by themselves. By speaking up calmly, getting help from teachers, and staying together as friends, we show bullies that we care for one another and refuse to let anyone be bullied without support.
questions.answer_ch: 当柯克欺负别人时，我会先确认我的同学没事——检查他们是否受伤或过于难过——然后我站到他们和柯克之间，看着柯克的眼睛，坚定地对他说：“这样做不对，停止！”如果柯克不肯听，我不会自己跟他打架；相反，我会护送我的朋友到一个安全的地方，然后立刻去找老师或达尼先生，因为大人知道如何保证大家的安全。我还会邀请其他同学一起走，这样没人会觉得孤单。放学后，我还会去关心被欺负的同学，确保他们知道自己并不孤单。通过冷静地发声、寻求老师的帮助和朋友们的团结，我们向欺凌者表明，我们彼此关心，绝不允许任何人在没有支持的情况下被欺负。

questions.question_en: What makes Amanda stand out in cooking class, and why do you think you like her as a friend or partner in cooking?
questions.question_ch: 是什么让阿曼达在烹饪课上脱颖而出？你为什么觉得自己喜欢她作为朋友或烹饪搭档？
questions.answer_en: Amanda shines in cooking class because she’s the kind of partner who somehow makes everything feel under control, even when the kitchen’s a mess. While most of us scramble to measure ingredients or keep knives from slipping, Amanda moves with steady confidence—she reads the recipe carefully, double-checks the timing, and never lets the dough stick to the bowl. She’s patient about explaining each step, whether it’s folding pastry or adjusting seasoning, and she’s not above rolling up her sleeves to help scrub the counter when we’re done. I like cooking with her because her calm, encouraging way turns what can be a frantic race against the clock into a relaxed adventure. She listens to my odd ideas—like adding mint to lamb stew—and then helps me shape them into something that actually tastes good. With Amanda by my side, I feel braver about trying new recipes, and I know that even if things go sideways, she’ll have a clever fix or at least a laugh to keep me from giving up. Having her as a friend in the kitchen makes cooking feel fun instead of frightening—she’s the kind of teammate who turns every mishap into a chance to learn.
questions.answer_ch:
Amanda在烹饪课上表现出色，因为她是那种能让一切看起来井井有条的搭档，即使厨房乱成一团。大多数人忙着量食材或防止刀具滑落时，Amanda却动作沉稳自信——她仔细阅读食谱，反复确认时间，从不让面团粘在碗上。她耐心地解释每一步，无论是折叠酥皮还是调整调味；做完后，她也会卷起袖子帮忙擦洗台面。

我喜欢和她一起做饭，因为她冷静、鼓励的方式能把原本紧张的倒计时变成一次轻松的冒险。她听我那些奇怪的想法——比如往羊肉炖汤里加薄荷——然后帮我把它们变成真正好吃的菜。有了Amanda在身边，我更有勇气尝试新菜谱，就算事情出岔子，她也能想出巧妙的解决办法，或者至少会笑着让我不放弃。有她当厨房里的朋友，做饭变得有趣而不是可怕——她就是那种能把每次失误都变成学习机会的队友。

questions.question_en: Have you ever helped Amanda choose ingredients or recipes, and how did she teach you something new about cooking?
questions.question_ch: 你有没有帮助阿曼达选择食材或食谱？她是如何教给你一些关于烹饪的新知识的？
questions.answer_en: Yes—last month in our after-school cooking club I helped Amanda pick ingredients for a spring vegetable risotto. She showed me how to choose the ripest asparagus tips by gently snapping them at the tender joint, and taught me that the secret to a glossy finish is stirring constantly while ladling in warm stock. I’d always thought you simply poured and waited, but Amanda explained that each cup of broth must be absorbed before adding the next, and that scraping the bottom of the pan releases the tiny browned bits that give risotto its nutty flavor. She even let me taste a pinprick of saffron steeped in hot water—just the smell made me understand why it’s so prized. That day I learned to trust my senses—snap, stir, taste—and I’ve used that lesson every time I cook since.
questions.answer_ch: 是的——上个月在我们的课后烹饪俱乐部，我帮阿曼达挑选春季蔬菜烩饭的食材。她教我如何通过在嫩节处轻轻折断来挑选最新鲜的芦笋顶端，还告诉我，要想烩饭有光泽的口感，关键是一边不断搅拌，一边用勺子舀入温热的高汤。我一直以为只要倒进去然后等着就行，可阿曼达解释说，每加一杯高汤都必须等它完全吸收后才能再加，而且刮动锅底能释放那些微小的焦化颗粒，为烩饭增添坚果般的香味。她甚至让我尝了一小撮用热水浸出的藏红花——仅仅闻到那股香味就让我明白了它为何如此珍贵。那天我学会了信任自己的感官——折、搅、尝——从那以后我每次做饭都在实践这个道理。

questions.question_en: What challenges do you and Jenny face when cooking together, and what’s your favorite dish that you’ve both made?
questions.question_ch: 当你和珍妮一起做饭时会遇到哪些挑战？你们最喜欢一起做的菜是什么？
questions.answer_en: Cooking with Jenny we often collide over timing and tasks: she hates waiting for dough to rest while I insist on measuring every ingredient to the gram; we both reach for the chopping board and swap spoons for spatulas without a word, only to discover halfway through we’ve missed a step in the recipe. Our taste buds clash too—I like something barely sweet, she loves syrupy finishes—so adjusting sugar levels sparks mini debates. Learning to communicate by assigning clear roles (she preps and I manage the heat) has helped us calm the kitchen chaos. Our favourite dish we’ve made together is chocolate-chip cookies: golden around the edges, gooey at the center, and the perfect symbol of what happens when our stubbornness finally turns into team-work.
questions.answer_ch: 在和珍妮一起做饭时，我们经常因为时间安排和分工而产生冲突：她讨厌等面团发酵，而我坚持把每一种配料都精确到克；我们俩经常同时伸手去拿切菜板，然后从勺子换到铲子，却一句话不说，直到半路才发现我们漏做了一个步骤。我们的味觉偏好也不一样——我喜欢稍微带点甜味，她喜欢糖浆般的甜蜜——所以调节糖量时总会引发小争论。后来我们学会了通过明确分工来沟通（她负责食材准备，我负责火候掌控），这帮助我们平息了厨房里的混乱。我们一起做过的最喜欢的菜是巧克力曲奇：边缘金黄，中心软糯，完美象征了当我们固执变成团队合作时所能达到的美妙效果。

questions.question_en: How do you and Jenny decide who does which task in cooking class—do you prefer stirring or chopping, and what does she prefer?
questions.question_ch: 你和珍妮如何决定在烹饪课上由谁负责哪个任务——你更喜欢搅拌还是切菜，她又更喜欢什么？
questions.answer_en: I’ve noticed in cooking class that Jenny and I always begin by asking which task each of us enjoys most—there’s never any bossing about it, just a quick chat. I always volunteer to do the stirring because I like the steady, rhythmic motion of folding batter or whisking a sauce; it feels a bit like a science experiment and I can watch the colours and textures change. Jenny, being a couple of years older and more confident with a knife, prefers the chopping—she’s careful yet swift with onions and peppers, and she says she enjoys the precision and the satisfying “clack‐clack” sound. If Jenny ever wants a break from chopping, she’ll hand me the chopping board and I’ll grate or slice under her supervision, and if I ever tire of stirring she’s happy to pick up the whisk. Sometimes, when neither of us has a strong preference, we flip a wooden spoon like a coin just for fun, and whoever “wins” chooses first—but more often than not we match the task to the skill and energy we each feel that day.
questions.answer_ch: 我注意到在烹饪课上，Jenny和我总是先聊一聊各自最想做的任务——从不指派，只有简短的交谈。我总是自愿去搅拌，因为我喜欢那种折叠面糊或打酱的稳定、节奏感动作；这感觉有点像做科学实验，我可以看着颜色和质地变化。Jenny大我几岁，用刀更有自信，她更喜欢切菜——对洋葱和青椒既小心又干脆，她说她喜欢那种精准感和令人满足的“咔嗒咔嗒”声。如果Jenny想暂时不切菜，她就把砧板交给我，在她监督下我就擦丝或切片；如果我累得不想搅拌，她也很乐意拿起打蛋器。有时当我们都没特别偏好，就会把木勺子当硬币一样抛一下，玩得开心，抛赢的人先选——但更多时候，我们还是根据当天的技能和精力来分配任务。

questions.question_en: What’s a memorable recipe you and Andy created together, and how did Andy react when the dish turned out well (or didn’t)?
questions.question_ch: 你和安迪一起创作过的最难忘的食谱是什么？当这道菜做得成功（或失败）时，安迪有何反应？
questions.answer_en: One of my most memorable cooking adventures with Andy was when we decided to make marmalade-glazed chicken skewers in our after-school cooking club. I’d insisted on using my favorite Bonne Maman orange marmalade in the marinade, and Andy nervously warned it might be too sweet. When the skewers first came out of the oven the glaze had caramelized into a cloying layer, and Andy bravely took a bite, his face twisting comically as he muttered, “It’s like eating a candy-coated drumstick!” We both burst into laughter at how sticky and over-the-top it was. Undeterred, we re-mixed the marinade with a dash of soy, a pinch of chili, and a squeeze of lemon, and on our second try the skewers turned out perfectly balanced—Andy closed his eyes, nodded slowly, and proclaimed, “This is proper grown-up food, Isaac—absolutely brilliant!”
questions.answer_ch: 我和安迪最难忘的一次烹饪冒险，是在课后烹饪俱乐部里一起做橙酱烤鸡肉串。我坚持要在腌料里用我最爱的Bonne Maman橙子果酱，安迪则紧张地警告说可能会太甜。鸡肉串刚出炉时，酱汁已经焦糖化成了一层黏乎乎的厚膜，安迪鼓起勇气咬了一口，脸都扭成了一团，低声嘟囔道：“简直像在吃糖衣鸡腿！”我们俩都被这过于黏腻夸张的味道逗得哈哈大笑。我们毫不气馁，又重新调了腌料，加入了一点酱油、一撮辣椒粉和几滴柠檬汁。第二次尝试时，鸡肉串的味道完美平衡——安迪闭上眼睛，缓缓点头，庄重地宣布：“这是正儿八经的大人菜，艾萨克——绝对精彩！”

questions.question_en: How do you handle mistakes in cooking class when you and Andy mix up ingredients—what did you learn from that experience?
questions.question_ch: 当你和安迪在烹饪课上把食材弄混时，你是如何处理这个错误的——你从那次经历中学到了什么？
questions.answer_en: One time in cooking class Andy and I accidentally swapped salt and sugar when we were making muffins and ended up with a batch that tasted like salted porridge – at first I felt really embarrassed, but our teacher helped us see it as a chance to learn: we tasted, we talked through what went wrong, and we agreed from then on to use mise en place—laying out and labeling every ingredient before we start—and to double-check our measures. I realized that mistakes aren’t failures but experiments that teach you to slow down, plan ahead, and trust your senses (smell, taste, sight) as much as the recipe, and now I always take a moment to ensure I’m using the right container and spoon before I pour anything.
questions.answer_ch: 有一次在烹饪课上，我和安迪在做松饼时不小心把盐和糖对调了，结果烤出来的松饼吃起来像咸粥——一开始我觉得非常尴尬，但老师帮我们把这次失误当作学习的机会：我们尝了尝，讨论出错的原因，然后决定从此使用“备料”方法——在开始前把所有食材都摆好并标记清楚——并且再次确认量具是否准确。我意识到错误并不是失败，而是教你放慢节奏、提前计划，并像依赖食谱一样相信自己的感官（嗅觉、味觉、视觉）的实验。现在每次倒任何东西之前，我都会先确认使用的是正确的容器和量勺。

questions.question_en: What tips has Rosa given you about improving your tennis or sports skills, and how did you practice them together on court?
questions.question_ch: 罗莎给了你哪些关于提高网球或其他运动技能的建议？你们是如何在球场上一起练习这些建议的？
questions.answer_en: Rosa told me that power in tennis comes not from arm strength alone but from your legs and hips driving through each shot, so she urged me to bend my knees deeply and push off my back foot as I swung. She also showed me how to use a proper continental grip for volleys—light in the fingers, firm in the wrist—and reminded me to keep my eyes on the ball until after I’d followed through. On court we’d spend the first few minutes side-by-side doing split-step footwork drills: she set out cones and had me shuffle laterally, always arriving in a low, balanced stance before swinging. Then we’d rally cross-court with slow feeds from her racket, each time she’d pause me to adjust my shoulder rotation or remind me to finish my swing high. Finally she’d stand at the net and lob gently, teaching me to step forward into a compact punch-style volley. Practicing in that order—footwork, grip, groundstrokes and net play—helped me feel my body working as one unit.
questions.answer_ch: 罗莎告诉我，网球的力量不仅仅来自手臂，而是源于双腿和臀部在每次击球中的发力贯穿，因此她督促我深屈膝，在挥拍时用后脚蹬地发力。她还教我在截击时使用正确的大陆式握拍——手指轻握，腕部稳固——并提醒我直到挥拍结束后才移开视线。场上我们会先并肩做几分钟分腿跳脚步练习：她摆放圆锥标，让我侧向滑步，每次都要在低而平衡的姿态中到位后再挥拍。然后我们进行斜对角来回击球练习，她用慢速喂球，每次都会让我停下来调整肩部旋转或提醒我高位收拍。最后她站在球网前轻轻吊高球，教我向前上步，用紧凑的“拳式”截击。按照这个顺序——脚步、握拍、底线击球和网前技术——练习让我感受到全身如一体般协同发力。

questions.question_en: How do you feel watching Rosa play at junior Wimbledon, and have you tried any of her training exercises at home?
questions.question_ch: 在青少年温布尔登看到罗莎比赛时，你有什么感受？你有没有在家尝试过她的训练练习？
questions.answer_en: I felt my heart race each time Rosa took the court at junior Wimbledon – her powerful serves and lightning-quick footwork made me catch my breath. Watching her play was like seeing a Valkyrie in a white skirt, so confident and graceful that I forgot to blink. I admired how she seemed to float across the grass, her racket poised perfectly, her eyes never leaving the ball. It filled me with pride to cheer for someone from my school, and just a tinge of envy at how easily she handled the pressure. At home I tried some of her training exercises: I set up a makeshift agility ladder with chalk on the patio and hopped through the rungs as fast as I could, then practiced bouncing a tennis ball repeatedly against the garage wall to sharpen my hand-eye coordination. I even swung my foam racket at a balloon to work on control without worrying about missing. I wasn’t as quick or precise as Rosa, but just as she did, I learned that every drill, however simple, helped me feel a little more like a champion.
questions.answer_ch: 每次罗莎在青少年温网场上出场，我的心都会狂跳——她那强力发球和电光火石般的步伐让我屏住了呼吸。看她比赛就像看见一个穿白色短裙的女武神，如此自信优雅，连眨眼的时间都让我忘了。我钦佩她在草地上仿佛飘逸而过，球拍姿势完美，目光从未离开球。为同校的选手加油让我充满自豪，也带着一丝嫉妒，羡慕她是如何轻松应对压力的。回到家后，我也尝试了她的一些训练：在露台上用粉笔画了一个简易敏捷梯，尽可能快地连续跳过每个梯档；然后对着车库墙不断击球，锻炼手眼协调；甚至拿泡沫球拍对着气球挥拍，练习控球而不必担心击空。我虽然没有罗莎那么快、那么精准，但就像她一样，我明白了每一个训练，无论多简单，都能让我更有冠军的感觉。

questions.question_en: What games do Jeffery and Luthien love to play together, and how do you help them settle when they disagree?
questions.question_ch: 杰弗里和卢西恩喜欢一起玩哪些游戏？当他们意见不合时，你如何帮助他们达成一致？
questions.answer_en: Jeffery and Luthien love the same things most of us do at break time – playing tag or hide-and-seek on the playground and huddling together over a board game like Snakes & Ladders in the corridor. They roar with laughter when Luthien’s piece slides down a snake and chase each other under the climbing frame at lunch. When they do disagree – as happened the other day over Jeffery’s yoghurt – I step in quietly, listen to each of them in turn, help them put into words how the other’s action made them feel, then suggest a simple compromise (say sorry, share a turn, make a new rule) so that they both feel respected. By asking “How would you feel if it happened to you?” and offering to shuffle the board, we clear away the upset and get back to playing together.
questions.answer_ch: Jeffery 和 Luthien 在课间最喜欢做的事和我们大多数人一样——在操场上玩捉人或捉迷藏，或者在走廊里围着“蛇与梯子”这样的桌游聚在一起。当 Luthien 的棋子顺着蛇滑下时，他们会笑得前仰后合；午餐时间，他们还会在攀爬架下你追我赶。偶尔发生分歧——就像前几天为了一杯酸奶吵起来那次——我会静静地介入，先后倾听他们的想法，帮助他们用语言表达对方的行为带给自己的感受，然后提出一个简单的折中方案（比如说“对不起”、轮流分享、制定新规则），让他们都感到被尊重。通过问“如果换成你，你会怎么想？”并提议重新洗牌，我们就能化解矛盾，继续愉快地玩耍。

questions.question_en: How do you encourage Jeffery when he’s shy or hesitant, since he’s Luthien’s best friend?
questions.question_ch: 既然杰弗里是露西恩最好的朋友，当他害羞或犹豫不决时，你会如何鼓励他？
questions.answer_en: When Jeffery seems shy or unsure, I first try to meet him where he is—whether that’s by quietly sitting beside him at lunchtime or by tapping my foot gently when he’s nervous before a game—so he knows he’s not alone. I remind him of all the times he’s done something brave, like the time he confidently launched his kite above Hampstead Heath, and I tell him, “You did that perfectly yesterday, you can do this too,” in a soft, steady voice. I share a small joke or ask about his favourite animal—“Hey, have you seen any penguins at the zoo lately?”—to take his mind off the pressure. If he’s hesitating to try something new, I offer to do it alongside him—“Let’s both draw a robot together and see whose looks more like our classmate Colin”—so it feels more like a game than a test. And whenever he takes even a tiny step forward, I cheer for him—often just a quiet “Well done” and a thumbs-up—that shows him I believe in him, and that encouragement usually helps him find his own confidence.
questions.answer_ch: 当杰弗里显得害羞或不确定时，我首先尝试在他所在的位置与他相遇——无论是午餐时静静地坐在他旁边，还是在他赛前紧张时轻轻地跺脚——让他知道自己并不孤单。我会提醒他那些他曾经勇敢的时刻，比如他自信地在汉普斯特德荒原上放风筝的那一次，然后用柔和而坚定的声音告诉他：“你昨天做得很完美，这次你也能做到。”我会讲个小笑话或问他最喜欢的动物是什么——“嘿，你最近在动物园里看到企鹅了吗？”——帮他分散注意力。如果他对尝试新事物犹豫不决，我会提出和他一起做——“我们一起画一个机器人，看看谁画得更像我们同学科林”——让它更像一个游戏而不是考试。每当他哪怕迈出一小步，我都会为他加油——通常只是轻声地说一句“做得好”并竖起大拇指——这向他展示了我对他的信任，而这种鼓励通常能帮助他找到自信。

questions.question_en: What happened when Luthien pushed Chris, and how did you help them make up afterward?
questions.question_ch: 当Luthien推了Chris时发生了什么？之后你是如何帮助他们和好？
questions.answer_en: When Luthien saw Chris grab Jeffery’s yogurt during lunch, she marched straight up and shoved Chris so hard she fell to the floor—and Chris burst into tears. I was shocked, but I knew I had to help them sort it out. First I quietly led Luthien aside and reminded her that next time she could warn Chris first instead of pushing. Then I brought Luthien back and sat with both girls, asking Chris why she’d taken Jeffery’s yogurt and encouraging her to say sorry. Luthien admitted she’d overreacted, Chris apologized for grabbing the yogurt, and they both agreed to use words before hands in the future. They ended up shaking hands and smiling, and I felt proud to have helped them make up without anyone feeling ignored or punished.
questions.answer_ch: 当午餐时间露西恩看到克里斯抓走杰弗里的酸奶时，她径直走过去，用力推了克里斯一把，把她推倒在地——克里斯当场哭了起来。我很震惊，但知道必须帮她们解决问题。首先，我悄悄把露西恩拉到一边，提醒她下次可以先警告克里斯，而不是直接动手。然后我让露西恩回到我身边，与两个女孩并坐，问克里斯为什么拿杰弗里的酸奶，并鼓励她道歉。露西恩承认自己反应过度，克里斯也为拿酸奶道了歉，她们都同意今后先用语言沟通再动手。最后，她们握手微笑，我为能在不让任何人感到被忽视或惩罚的情况下帮助她们和好而感到自豪。

questions.question_en: How do you and Chris make sure everyone understands each other’s feelings so that pushing doesn’t happen again?
questions.question_ch: 你和克里斯如何确保彼此都能理解对方的感受，以免再次发生推搡？
questions.answer_en: I remembered that after the pushing incident Chris and I found a quiet moment behind the bike sheds to talk it through: I told her I’d felt scared when she shoved me, and she said she was angry at what had happened with Jeffery’s yogurt; we both said “I’m sorry” in turn, and agreed that next time one of us would say “Stop” before hands went up. We decided to watch our words and remember we’re friends first, so if one of us felt upset we’d say “Can we talk?” instead of pushing; we even practised nodding to show we understand. Since then, every time we’ve had a disagreement we’ve used those signals—saying “I feel…” and asking “Really? Thank you for telling me” —and we’ve never pushed each other again.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得在推搡事件之后，克里斯和我在自行车棚后面找了个安静的时刻把事情聊开了：我告诉她，当她推我时我感到很害怕，她说她是因为杰弗里的酸奶的事而生气；然后我们轮流说了“对不起”，并约定下次如果要动手，一定会先说“停”。我们决定注意言辞，记住我们首先是朋友，所以如果有一方不高兴，我们会说“我们能谈谈吗？”，而不是推搡；我们甚至练习点头来表示理解。从那以后，每次发生分歧时，我们都会使用这些信号——说“我感觉……”并且问“真的吗？谢谢你告诉我”——我们再也没有互相推搡过。

questions.question_en: What was your favorite lesson from Year 1 with Mr. Andrew, and how did he make learning fun?
questions.question_ch: 在一年级与安德鲁老师一起时，你最喜欢哪一节课？他是如何让学习变得有趣的？
questions.answer_en: My favourite Year 1 lesson with Mr Andrew was the outdoor Art Week project, “Our Garden Planet.” Instead of sitting at desks, he led us out into the playground and had us paint giant panels with leaves, sticks and colourful chalks. He let us mix paint in the sunshine, splash water on the boards, and invent our own designs – even making me “academic advisor” for bug-spotting details. His endless praise (“Fantastic idea!” “Brilliant colour choice!”) and playful energy turned a simple painting class into a wild, messy science experiment. Painting under blue skies with my friends, laughing when someone’s canvas ran down with paint, made learning feel like the best game ever – that’s why I still remember it so fondly.
questions.answer_ch: 我最喜欢的一年级安德鲁老师的课是户外艺术周项目“我们的花园星球”。他没有让我们坐在课桌前，而是带我们来到操场，让我们用树叶、树枝和五颜六色的粉笔在巨大的画板上作画。他让我们在阳光下调和颜料，在木板上撒水，随意发挥创意设计——甚至让我担任“学术顾问”，负责观察和记录小虫子的细节。他不断的赞美（“太棒的创意！”“配色真精彩！”）和充满趣味的活力，把简单的绘画课变成了一场狂野又混乱的科学实验。在蓝天下和朋友们一起作画，看着谁的画布因颜料流淌而大笑，让学习感觉像是玩最好玩的游戏——这就是我至今仍记忆犹新的原因。

questions.question_en: How did Mr. Andrew handle times when you felt sensitive to criticism, and what did he do to help you feel more confident?
questions.question_ch: 当你对批评感到敏感时，安德鲁先生是如何应对的？他做了什么来帮助你增强自信？
questions.answer_en: He always noticed when I grew quiet after someone pointed out a mistake. Instead of scolding me for being oversensitive, Mr. Andrew would pull me aside and remind me of something I’d done well—maybe how accurately I’d identified a bird’s call on our nature walk or how neatly I’d arranged my paint colors during Art Week. Then he’d give me a small role of responsibility, like “academic advisor” when we built our class mural, so I felt trusted rather than judged. He’d say, “Isaac, you know this stuff better than anyone here—your ideas matter,” and send me outside with a clipboard to help lead our outdoor science session. By singling out my strengths, entrusting me with tasks, and getting me back into the fresh air where I felt at home, he helped me shake off the sting of criticism and remember that I belonged in the classroom as much as anyone.
questions.answer_ch: 每当有人指出我的错误后，我变得沉默时，他总能注意到。安德鲁老师没有因为我太敏感而训斥我，他会把我拉到一边，提醒我曾做得很好的事情——也许是在自然观察课上我多么准确地辨认出了鸟鸣，或者是在美术周里我多么整齐地排列了颜料。然后他会给我一个小小的责任角色，比如在我们一起绘制班级壁画时担任学术顾问，让我感到被信任而不是被评判。他会说：“艾萨克，你对这些比这里任何人都了解——你的想法很重要。”然后让我拿着写字板到户外去，帮助带领我们的科学课。通过发掘我的长处，委以我任务，并把我带回那片让我感到自在的新鲜空气中，他帮助我摆脱了批评的刺痛，记起我和任何人一样，都属于这个课堂。

questions.question_en: What activities did Mr. Jacob introduce in Year 2 that made you curious about new subjects?
questions.question_ch: 雅各布先生在二年级引入了哪些活动，让你对新学科产生了好奇？
questions.answer_en:
In Year 2 Mr Jacob did two things that really opened my eyes to new subjects. First he ran a monthly “Passport Project” in PSHE, where each of us chose a country, found out a traditional food, a folk story or a craft from that place, and then shared it with the class. One month I brought in Chinese kites, another time I learned about Irish soda bread—and every time I discovered things I’d never even thought to ask about before. 

Then he teamed up with the science teacher and took us out into the school’s little garden for “Nature Detectives” days. We built simple bug hotels, pond-dipped to see water creatures under the microscope and recorded which insects visited which flowers. Holding a ladybird in one hand and a notebook in the other made me realise that biology wasn’t just a list of facts in a book but something you could explore and experiment with yourself. Those two activities—sharing the world’s cultures and investigating real wildlife—are what made me curious about geography, history and science all at once.
questions.answer_ch:
在二年级时，雅各布老师做了两件事，真正让我对新学科大开眼界。首先，他在个人、社会、健康和经济教育课（PSHE）中每月举办一次“护照项目”，我们每个人选择一个国家，了解该地的传统食物、民间故事或手工艺品，然后与全班分享。一个月我带来了中国风筝，另一个月我了解了爱尔兰苏打面包——每次我都发现了以前从未想过要了解的东西。

随后，他与科学老师合作，带我们到学校的小花园里进行“自然侦探”日活动。我们搭建了简易昆虫旅馆，用池塘水样在显微镜下观察水生生物，并记录哪些昆虫探访了哪些花朵。手里拿着瓢虫，另一只手拿着笔记本，我才意识到生物学不仅仅是书本上的一堆事实，而是可以自己动手探索和实验的东西。正是这两项活动——分享世界文化和调查真实野生生物——让我对地理、历史和科学产生了浓厚的好奇心。

questions.question_en: How did Mr. Jacob help you when you had trouble understanding something, and what did you learn most from him?
questions.question_ch: 当你在理解某事时遇到困难，Jacob先生是如何帮助你的？你从他身上学到的最多的是什么？
questions.answer_en: Whenever I got stuck in Mr. Jacob’s class—usually on those tricky fraction problems—he’d always stay behind after everyone else had filed out. He’d pull out colored paper strips or cut-up fruit and quietly show me how one whole could be broken into equal parts, letting me arrange the pieces myself until the idea clicked. Sometimes he even let me teach back what I’d just learned, so he knew I really understood. What I learned most from him wasn’t just how to add or subtract fractions but that it’s perfectly okay to ask for help, and that patience and a different way of looking at a problem can turn something confusing into something you can master.
questions.answer_ch: 每当我在雅各老师的课上遇到难题——通常是那些棘手的分数问题时，他总会在其他人都走后留下来。他会拿出彩色的纸条或切好的水果，悄悄地给我演示如何把一个整体分成相等的部分，让我自己摆放这些碎片，直到我真正领悟。有时他甚至让我把刚学到的东西再教给他一遍，以确认我真的理解了。他教给我的，不仅是如何加减分数，更让我明白：寻求帮助完全没问题，而且耐心和换个角度看问题，可以把困惑变成掌握的知识。

questions.question_en: What was Aki’s favorite part of Gerald’s birthday party, and how did you and Aki play together?
questions.question_ch: 在杰拉德的生日派对上，Aki最喜欢的环节是什么？你和Aki是怎么一起玩的？
questions.answer_en: Aki’s favorite moment was when we fired up the Nintendo Switch and teamed up in Super Mario. She grinned every time we slid down a flagpole together or wall-jumped over a Goomba, and she kept saying how much fun it was. We sat side by side, me on Mario and her on Luigi, coordinating our moves perfectly—she’d hold a Goomba in place while I grabbed a power-up, we’d time our jumps in unison and clear each level without ever losing a life. By the end of the party we felt unbeatable, high-fiving after every victory and laughing at our own tricks.
questions.answer_ch: Aki最喜欢的时刻是我们打开Nintendo Switch，一起玩《超级马里奥》的时候。每次我们一起从旗杆上滑下或贴墙跳过一只蘑菇人，她都会咧嘴笑，并不停地说有多么好玩。我们并排坐着，我操控马里奥，她操控路易吉，完美配合——她按住蘑菇人让我去捡强化道具，我们同步跳跃，一关关通关，甚至一次都没死。聚会结束时，我们感觉无往不胜，每赢一局就击掌庆祝，为自己的花式操作捧腹大笑。

questions.question_en: How do you and Aki bond over shared interests, like drawing or toys, when you meet at Gerald’s house?
questions.question_ch: 当你在杰拉德家见面时，你和阿基如何通过共同的兴趣，比如画画或玩具建立联系？
questions.answer_en: Whenever Aki and I meet at Gerald’s house, we head straight for the little art corner he and his uncle set up in the kitchen and pull out our sketchbooks, markers and colored pencils. I’ll show her how I map out silhouettes of birds or insects I’ve been studying—last week it was the pipevine swallowtail’s distinctive wing pattern—while she teaches me how to draw her favorite anime-style characters with those big expressive eyes she loves. Sometimes we’ll compare stickers and toys—she brought a tiny penguin figure she got in Xi’an, and I let her inspect my Rainbow Stag Beetle model—then we’ll sketch them side by side. If we tire of drawing we’ll spread out our action figures and invent stories, sending them on wildlife rescue missions or space adventures before diving back into doodling. Every visit ends the same way: we swap our latest creations and promise to finish the other’s drawing before the next playdate, letting shared projects turn our afternoons into a small, happy workshop.
questions.answer_ch: 每次我和阿纪在杰拉尔德家见面，我们都会径直走到他和他叔叔在厨房里布置的小小艺术角，拿出素描本、马克笔和彩色铅笔。我会给她示范我是怎样勾勒我最近研究的鸟类或昆虫的轮廓——上周画的是管道藤凤蝶那独特的翅膀花纹——而她则教我画她最喜欢的动漫风角色，尤其是那些大大而富有表情的眼睛。有时候我们会互相拿出贴纸和玩具比一比——她带来一只在西安买的小企鹅模型，我则让她把玩我的彩虹锹甲模型——然后我们就并排画它们。如果画累了，我们就把动作人偶摆开，编故事，让它们去执行野生动物营救任务或太空冒险，然后再继续涂鸦。每次玩耍都以同样的方式结束：我们交换最新的作品，并约定在下次见面前把对方的画补画完，让这些共同的项目把我们的下午变成一个小小而快乐的工作坊。

questions.question_en: What did you and Batul do together at the Nadam festival, and how did you learn about Mongolian culture from him?
questions.question_ch: 你和巴图尔在那达慕节上一起做了什么？你是如何从他那里了解蒙古文化的？
questions.answer_en: At the Mongolian Nadam festival we all piled into a tiny tent-turned tea stall where Batul, a ten-year-old Mongolian boy, was helping serve steaming bowls of salty-buttery milk tea. Lucy and I sipped from the little reed cups while Batul patiently showed me how to hold and swirl the tea just right. Between mouthfuls, he told me his name means “hero” or “warrior,” and that many Mongolian boys share that name because it carries a wish for strength. He explained why they churn yak butter into the tea to keep warm on the cold steppe, and how a good cup is as important to their nomadic life as a sturdy horse. From our chat—and from watching him beam with pride as he spoke—I learned that naming carries deep meaning in Mongolian culture, that milk tea is more than a drink but a link to centuries-old traditions, and that festivals like Nadam are as much about community stories as they are about wrestling or horse racing.
questions.answer_ch: 在蒙古那达慕节上，我们一行人挤进了一顶改成茶摊的小帐篷里，十岁的蒙古男孩巴图尔正在帮忙端上热气腾腾、咸香奶油味的奶茶。露西和我用小芦苇杯轻啜，巴图尔耐心地教我如何正确地握杯和搅拌奶茶。喝茶间歇，他告诉我他的名字意思是“英雄”或“战士”，因为寓意坚强，不少蒙古男孩都叫这个名字。他还解释了为什么在寒冷的草原上要把牦牛油搅进奶茶里保暖，以及一杯好奶茶对他们的游牧生活有多重要，就像一匹健壮的马一样。通过我们的交谈——以及看他自豪地笑着讲述——我了解到在蒙古文化中取名有深意，奶茶不仅是一种饮品，更是与数百年传统相连的纽带，而那达慕这样的节日，也不仅仅是摔跤或赛马，更是社区故事的聚会。

questions.question_en: How do you and Batul stay in touch or play together after meeting briefly at the festival?
questions.question_ch: 在节日上短暂相遇后，你和巴图尔如何保持联系或一起玩耍？
questions.answer_en: After the festival Batul and I asked our parents to share our contact details so we could stay in touch. I sent him a little postcard I had made showing the wrestling ring and the camel races, and he drew pictures of the archery stalls and mailed them back. Some weekends my dad and I would meet Batul and his mum at Hampstead Heath, where we’d fly kites and share snacks. We also video-call each other once a week and play an online falcon-spotting game together. That way, even though we only saw each other briefly at Naadam, we’ve kept our friendship alive all year round.
questions.answer_ch: 节日过后，我和巴图尔请求父母交换联系方式，以便保持联系。我给他寄了一张自己做的小明信片，上面画了摔跤场和骆驼赛跑的场景；他则画了射箭摊的图寄还给我。有些周末，我和爸爸会在汉普斯特德荒地（Hampstead Heath）与巴图尔和他妈妈见面，一起放风筝、分享零食。我们还每周视频通话一次，一起玩线上猎鹰观察游戏。就这样，虽然我们只在那达慕上短暂相见，却让友谊一年四季都保持着活力。

questions.question_en: What makes Belsize St. George Primary School different from other schools you’ve heard about?
questions.question_ch: 贝尔赛街圣乔治小学与您听说过的其他学校有什么不同？
questions.answer_en: Belsize St. George Primary never feels like an ordinary school because creativity and community pulse through every corner. Each spring the entire campus transforms into Art Week, an open-air gallery where students’ paintings and teachers’ sculptures stand side by side. Every month we “visit” a different continent through colourful stalls, traditional dress, music and world food markets where I’ve proudly sold my own lamb paomo. We learn in partnership with a local nursing home, so our history, science and drama lessons often happen under the same roof as residents whose stories enrich our studies. Class sizes are small, teachers like Ms MacFarlane encourage outdoor learning and even climb mountains themselves, and every child’s work—no matter how messy or wild—is displayed with equal pride. It’s a school where learning feels like an adventure.
questions.answer_ch: 贝尔赛斯圣乔治小学从来不觉得是一所普通的学校，因为创造力和社区精神充满了每一个角落。每年春天，整个校园都会变成艺术周，成为一个露天画廊，学生的画作和老师的雕塑并肩而立。每个月，我们通过色彩缤纷的摊位、传统服饰、音乐和世界美食市场“访问”不同的大陆，在这里，我自豪地出售我的羊肉泡馍。我们与当地的养老院合作学习，因此我们的历史、科学和戏剧课常常与那些丰富我们学习故事的居民在同一屋檐下进行。班级人数少，像麦克法兰女士这样的老师鼓励户外学习，甚至自己爬山，每个孩子的作品——无论多么凌乱或狂野——都同样受到自豪的展示。这是一所让学习感觉像冒险的学校。

questions.question_en: How does the 4–11 age range influence classroom activities, and what do you enjoy most about that grouping?
questions.question_ch: 4到11岁的年龄范围如何影响课堂活动，您最喜欢这个年龄组的什么？
questions.answer_en: Because our school taught children from age four all the way to age eleven, classroom activities always had to suit very different stages of learning: in the mornings we might begin with lively songs and movement games that helped the youngest children learn the alphabet and basic counting, then after that older children would break into small groups to work on more complex stories or science experiments, while the youngest practiced phonics with picture cards. Teachers used colourful visuals and hands-on resources so that the four- and five-year-olds could stay interested, then gradually increased the difficulty so the ten- and eleven-year-olds could tackle longer writing tasks or solve maths problems in pairs. I especially loved how sometimes the older children became helpers, guiding the younger ones through drawing or reading activities; I felt proud explaining a tricky word to a five-year-old or showing an eight-year-old how to share paints fairly. What I enjoyed most about that wide age range was watching everyone learn from each other: the littlest faces brightened whenever they copied an older friend, and the eldest felt grown-up when they offered a helping hand, so our classroom felt more like a big family than a group of isolated ages.
questions.answer_ch: 因为我们的学校从四岁教到十一岁，课堂活动必须适应不同的学习阶段：早上我们可能会用生动的歌曲和运动游戏开始，以帮助最小的孩子学习字母和基本的计数，之后年长的孩子会分成小组，进行更复杂的故事或科学实验，而最年轻的孩子则用图片卡片练习拼读。老师们使用丰富多彩的视觉辅助材料和动手资源，让四岁和五岁的孩子保持兴趣，然后逐渐增加难度，以便十岁和十一岁的孩子可以进行更长的写作任务或两人合作解决数学问题。我特别喜欢的是，有时年长的孩子会成为助手，引导年轻的孩子进行绘画或阅读活动；我为向五岁的孩子解释一个难懂的词或向八岁的孩子展示如何公平地分享颜料而感到自豪。我最喜欢这个广泛年龄段的原因是看到每个人相互学习：最小的孩子在模仿年长的朋友时脸上洋溢着光彩，而最大的孩子在提供帮助时感觉自己变得成熟，因此我们的课堂更像是一个大家庭，而不是一个孤立年龄的群体。

questions.question_en: What subjects or projects do you most look forward to in Key Stage 1, and why?
questions.question_ch: 你在第一阶段最期待哪些科目或项目，为什么？
questions.answer_en: I most look forward to science lessons in Key Stage 1 because I get to do hands-on experiments—like mixing baking soda and vinegar to make fizz or watching seeds sprout in a jar—and I love discovering how the world works. I’m also excited by design and technology projects, especially when we plan and build things—last year I made a paper kite and this year I can’t wait to bake soda bread and learn the chemistry of cooking. Geography appeals to me too, because map skills bring far-away places to life and I daydream about visiting Dorset to hunt fossils just like a little Mary Anning. Art Week is another highlight: I love the freedom to choose any materials and splash paint or weave yarn into my own “Light of the Elves” creations under our teacher’s gentle guidance. Finally, I enjoy computer lessons where I learn simple coding puzzles and logical thinking—it feels like solving a mystery. All these subjects let me combine curiosity, creativity and discovery, which is exactly why I look forward to each new project in Key Stage 1.
questions.answer_ch: 我最期待的就是科学课，因为我可以做动手实验——比如混合小苏打和醋来制造泡沫，或者看种子在罐子里发芽——我喜欢发现世界是如何运作的。我对设计和技术项目也很兴奋，特别是当我们计划和建造东西时——去年我做了一个纸风筝，而今年我迫不及待想烤小苏打面包，学习烹饪的化学。地理也吸引我，因为地图技能让遥远的地方变得栩栩如生，我常常梦想着去多塞特寻找化石，就像小玛丽·安宁一样。艺术周是另一个亮点：我喜欢在老师温柔的指导下自由选择任何材料，溅洒颜料或编织纱线，创作我自己的“精灵之光”。最后，我享受计算机课，学习简单的编码难题和逻辑思维——这就像是在解决一个谜题。所有这些科目让我结合了好奇心、创造力和发现感，这正是我期待每一个新的Key Stage 1项目的原因。

questions.question_en: How does learning in Key Stage 2 build on what you did earlier, and which new challenges excite you?
questions.question_ch: 在关键阶段二的学习是如何建立在你之前的学习基础上的？有哪些新的挑战让你感到兴奋？
questions.answer_en: In Key Stage 1 I spent most days learning to read simple stories, add and subtract numbers up to twenty, explore my local park for plants and minibeasts, draw basic maps and make simple recipes with Mum. In Key Stage 2 I build on those foundations by reading longer chapter books, writing my own multi-paragraph stories, multiplying and dividing larger numbers, learning fractions and decimals, conducting science experiments on electricity and sound, studying the water cycle and classifying living things, interpreting maps with grid references, programming simple stories on the computer and even using more complex tools in design and technology. What excites me most is tackling new challenges such as mastering all my times-tables so I can solve multistep problems in seconds, planning and running my own science investigation from hypothesis to conclusion, writing persuasive essays on historical events, presenting a project at Art Week, debating world issues in PSHE, leading a group in our multicultural festival and learning to weld and drill parts to build my own bookcase—each of these pushes me to use everything I learned before in clever new ways and discover skills I never knew I had.
questions.answer_ch: 在第一阶段，我的大部分时间都用来学习阅读简单故事、加减到二十的数字、在本地公园探索植物和小动物、绘制基本地图以及和妈妈一起制作简单食谱。在第二阶段，我在这些基础上继续发展，通过阅读较长的章节书、写我自己的多段故事、乘法和除法较大的数字、学习分数和小数、进行电和声音的科学实验、研究水循环和分类生物、用网格参考解读地图、在电脑上编程简单故事，甚至使用设计与技术中的更复杂工具。我最兴奋的是面临新的挑战，比如掌握所有的乘法表，以便我能在几秒钟内解决多步骤问题，规划和进行我自己的科学调查，从假设到结论，撰写关于历史事件的说服性论文，在艺术周展示项目，在个人、社会和健康教育课上辩论全球问题，领导我们多元文化节的一个小组，以及学习焊接和钻孔部件来建造自己的书架——每一项都促使我以聪明的新方式运用之前学到的知识，并发现我从未意识到的技能。

questions.question_en: During Art Week, what is your favorite medium to work with—paints, clay, or something else—and why?
questions.question_ch: 在艺术周期间，您最喜欢使用哪种媒介——油漆、黏土，还是其他什么——为什么？
questions.answer_en: Last Art Week I discovered that paint was my favourite medium because it allowed me to move faster than clay or pencils ever could. In Uncle Owen’s studio I gathered jars of acrylic and squeezed colours onto scraps of cardboard or canvas boards then flung and smeared them with my hands, spoons, or even a twig until shapes and patterns emerged that surprised me. Painting felt wild and free, as if the energy inside me poured out in streaks of red, blue, and yellow, and no brush stroke was ever wrong. I tried modelling clay too, but clay asked me to be neat and precise, whereas paint celebrated my biggest feelings in one glorious splatter. I still keep a corner in the studio marked “my space” and cover it in every colour I could find.
questions.answer_ch: 上一个艺术周，我发现油漆是我最喜欢的媒介，因为它让我比粘土或铅笔更快地表达。在欧文叔叔的工作室里，我收集了很多丙烯颜料，把颜色挤到纸板或画布上，然后用手、勺子甚至树枝抹涂，直到出现让我惊讶的形状和图案。绘画感觉狂野而自由，仿佛我内心的能量在红色、蓝色和黄色的笔触中倾泻，没有任何一笔是错误的。我也尝试过模具粘土，但粘土要求我做到整齐和精准，而油漆则以一个辉煌的飞溅庆祝我最强烈的感受。我仍然在工作室保留了一个标记为“我的空间”的角落，用我能找到的每一种颜色覆盖它。

questions.question_en: Can you describe a memorable project you created during last Art Week and what inspired it?
questions.question_ch: 你可以描述一下你在上一次艺术周期间创造的一个难忘项目，以及是什么激发了这个项目吗？
questions.answer_en: During last Art Week I built an interactive installation called “Skyward Return” inspired by the night I felt myself float to the ceiling in my great-grandmother Orla’s house and the mysterious moment she told me to come back. I suspended a dozen hand-painted cloud shapes from the gallery ceiling using clear fishing line and brushed them with pearly silver and pale blue highlights so they seemed to glow under the lights. On each cloud I drew tiny pencil sketches of what I remembered seeing from above—everyone’s heads, the heater by which Orla sat, even the spiral staircase—and attached small speakers that played my whispered question, “Where do you wish to return?” when visitors reached up and gently tapped them. The project was memorable because it transformed a private, surreal memory into a shared dream-like experience and invited people to explore their own feelings about home, memory and the pull of gravity.
questions.answer_ch: 在上一个艺术周，我制作了一个名为“向天空归去”的互动装置，它的灵感来自于我曾在曾祖母奥拉的家中感受到自己飘浮到天花板上的那个夜晚，以及她神秘地告诉我回来的时刻。我用透明渔线将十几个手绘的云形状悬挂在画廊天花板上，并用珍珠银和淡蓝色的高光刷涂，使它们在灯光下看起来像是发光的。在每朵云上，我画了我从上方看到的记忆中的小铅笔素描——每个人的头、奥拉坐的加热器，甚至是螺旋楼梯——并附上小扬声器，当访客伸手轻轻敲击时，会播放我低声的问题：“你希望回到哪里？”这个项目令人难忘，因为它将一个私人而超现实的记忆转化为一个共享的梦幻般的体验，并邀请人们探索他们对于家、记忆和重力吸引力的感受。

questions.question_en: What was the most impressive exhibition or performance you saw on campus, and how did it make you feel?
questions.question_ch: 你在校园里看到的最令人印象深刻的展览或表演是什么？它让你有什么感受？
questions.answer_en: The exhibition that impressed me most was an installation called “Contact” during our spring Art Week, created by my classmate Maeve and me. The piece looked like a glowing, skeletal shell of an otherworldly creature, built from layers of thin white paper you could actually slip inside. Seeing it stretched across the lawn felt like discovering a giant silver cocoon in the middle of our school grounds. Walking into it, I felt my heart pound with wonder and a little trepidation, as though I were stepping into someone’s secret dream. It made me feel both small and infinite at once, as if our imaginations could shape reality. Never before had I believed art could transport me so completely; in that moment I understood how powerful creativity can be at making the invisible suddenly visible.
questions.answer_ch: 给我留下最深刻印象的展览是我们春季艺术周期间，由我的同学梅芙和我创作的装置作品《接触》。这个作品看起来像是一个发光的、骷髅般的外星生物的壳，由层层薄薄的白纸构成，你实际上可以走进去。看到它延伸在草坪上，感觉就像是在学校的中央发现了一个巨大的银色茧。走进去时，我感到心跳加速，既有惊奇又有些忐忑，仿佛我正在踏入某人的秘密梦境。这让我同时感到渺小和无限，好像我们的想象力能够塑造现实。我从未相信过艺术能够如此完全地把我带入另一个境界；在那一刻，我明白了创造力在让无形变得突然可见时是多么强大。

questions.question_en: Have you ever participated in one of those performances? If so, what role did you have and how did you prepare?
questions.question_ch: 你曾参加过其中一场表演吗？如果有，你扮演了什么角色，准备了些什么？
questions.answer_en: Yes—I once took part in the Year 3 Arts Week play called “Our Garden Planet,” and I got to be a honeybee on stage. My role was to buzz around collecting pollen and then explain to the audience how bees help flowers grow. To prepare I spent afternoons in Owen’s studio fashioning my own wings from wire and painted card, I practised buzzing and “landing” motions in the garden so they looked smooth, and each evening I stood in front of Dad and recited my short lines—“Without bees there’d be no apples!”—until I had them perfectly memorised and could say them loudly without forgetting a word. Monica our music teacher even taught me a simple rhythm on a djembe drum so I could join the ensemble, and practising with Gerald in the playground until I felt truly confident made the performance feel like flying.
questions.answer_ch: 是的，我曾经参与过三年级的艺术周表演，名为《我们的花园星球》，我在台上扮演了一只蜜蜂。我的角色是围绕着飞舞，收集花粉，然后向观众解释蜜蜂如何帮助花朵生长。为了准备这个角色，我在欧文的工作室中花了几个下午，用铁丝和涂色的纸板制作了我的翅膀，我在花园里练习飞行和“着陆”的动作，让它们看起来更自然，每晚我都会站在爸爸面前背诵我的短句——“没有蜜蜂就没有苹果！”——直到我完全记住，能够高声说出来而不忘记任何一个字。我们的音乐老师莫妮卡甚至教我在非洲鼓上打出简单的节奏，以便我能加入合奏，我还在操场上与杰拉德一起练习，直到我感到真正自信，让演出像是在飞翔。

questions.question_en: Which cuisine stood out most to you at the International food market, and did you try any new dishes?
questions.question_ch: 在国际美食市场上，哪种 cuisine 给你留下了最深刻的印象，你尝试了哪些新菜肴吗？
questions.answer_en: The cuisine that really stole my attention at the International Food Market was the Iranian stall – I’d never seen anything like lamb paomo before, and its tender shredded lamb swimming in a fragrant broth with torn flatbread was simply unforgettable. I’d helped Jessica prepare it at home, but tasting it alongside everyone else that day made it feel even more special. I also couldn’t resist sampling a bowl of Tom Yum soup from the Thai booth and a few pieces of Turkish baklava from another stall – the zing of the chilli and lemongrass in the Tom Yum was completely new to me, and the honeyed sweetness of the baklava was a delightful surprise!
questions.answer_ch: 在国际美食市场上真正吸引我注意的是伊朗摊位——我从未见过像羊肉泡馍这样的食物，嫩滑的 shredded 羊肉漂浮在香气四溢的汤中，与撕成片的薄饼搭配，简直令人难忘。我曾在家帮杰西卡准备过，但那天与大家一起品尝使它显得更加特别。我还忍不住尝试了泰国摊位的汤姆汤和另一个摊位的几块土耳其巴克拉瓦——汤姆汤中的辣椒和香茅的味道对我来说是全新的，而巴克拉瓦的蜜糖甜味则让我感到惊喜！

questions.question_en: How did you help with the International food market—cooking, serving, or telling guests about the dishes?
questions.question_ch: 你是怎样帮助国际美食市场的——是烹饪、服务，还是向客人介绍菜肴？
questions.answer_en: I remember arriving before dawn in our school kitchen alongside Chen Jia’s mum, cracking the lamb into the simmering broth and testing its seasoning until it smelled just like Grandma’s. Once our stall was set up on the lawn, I ladled the rich soup over torn chunks of flatbread, stacking bowls on a warming tray. As the queue formed I switched to serving mode, balancing two bowls at a time, greeting each guest with a small bow and a quick, “This one’s lamb pao mo—hearty, warm, full of onions and cumin.” Between pouring broth and counting change I shifted into storyteller mode, telling curious shoppers about how the dish comes from Xi’an’s winding alleys, how its soft bread soaks up the broth, and how each spoonful was inspired by Chen Jia’s family recipe back home in Shaanxi. By the end of the day I was exhausted but beaming: we’d sold every bowl, and I’d made new friends by sharing a piece of our world.
questions.answer_ch: 我记得在黎明前和陈佳的妈妈一起到学校厨房，往炖汤里放羊肉，调试调味，直到它的味道就像奶奶做的一样。当我们的摊位在草坪上搭好后，我把浓汤舀在撕成块的平面饼上，把碗堆在加热托盘上。随着队伍的形成，我进入了服务模式，双手端着两个碗，一边向每位客人微微鞠躬，一边快速说道：“这个是羊肉泡馍——丰盛、温暖，充满洋葱和孜然。”在倒汤和找零之间，我转变成故事讲述者，向好奇的顾客讲述这道菜来自西安曲折的小巷，柔软的面饼如何吸收汤汁，以及每一勺都受到陈佳家乡陕西的家常菜谱启发。到一天结束时，我已经精疲力竭，但满脸笑容：我们卖完了每一碗，我通过分享我们的世界交到了新朋友。

questions.question_en: How does having equal display space for students and teachers encourage you to share your work more confidently?
questions.question_ch: 在学生和老师之间拥有平等的展示空间如何鼓励你更自信地分享你的作品？
questions.answer_en: When I see my painting hung next to my teacher’s work, it makes me feel that my ideas matter just as much as theirs and that I’m part of a community of creators rather than just a pupil being judged. Sharing the same display space removes the invisible barrier between “student” and “expert,” reminding me that teachers once experimented and made mistakes too. That sense of equality empowers me to take more risks, try bolder ideas, and trust that my voice is valued—and because I’m not afraid of being “smaller” or “less skilled,” I can share my work with genuine confidence.
questions.answer_ch: 当我看到我的画挂在老师的作品旁边时，我感到我的想法和他们一样重要，我是创作者社区的一部分，而不仅仅是一个被评判的学生。共享同一个展示空间消除了“学生”和“专家”之间的无形障碍，让我想起教师们也曾经实验和犯错。这种平等感使我更有勇气去冒险，尝试更大胆的想法，并相信我的声音是被重视的——因为我不怕自己“更小”或“技术更差”，我能够以真正的自信分享我的作品。

questions.question_en: What piece of your work did you find most rewarding to display alongside your teachers’ creations, and why?
questions.question_ch: 您在与老师的作品一起展示时，觉得哪一件作品最有成就感，为什么？
questions.answer_en: The work I found most rewarding to display alongside my teachers’ creations was the installation Maeve and I called “Contact,” a life-sized silhouette of Hassel constructed from sheer paper panels and repurposed calligraphy sheets. Seeing it placed in the school exhibition space right next to Phyllis’s bold mixed-media sculptures and hearing visitors walk through and marvel at how light played across those translucent surfaces made me feel that my very personal vision—born from a dream—had earned a place of equal respect among the adults’ art.
questions.answer_ch: 我发现最值得与老师的作品一起展示的是我和梅夫称之为“接触”的装置作品，它是由透明纸板和再利用的书法纸张构成的哈塞尔的真人大小轮廓。看到它被放置在学校展览空间，紧挨着菲莉丝大胆的混合媒介雕塑，听到参观者走过时惊叹于光线如何在那些半透明的表面上游走，让我感觉到我这种源于梦境的个人视觉在成人艺术中获得了同样的尊重。

questions.question_en: How do you celebrate the New Year Holiday with your family, and what traditions do you enjoy most?
questions.question_ch: 你们是如何和家人一起庆祝新年假期的，最喜欢哪些传统？
questions.answer_en: On New Year’s Eve I stayed up with my family in our living room eating Mom’s homemade mince pies and Dad’s whole-wheat marmalade toast while sipping warm hot chocolate spiced with cinnamon; at midnight we opened the front door to hear fireworks echoing across London, hugged each other and shouted “Happy New Year!” before rushing back inside to write our resolutions in little notebooks—mine always ended with a sketch of a telescope to remind me to explore more—and pin them to the fridge. On New Year’s Day morning we bundled up and walked together to Hampstead Heath with our binoculars to spot the first birds of the year—this time I saw a jay—then returned to Grandma and Grandpa’s house for a late breakfast of lamb soup and scones with Devonshire cream, followed by a marathon of Rummikub and Snakes & Ladders around the kitchen table. The traditions I enjoy most are the moment of fireworks at midnight, the quiet cold-air birdwatching that feels like discovering a new world, and the laughter and playfulness of our first family games in the bright new year.
questions.answer_ch: 在除夕夜，我和家人一起熬夜，在我们的客厅里吃着妈妈做的自制肉馅饼和爸爸的全麦橘子酱吐司，喝着加了肉桂的温热热巧克力；午夜时分，我们打开前门，听到烟花在伦敦的回声，互相拥抱并大喊“新年快乐！”然后急忙回到屋里，在小本子上写下我们的决心—我的总是以望远镜的素描结束，以提醒我多多探索—然后把它们贴在冰箱上。在新年第一天的早晨，我们穿上厚衣服，带着双筒望远镜一起走到汉普斯特德公园，寻找新年的第一只鸟—这次我看到了蓝鸟—然后返回奶奶和爷爷的家享用晚早餐，羊肉汤搭配德文奶油的司康，随后围坐在厨房桌旁，进行一轮“拉米库”和“蛇梯”马拉松。我最享受的传统是午夜烟花的那一刻，感受着在寒冷空气中观察鸟类的宁静，那种感觉就像是在发现一个新世界，还有在崭新的年头里，家人初次游戏时的欢声笑语与嬉戏。

questions.question_en: Do you watch the Australian Open at home? If so, which match or player did you find most exciting this year?
questions.question_ch: 你在家里看澳大利亚网球公开赛吗？如果看，您今年觉得哪个比赛或球员最令人兴奋？
questions.answer_en: Yes—I always tune in at home with Dad, even though the live matches start at dawn. This year the most thrilling was the men’s semi-final between Novak Djokovic and Stefanos Tsitsipas: they battled for five grueling hours in sweltering conditions, trading lightning-fast cross-court rallies that made my heart pound so hard I nearly dropped my mug. On match point, Djokovic sprinted to the net and unleashed a volley so precise it left me breathless, and I couldn’t stop cheering. Watching those two giants push every sinew to conjure brilliance with their rackets felt like witnessing pure alchemy—and I’ve never felt tennis so alive!
questions.answer_ch: 是的——我总是和爸爸在家里一起收看比赛，即使直播比赛是在黎明时分开始。今年最令人兴奋的是诺瓦克·德约科维奇与斯特法诺斯·西西帕斯之间的男子半决赛：他们在炎热的条件下拼搏了五个小时，进行着快速的斜线对拉，让我的心跳得如此剧烈，我差点掉了杯子。在比赛点上，德约科维奇冲向网口，发出了一记如此精准的截击，令我喘不过气来，忍不住欢呼。看到这两位巨头将每一根肌肉都用来用球拍创造辉煌，感觉就像目睹了纯粹的炼金术——我从未感受到如此生动的网球！

questions.question_en: What do you usually do during the Half-term break—travel, visit friends, or try a new activity?
questions.question_ch: 你通常在半学期假期做什么——旅行、拜访朋友还是尝试新活动？
questions.answer_en: During half-term I usually mix a few favourite things: we might travel for a short family trip—sometimes up to Devon or to stay with Grandma and Grandpa in the Cotswolds—then I squeeze in an adventure, like visiting the Natural History Museum to see fossils or trying a new activity such as archery or a science workshop. I also love spending a morning at the London Zoo or Richmond Park with Gerald and Leslie, watching animals and spotting birds, and in the evenings I’ll cook a special meal or experiment with a new recipe. If I’m home, I’ll dedicate time to my art projects in Uncle Irvin’s studio, or rant pages in my notebook about whatever I’ve been reading. Half-term always feels like a mini-holiday—a chance to explore, learn, create and recharge before school starts again.
questions.answer_ch: 在半学期的时候，我通常会混合一些我喜欢的事情：我们可能会进行一次短途家庭旅行——有时去德文郡，或者去科茨沃尔德和爷爷奶奶待一段时间——然后我会挤出时间去冒险，比如参观自然历史博物馆看化石，或者尝试新的活动，比如射箭或科学工作坊。我还喜欢和杰拉尔德、莱斯利一起在伦敦动物园或里士满公园度过一个早晨，观察动物和观鸟，晚上我会做一顿特别的饭或尝试新的食谱。如果我在家，我会在叔叔欧文的工作室里 dedicat 股票来我的艺术项目，或是在我的笔记本上写下关于我所阅读内容的想法。半学期总让我感觉像是一个迷你假期——一个在学校重新开始之前探索、学习、创造和充电的机会。

questions.question_en: Which book do you dress up as or talk about on World Book Day, and why is it special to you?
questions.question_ch: 你在世界读书日扮演哪个角色或者讨论哪本书，为什么它对你特别重要？
questions.answer_en: On World Book Day I always choose to talk about “Charlotte’s Web” by E.B. White. I love dressing up as Charlotte—complete with eight silvery legs—because it’s the story of a spider who saves her friend Wilbur the pig by writing words in her web. That book taught me more about friendship, courage and how even the smallest creatures can make a huge difference. It’s special to me because I’ve spent hours watching real spiders in my garden and in Irvin’s studio, and whenever I read Charlotte’s gentle, clever voice I feel like I’m honoring all those little animals I care about—and remembering that true loyalty can change the world.
questions.answer_ch: 在世界图书日，我总是选择谈论E.B. 怀特的《夏洛的网》。我喜欢打扮成夏洛，身上还要有八条银色的腿，因为这是一个关于一只蜘蛛通过在网上写字来拯救她的朋友小猪威尔伯的故事。这本书让我更懂得友谊、勇气，以及即使是最小的生物也能带来巨大的改变。它对我来说很特别，因为我曾在花园和欧文的工作室花费了很多小时观察真正的蜘蛛，每当我读到夏洛温柔而机智的声音时，我就觉得我在尊重那些我关心的小动物，并且记住真正的忠诚可以改变世界。

questions.question_en: How do you celebrate St Patrick’s Day—do you wear something green, learn about Irish culture, or join a parade?
questions.question_ch: 你是如何庆祝圣帕特里克节的——你穿绿色的衣服、了解爱尔兰文化，还是参加游行？
questions.answer_en: I wore my green jumper and pinned a little paper shamrock to my lapel then headed off to school where we gathered in assembly to hear stories of St Patrick driving snakes from Ireland and learned a few words of Gaelic; after classes I helped Grandma Mary bake her crisp soda bread studded with oats so it smelled of home, then we walked together to Trafalgar Square to watch the Irish dance troupe step out an energetic jig; later I spent a happy hour trying to mimic their footwork in our living room, then back home I read a chapter about leprechauns from my mythology book and tasted my first spoonful of champ—mashed potatoes with kale—before finishing the day by decorating shamrock-shaped cookies with green icing alongside Mum, Dad and Lucy while we swapped fun facts about Ireland’s patron saint.
questions.answer_ch: 我穿上了绿色的毛衣，在我的领口别上了一片小纸质的三叶草，然后出发去学校，我们在集会上聚集在一起，听关于圣帕特里克驱赶爱尔兰蛇的故事，并学习了一些盖尔语的单词；下课后，我帮助玛丽奶奶烤她的脆饼干，里面夹着燕麦，散发着家的气息，然后我们一起走到特拉法加广场，观看爱尔兰舞蹈团表演充满活力的舞蹈；后来，我花了一个愉快的小时在我们的客厅里模仿他们的脚步，回到家后我阅读了一章关于小精灵的神话书，还尝了第一口章鱼土豆泥——和羽衣甘蓝混合的土豆泥——然后和妈妈、爸爸、露西一起用绿色糖霜装饰三叶草形状的饼干，同时交换有关爱尔兰守护圣人的有趣事实。

questions.question_en: What do you do to show appreciation on Mothering Sunday, and what gift or gesture makes your mother happiest?
questions.question_ch: 你在母亲节做些什么来表达感激之情，什么礼物或举动最让你的妈妈开心？
questions.answer_en: On Mothering Sunday I always take over the kitchen duties so Mum can sleep in a little longer. I wake up early, make her favourite Bonne Maman marmalade on whole-wheat toast, brew her a pot of Earl Grey and bring it to her in bed on a tray with a small vase of daisies I picked from our garden. Later I help Dad tidy the house and do Luthien’s bedtime routine so Mum can relax with a good book or a film. The gift that makes Mum happiest isn’t anything expensive but something I’ve made myself – last year I pressed and dried spring flowers to make pretty bookmarks and she was overjoyed. She always says it’s the thought and the time I’ve spent that means the most to her.
questions.answer_ch: 在母亲节那天，我总是承担厨房的工作，这样妈妈可以多睡一会儿。我早起，给她做她最喜欢的全麦吐司配Bonne Maman橘子酱，泡一壶伯爵茶，然后端到她床上，配上我从花园里摘的一小瓶雏菊。之后我帮助爸爸打扫房子，并照顾露西恩的睡前程序，这样妈妈就可以放松一下，看看好书或电影。让妈妈最开心的礼物并不是昂贵的，而是我亲手做的东西—去年我压制并干燥了春天的花朵，做成了漂亮的书签，她非常高兴。她总是说，最让她感动的是我的心意和我花的时间。

questions.question_en: What is your favorite activity or trip during the Easter Holidays, and how do you keep entertained for nearly three weeks?
questions.question_ch: 你在复活节假期最喜欢的活动或旅行是什么？你怎么让自己在将近三周的时间里保持娱乐？
questions.answer_en: My very favorite Easter adventure was our two‐week trip to Yellowstone National Park—waking up to steam rising from geysers, spotting bison on the plains and camping under the stars felt like living inside a nature documentary. To stay busy across those three weeks, I mix mini-expeditions with home-grown projects: I map out fossil hunts on the Jurassic Coast, lead “soap-making labs” in Uncle Irvin’s studio (with weird ingredients like coffee grounds and mint leaves), bake new recipes from my cooking books, build wild LEGO castles, sketch the birds I spot in Hampstead Heath, practice little science experiments with Gerald, and squeeze in afternoon visits to Kew Gardens or the Natural History Museum. Every day I plan something different—board games and kite-flying with Leslie, cooking workshops for Sophie, even impromptu theater rehearsals with Phyllis in the garage—so the long holiday never feels dull.
questions.answer_ch: 我最喜欢的复活节冒险是我们为期两周的黄石国家公园之旅——在喷泉冒烟中醒来，在平原上发现野牛，星空下露营，感觉就像生活在一部自然纪录片中。为了在这三周里保持忙碌，我将迷你探险与自制项目结合起来：我在侏罗纪海岸规划化石猎取，带领在叔叔欧文的工作室里进行的“皂化实验”（使用咖啡渣和薄荷叶等奇怪的成分），从我的烹饪书中烘焙新食谱，搭建狂野的乐高城堡，素描我在汉普斯特德公园遇到的鸟类，与杰拉尔德一起进行小科学实验，抽空去国家植物园或自然历史博物馆。在每一天，我都计划不同的活动——和莱斯利玩桌游和放风筝，为索菲举办烹饪工作坊，甚至在车库里与菲利斯即兴排练戏剧——因此这个漫长的假期从来不觉得无聊。

questions.question_en: Does your family have any special traditions for Good Friday—quiet reflection, cooking certain foods, or attending a service?
questions.question_ch: 你们家在耶稣受难日有什么特别的传统吗——静默反思、烹饪特定食物或参加礼拜？
questions.answer_en: In our family Good Friday is always a quiet, reflective day: we begin by attending the 3 pm service at our local Anglican church, processing the Stations of the Cross and listening to the choir’s somber hymns. Once home we turn off screens and gather in the living room, lighting a single candle and saying a short prayer together. Mum then prepares a simple fish stew—usually cod with potatoes and parsley—and we share hot-cross buns for dessert, each split and lightly spread with marmalade rather than butter. No meat is served and we keep the meal humble and unadorned. Some years we follow this with a silent walk on Hampstead Heath, binoculars slung over our shoulders so we’re ready to spot returning spring birds, and sketch clouds or wildflowers in our notebooks instead of talking. It’s a simple, unchanging ritual that always makes the day feel special.
questions.answer_ch: 在我们家，耶稣受难日总是一个安静、反思的日子：我们会参加当地英国教会下午3点的礼拜，走过耶稣受难的路径，聆听合唱团忧伤的圣歌。回到家后，我们关闭屏幕，聚集在客厅，点燃一支蜡烛，一起简单祈祷。妈妈随后会准备一道简单的鱼炖菜——通常是鳕鱼配土豆和香菜——甜点则是热交叉面包，每个面包切开，轻轻抹上橘子酱而不是黄油。不提供肉类，我们保持这顿饭的朴素与简约。有些年，我们会在汉普斯特德荒野进行一次沉默的散步，望远镜搭在肩上，以便准备观察返回的春鸟，并在笔记本上素描云朵或野花，而不是交谈。这是一个简单、毫无变化的仪式，总让这一天显得特别。

questions.question_en: What is your favorite part of Easter Sunday—egg hunts, family meals, or attending a celebration?
questions.question_ch: 复活节星期天你最喜欢的部分是什么——寻找彩蛋、家庭聚餐还是参加庆祝活动？
questions.answer_en: My favorite part of Easter Sunday is the egg hunt—there’s something about scouring the garden for hidden treasures that makes me feel like a tiny explorer mapping uncharted territory. I love the moment I spot a brightly painted egg tucked beneath a rosebush or nestled in the crook of a low branch, the same thrill I feel when I discover a rare beetle or peek at a nest through my binoculars. Once the hunt ends, though, I savor our family meal almost as much: the way the lamb soup warms my hands, the careful ceremony of passing plates, and the laughter that fills the room as we compare our finds. And attending the church celebration early in the morning ties it all together—a quiet chance to reflect before the day’s adventures—so really, it’s the hunt that sets the whole day in motion, and everything that follows feels even richer because of it.
questions.answer_ch: 我最喜欢复活节星期天的部分是寻找彩蛋——在花园里寻找隐藏的宝藏让我感觉像一位微小的探险家，在未知的领域中探索。我喜欢在玫瑰灌木下或低树枝的弯处发现一个色彩鲜艳的彩蛋的那一刻，那种发现稀有甲虫或通过望远镜窥视鸟巢时的兴奋感一样。不过，一旦寻找结束，我同样享受我们全家的餐顿：羔羊汤温暖我的双手，传递盘子的细致仪式，以及我们在比较收获时充满欢笑的房间。清晨参加教会的庆祝活动将这些都联系在一起——在一天的冒险之前，安静地反思的机会——所以，实际上，正是这个寻找活动开启了整个星期天，之后的一切因为这个活动而显得更加丰富。

questions.question_en: How do you learn about St George’s Day at school—stories, plays, or assemblies—and what do you find most interesting?
questions.question_ch: 你在学校怎么了解圣乔治节—通过故事、戏剧还是集会—你觉得什么最有趣？
questions.answer_en: At school we usually mark St George’s Day with a special assembly where our teacher tells the story of St George and the Dragon, then in history and drama lessons we act out key scenes—complete with cardboard shields and a “dragon” puppet—and in art we design our own red-and-white Cross of St George flags and heraldic shields; what I find most interesting is how a simple tale of one man’s courage against a fearsome beast can become such a lasting national symbol, and how, as we don medieval costumes and play the roles, we feel connected to a legend that’s more than a thousand years old.
questions.answer_ch: 在学校，我们通常通过一个特别的集会来庆祝圣乔治节，在那里老师讲述圣乔治与龙的故事，然后在历史和戏剧课上，我们表演关键场景——配有纸板盾牌和“龙”玩偶——在艺术课上，我们设计自己的红白色圣乔治十字旗和徽章；我最感兴趣的是，如何一个关于人们勇敢对抗可怕野兽的简单故事，能成为如此持久的国家象征，以及当我们穿上中世纪服装并扮演角色时，如何感受到与这个已有一千多年历史的传奇的联系。

questions.question_en: How do you spend the Early May Bank Holiday—family picnic, local festival, or just relaxing at home?
questions.question_ch: 你如何度过五月初的银行假期——家庭野餐、当地节日，还是在家放松？
questions.answer_en: I woke up early on the Early May Bank Holiday, and after Dad and I packed a basket of whole-wheat toast with Bonne Maman marmalade, soda bread from Grandma and a flask of mint tea, we set off to Hampstead Heath for a family picnic. Lying on the grass with Lucien, I watched woodpeckers and sparrowhawks through my binoculars while Dad and Mum relaxed under the shade of an oak. In the afternoon we strolled over to the village green where Morris dancers twirled ribbons around a maypole, and a small fair buzzed with stalls selling homemade lemonade, cheese pasties and seed-bombs to help plant wildflowers. By early evening we were all happily tired, so we headed home to curl up on the sofa with “Big Questions from Little People,” and I fell asleep thinking about where my next adventure might be.
questions.answer_ch: 我在五一假期的早晨醒来，和爸爸一起准备了一篮全麦吐司、Bonne Maman的果酱、奶奶做的苏打面包和一瓶薄荷茶，便出发去汉普斯特德荒野进行家庭野餐。躺在草地上和Lucien一起，我通过望远镜观看啄木鸟和麻雀鹰，而爸爸和妈妈则在橡树的阴凉处放松。下午，我们漫步到村庄绿地，看到莫里斯舞者在五月柱周围旋转缎带，小集市里熙熙攘攘，出售自制柠檬水、奶酪馅饼和帮助种植野花的种子炸弹。到了傍晚，我们都感到愉快地疲惫，所以我们回家蜷缩在沙发上，边看《小人物的大问题》，边想着我的下一个冒险可能会在哪里就睡着了。

questions.question_en: What special event or outing do you and your family plan for the Spring Bank Holiday each year?
questions.question_ch: 你和你的家人每年春季银行假期计划什么特别活动或外出？
questions.answer_en: Every Spring Bank Holiday our family always packs a picnic, loads up Dad’s binoculars and our kites, and drives out to Richmond Park. We spend the day on the grass watching the wild deer wander through the mist, exploring ant-hill colonies and flying our kites on the wide open fields. It’s become our special holiday tradition—fresh air, deer spotting and kite-flying make the long May weekend feel truly magical.
questions.answer_ch: 每年的春季银行假期，我们全家总是准备一次野餐，带上爸爸的望远镜和我们的风筝，开车去里士满公园。我们在草地上度过一天，看着野鹿在雾中徘徊，探索蚁丘群，在宽阔的田野上放风筝。这已成为我们特别的假期传统——新鲜空气、观察鹿和放风筝让漫长的五月周末感觉格外神奇。

questions.question_en: Do you follow the French Open tennis tournament? If so, which player’s style do you admire most and why?
questions.question_ch: 你关注法国网球公开赛吗？如果是的话，你最欣赏哪位球员的风格，为什么？
questions.answer_en: I did follow the French Open this year, mostly watching matches live with Dad on TV. I admired Rafael Nadal’s style most of all because on clay he moves like it’s part of him—he slides into every shot with incredible balance, digs balls out from impossible angles, and never seems to lose belief even when the rallies stretch on forever. His heavy topspin forehand felt almost magical as it dipped low over the net and kicked up high, and every time he pumped his fist after a point I felt I’d just witnessed something heroic. Though I’d given up playing tennis myself, watching Nadal made me remember why I fell in love with the sport in the first place: it’s about tenacity, grace under pressure, and treating every point as worth fighting for.
questions.answer_ch: 我今年跟随法国公开赛，主要在电视上和爸爸一起观看比赛。我最欣赏拉斐尔·纳达尔的风格，因为在红土场上，他的移动就像是身体的一部分——他以令人难以置信的平衡滑步击球，从不可能的角度挖出球来，即使在长时间的拉锯战中也从不失去信心。他的重上旋正手击球几乎是魔幻的，低低地越过网后又高高弹起，每当他在得分后握紧拳头时，我都感觉自己目睹了什么英雄般的瞬间。尽管我自己已经放弃了打网球，观看纳达尔让我想起了我为什么会爱上这项运动：这关乎韧性、在压力下的优雅，以及把每一个分数都看作值得争取的战斗。

questions.question_en: What do you enjoy doing with your father on Father’s Day, and what gift did you choose for him this year?
questions.question_ch: 你在父亲节喜欢和爸爸做什么，今年为他选择了什么礼物？
questions.answer_en: I love spending Father’s Day with Dad out in Hampstead Heath, binoculars around our necks, spotting birds and red kites, then settling on the grass for his favorite picnic—cheese sandwiches and lemonade. This year I made him a jar of my own marmalade (the best organic oranges I could find) and wrapped it in a hand-drawn label. He said it was the tastiest breakfast gift he’d ever had, and we ate toast together while he told me stories about his childhood hikes.
questions.answer_ch: 我喜欢和爸爸在汉普斯特德公园度过父亲节，脖子上挂着望远镜，观察鸟类和红鸢，随后在草地上享受他最爱的野餐——奶酪三明治和柠檬水。今年我给他做了一罐自己的橘子酱（我找到了最好的有机橙子），还用手绘的标签包裹起来。他说这是他吃过的最美味的早餐礼物，我们一边吃吐司一边聊他童年远足的故事。

questions.question_en: Have you ever watched Wimbledon live or on TV? Which match or competitor left the biggest impression on you?
questions.question_ch: 你曾经在现场或电视上观看温布尔登吗？哪场比赛或哪位选手给你留下了最深刻的印象？
questions.answer_en: Yes, I’ve watched Wimbledon on TV each summer with my dad—and once we even managed to score tickets to sit in the stands for a day-session match. The player who’s stayed with me most is Andy Murray. I remember the first time I saw him play a full five-set final: how every brick-hard backhand and every never-give-up sprint across the court felt like he was carrying the hopes of every Brit in the crowd. His grit, determination and sportsmanship—always applauding his opponent at the net, no matter the score—showed me that winning isn’t just about the trophy but about doing your very best and respecting the game.
questions.answer_ch: 是的，我每年夏天都会和我爸爸在电视上看温布尔登——有一次我们甚至成功地买到了票，在看台上观看了一场日间比赛。我印象最深刻的球员是安迪·穆雷。我记得第一次看到他打完整个五盘决赛：每一次坚硬的反手击球和每一次不放弃地冲刺都让我感觉他承载着每位观众的希望。他的韧性、决心和体育精神——无论比分如何，总是在网上为对手喝彩——让我明白，胜利不仅仅是奖杯，更是尽己所能、尊重比赛。

questions.question_en: What is your favorite way to start the Summer Holidays—special trip, sleep-ins, or spending time with friends?
questions.question_ch: 你最喜欢怎样开始暑假——特别的旅行、睡懒觉还是和朋友们共度时光？
questions.answer_en: I always wake up with a flutter of excitement on the last day of school, not because I can sleep late but because Summer Holidays truly begin when Dad, Mum and I pile into the car and head to Devon. There’s something magical about the two-hour drive across green fields, the first glimpse of the Jurassic Coast, and the promise of fossil digs on the sandy shore. I pack my notebook, binoculars and hammer with reverent care and spend hours poking in rock pools for ichthyosaur bones, then at night pitch our tent under the Milky Way in the New Forest, waiting for the Perseid meteors to streak overhead. Devon means freedom: building sandcastle laboratories, tasting Mum’s picnics by hidden coves, and watching Dad’s face light up at every new fossil discovery. No lie-ins or backyard games ever bring me closer to summer than those first mornings in Devon, where every sunrise is a fresh invitation to explore, learn and feel utterly, wonderfully alive.
questions.answer_ch: 我总是在学校最后一天兴奋地醒来，不是因为可以睡懒觉，而是因为当爸爸、妈妈和我挤进车里前往德文时，暑假真正开始了。那两小时穿越绿田的车程充满了魔力，第一次看到侏罗纪海岸，以及在沙滩上挖掘化石的美好承诺。我小心翼翼地打包我的笔记本、望远镜和锤子，花几个小时在岩石池中寻找鱼龙的骨头，晚上在新森林的银河下搭帐篷，等待英仙座流星划过天际。德文意味着自由：建造沙堡实验室，品尝妈妈在隐蔽海湾享用的野餐，看到爸爸在每一项新化石发现时脸上洋溢的笑容。没有什么比德文的清晨更让我感受到夏天的气息，每一个日出都是一次全新的探索、学习和感受生命的邀请，完全、精彩地活着。

questions.question_en: What memory stands out from your Devon vacation this July, and what new experience did you have there?
questions.question_ch: 你在今年七月的德文假期中最令人难忘的记忆是什么？你在那里经历了什么新的体验？
questions.answer_en: The memory that still makes my heart race is the moment I crouched on the shingle at Lulworth Cove and held my very first genuine fossil in my palm—a flaked piece of ichthyosaur bone I’d just prised from the rock with Dad’s little hammer and chisel. I’d never felt such a thrill, as though I’d unearthed a real treasure from the deep past, and it made me imagine Mary Anning herself cheering me on. The new experience wasn’t just finding a fossil but using proper tools: I learned how to angle the hammer, chip away safely and patiently, and marvel at the tiny fragments that told a story of creatures older than dinosaurs. It felt like stepping into a real-life adventure, and afterward, tucked into my tent by the waves, I couldn’t stop thinking about how much more there must be waiting to be discovered.
questions.answer_ch: 仍然让我心跳加速的记忆是我蹲在卢尔沃斯湾的碎石上，手上握着我第一块真正的化石——一块我刚刚用爸爸的小锤子和凿子从岩石上凿下来的鱼龙骨头。这种激动的感觉我从未体验过，就好像我从深远的过去挖掘出了一件真正的宝藏，它让我想起玛丽·安宁在为我加油。这种新体验不仅仅是发现化石，而是使用真正的工具：我学会了如何调整锤子的角度，小心而耐心地凿削，惊叹于那些讲述比恐龙更古老生物故事的小碎片。这感觉就像步入了一场现实生活的探险，之后，我躺在海浪边的帐篷里，脑海中不断想着还有多少东西在等待被发现。

questions.question_en: How do you and your family celebrate the Summer Bank Holiday—BBQ, day trip, or visiting relatives?
questions.question_ch: 你和你的家人如何庆祝夏季银行假期——烧烤、一天的短途旅行，还是拜访亲戚？
questions.answer_en: On Summer Bank Holiday we nearly always pack a picnic and set off with Dad for a day trip – sometimes to Richmond Park to spot the deer, other times to Kew Gardens or up into the Chiltern Hills – and often we end up staying with Grandma and Grandpa in the Cotswolds. We load the car with my binoculars, a flask of elderflower cordial, my notebook and pencils, and Mum’s famous whole-meal toast with marmalade. At Grandma’s there’s usually a barbecue or a take-over of the garden for a Sunday Roast under the chestnut trees, while Lucy and I chase butterflies and inspect ants’ nests. If it’s drizzly (as Bank Holiday Mondays so often are) we retreat indoors to board games or help Grandpa with his workshop projects. By evening, we’re all sandy-footed and leaf-stained, bellies full of roast lamb or spicy sausage rolls, and it feels like the perfect way to stretch out summer before school starts again.
questions.answer_ch: 在夏季银行假日，我们几乎总是打包野餐，跟爸爸出发去一天的短途旅行——有时去理查德公园看鹿，其他时候去基尤花园或前往奇尔滕山脉——我们常常最后留在科茨沃尔德与奶奶和爷爷在一起。我们把双筒望远镜、接骨木花果汁瓶、我的笔记本和铅笔，还有妈妈著名的全麦果酱吐司装进车里。在奶奶家，通常会有烧烤或在栗树下进行的周日烤肉，而露西和我则追逐蝴蝶，检查蚂蚁窝。如果下着小雨（银行假日的星期一常常是这样），我们就退到室内玩棋盘游戏或帮助爷爷完成他的车间项目。到了晚上，我们的脚上沾满了沙子和树叶，肚子里饱含着烤羊腿或香肠卷，这感觉是拉长夏天、为学校重新开学前做好准备的完美方式。

questions.question_en: When you watch the US Open at home, which aspect of the tournament—score keeping, player styles, or fashion—interests you most?
questions.question_ch: 当你在家观看美国公开赛时，比赛的哪个方面——计分、球员风格还是时尚——最吸引你？
questions.answer_en: When I watched the US Open at home, what I found most exciting wasn’t the chalk‐white scorecards or the colorful outfits but the way each player moved and struck the ball. I’d sit on the sofa with my binoculars around my neck—Dad laughed, saying I was overdoing it—and immediately lean forward when someone fired off a slice or sprinted along the baseline. I loved how Serena’s powerful serve seemed to rumble through the court, how Alcaraz danced on his toes before a drop shot, and how each player’s unique style of footwork, spin and stroke spun a new story point by point. Fashion was fun, and knowing the score kept me guessing, but it was the pure poetry of their movements and how they solved each rally that made me feel like I was part of their game.
questions.answer_ch: 当我在家观看美国网球公开赛时，我觉得最兴奋的不是白色的记分卡或色彩缤纷的服装，而是每位选手的移动和击球方式。我会坐在沙发上，望远镜挂在脖子上——爸爸笑着说我过于夸张——一看到有人发出切球或沿着底线冲刺，我就立刻向前倾身。我喜欢塞雷娜那强有力的发球似乎在球场上隆隆作响的感觉，阿尔卡拉斯在击球前踮起脚尖的舞蹈姿态，以及每位选手独特的步法、旋转和击球风格每个细节都在讲述新的故事。时尚很有趣，知道比分让我保持猜测，但正是他们肢体的纯粹诗意和解决每个回合的方式让我感觉自己成为了他们比赛的一部分。
